\item[(ii)] Let $\overline  \sX$ be the disconnected inverse limit of $\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \mathcal{X}, x_0\right)}$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_topological_inv_lim_defn}), let $\overline  p:  \overline  \sX \to \sX$ be the natural covering. Suppose that
	$$
	A_0\left(\overline  \sX\right)\bydef C_0\left(\lift_{ \overline{p}}\left[A_0\left(  \sX\right)\right] \right).
	$$
If $\overline \H_a$ is the space of the atomic representation $\overline{\pi}_a :A_0\left(\overline  \sX\right) \hookto B\left( \overline \H_a \right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{atomic_repr_defn}), $\widehat{  \mathcal X}$ is the projective limit $\varprojlim \sX_\la$ of topological spaces and $\widehat \H_a$ is the space of the atomic representation $\widehat{\pi}_a : C^*\text{-}\varinjlim_\La A_0\left(\sX_\la\right) \hookto B\left( \widehat \H_a \right)$ then there is the natural isomorphism
$$
\overline \H_a \cong \widehat \H_a.
$$.
\item[(iii)] If $\left\{a_\la \in \widehat A\right\}_{\la \in \La}$ is a bounded strongly convergent in $B\left( \widehat \H_a \right)$ net then the strong limit $\overline a= \lim \widehat\pi_a\left(a_\la \right)$ is given by
\be\label{top_strong_eqn}
\begin{split}
\overline a\xi=\overline a \left(...~, \underbrace{ \xi_{\widehat x}}_{\widehat x^{\mathrm{th}}~\mathrm{place}},... \right)= \left(...~, \underbrace{ \overline a_{\widehat x}\xi_{\widehat x}}_{\widehat x^{\mathrm{th}}~\mathrm{place}},... \right); \\
 \xi=\left(...~, \underbrace{ \xi_{\widehat x}}_{\widehat x^{\mathrm{th}}~\mathrm{place}},... \right) \in {\widehat \H}_{a} =\bigoplus_{\widehat x\in \widehat \sX} \widehat\H_{ \widehat x}
\end{split}
\ee
where $a_{\widehat x} \in B\left(\ {\widehat \H}_{\widehat x} \right)$ is the strong limit $a_{\widehat x}  = \lim_{\la \in \La }\rep_{ \widehat{x}}\left( a_\la\right)$. 
\end{itemize}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	(i) The spectrum of $A_0\left( \sX_\la\right)$ is $\sX_\la$, and taking into account the Lemma \ref{inverse_lim_sp_lem} one concludes that spectrum of the $C^*$-inductive limit  $C^*\text{-}\varinjlim_\La A_0\left(\sX_\la\right)$ is the projective limit $\varprojlim \sX_\la$.\\
	(ii) Denote by $\widehat\sX\stackrel{\text{def}}{=} \varprojlim \sX_\la$ and $\widehat A\stackrel{\text{def}}{=} C^*\text{-}\varinjlim_\La A_0\left(\sX_\la\right)$. The space $\overline  \sX$ is the spectrum of  	$A_0\left(\overline  \sX\right)$. From (ii) of the Lemma \ref{top_spec_top_constr_lem} it follows that there is the bijective continuous map $\overline{\widehat p}: \overline  \sX \to \widehat  \sX$. If $x \in \sX$, $\widehat x \in \widehat\sX$, $\overline x \in \overline \sX$ are points and $\rep_{x} : A_0\left(\sX\right)\to B\left(\H_{x}\right)$, $\rep_{\overline x} : A_0\left( \overline\sX\right)\to B\left(\overline\H_{ \overline x}\right)$, $\rep_{\widehat x} :  \widehat A\to B\left(\H_{\widehat x}\right)$ are corresponding irreducible representations then there are natural isomorphisms
	\bean
	\overline\H_{ \overline x} \cong \H_{\overline p\left(\overline x\right)},\\
	\widehat\H_{ \widehat x} \cong \H_{\widehat p\left(\widehat x\right)}\\
	\eean
	where $\widehat p: \widehat \sX \to \sX$ is the natural surjective map.
	It follows that 
	$$
	\overline\H_{ \overline x} \cong \widehat\H_{\overline{\widehat p} \left( \overline x\right) }
	$$
	and taking into account
	\bean
	\overline\H_{a} =\bigoplus_{\overline x\in \overline \sX} \overline\H_{ \overline x},\\
	\widehat\H_{a} =\bigoplus_{\widehat x\in \widehat \sX} \widehat\H_{ \widehat x}\cong \bigoplus_{ \overline x \in \overline \sX} \overline\H_{ \overline{\widehat p}\left( \overline x\right)}
	\eean
	one has
	$
	\overline\H_{a} \cong \widehat\H_{a}
	$.\\
		(iii)  Follows from the Lemma \ref{direct_sum_strong_lim_lem}.
	\end{proof}


\begin{empt}\label{top_spec_empt}
	Consider the specialization of the Lemma  \ref{top_atomic_lem} such that\\ $A = \left(\sX, \left\{\C_x\right\}_{x \in \sX}, \sF\right)= C_0\left(\sX \right) $,   $A_0 = C_0$, and the given by \eqref{top_alg_cat} category equals to
	\begin{equation}\label{top_talg_cat_eqn}
	\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}_{ C_0\left(\sX \right) } = \\
	=\left(\left\{ C_0\left( p_\la\right) :  C_0\left(\sX \right)  \hookto  C_0\left(\sX_\la \right)\right\}, \left\{ C_0\left( p_\nu^\mu\right) :  C_0\left(\sX_\nu \right) \hookto  C_0\left(\sX_\mu \right)\right\}\right).
	\end{split}
	\end{equation}
	For any $\widehat x \in \widehat \sX$ the corresponding irreducible representation is the $\C$-linear map
	\bean
	\rep_{\widehat x} : \widehat A\to \C;\\
	\widehat a \mapsto \widehat a_{\widehat x} =\widehat a\left(\widehat x\right) \
	\eean
	and taking into account (iii) of the Lemma \ref{top_atomic_lem} any special element $\overline a$ (cf. Definition \ref{special_element_defn}) of the category \eqref{top_talg_cat_eqn} corresponds to a family
	$
	\left\{a_{\widehat{x}}\in \C\right\}_{\widehat{x}\in \widehat{\sX}}
	$. 
	Similarly any weakly special element $\overline b = \widehat c ~\overline a ~\widehat d$ with $\widehat c, \widehat d \in \widehat{ C_0\left( {\sX}\right)}$ corresponds to a family
	$
	\left\{b_{\widehat{x}}\in \C\right\}_{\widehat{x}\in \widehat{\sX}},
	$
	If $\Xi\left(	\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}\right) }  \right)$ is a $\widehat{ C_0\left( {\sX}\right)}$-bimodule of weakly special elements (cf. Definition \ref{weakly_spec_defn}) and $D^*\left( \widehat{\sX}\right)$ the $C^*$- algebra of all (possibly discontinuous) bounded maps $\widehat{\sX} \to \C$ then the above construction gives is the  $\C$-linear map
		\be\nonumber
	\begin{split}
	\Xi\left(	\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}\right) }  \right)\to D^*\left( \widehat{\sX}\right).
	\end{split}
	\ee
Taking into account the bijective map $\overline\sX \to \widehat{\sX}$ one has  the  $\C$-linear map
	\be\label{comm_sp_x_eqn}
	\begin{split}
		\phi:\Xi\left(	\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}\right) }  \right)\to D^*\left( \overline{\sX}\right).
	\end{split}
	\ee
\end{empt}
%Indeed the image of $\phi$ is contained in the *-algebra of bounded D-Borel functions (cf. \ref{st_rep_sec}).

\begin{lemma}\label{comm_disc_inc_lem}
	If $\overline{A}$ is the disconnected infinite noncommutative covering of $\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}\right)}$ then the map \eqref{comm_sp_x_eqn} yields the natural injective *-homomorphism
	\be\label{comm_inc_eqn}
	\varphi:\overline{A}\hookto D^*\left( \overline{\sX}\right).
	\ee
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	 Since $\overline{A}$ is the $C^*$-norm completion of $f^\Xi\left(\Xi\left(	\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}\right) }  \right) \right)$ the map \eqref{comm_sp_x_eqn} uniquely defines the map $\varphi$. From  the Lemma \ref{top_atomic_lem} it turns out that $\varphi$ is injective.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}\label{comm_c0_inc_lem}
	If $C_0\left( \overline{\sX}\right) \subset D^*\left( \overline{\sX}\right)$ is the natural inclusion then 
in the situation ot the Lemma \ref{comm_disc_inc_lem} one has
$$
C_0\left( \overline{\sX}\right)\subset \varphi\left( \overline{A}\right).
$$
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
	From 	$\widehat \H_{a} =\bigoplus_{\overline x\in \overline \sX} \C_{\overline{ x}}$ it follows that there is the natural representation $\rho: C_0\left( \overline \sX\right) \to B\left(\widehat \H_{a} \right)$. Also from the Definition \ref{main_defn} it follows that there is the representation $\phi: \overline{A}\to \widehat \H_{a}$. This lemma means that
	$$
	\rho\left( C_0\left( \overline \sX\right)\right) \subset \phi\left(  \overline{A}\right).
	$$  
	Denote by	$\overline{p}: \overline{   \mathcal X } \to \sX$ and $\overline{p}_\la: \overline{   \mathcal X } \to \sX_\la$ the natural coverings. Let $\widehat G \bydef \varprojlim_{\la\in\La}  G\left(\left.\sX_\la~\right|~ \sX\right)$, $\quad G_\la \bydef \ker\left(  \widehat G\to  G\left(\left.\sX_\la~\right|~ \sX\right)\right) $, and let $C_0\left(\sX_\la \right)^{\sim}$ be given by \eqref{unital_notation_eqn}. Let  $ \desc_{\overline p_\la}$ be the $\overline p_\la$-descend  (cf. Definition \ref{top_lift_desc_defn}).
	If $\overline a \in C_c\left(\overline\sX\right)_+$ is a positive function then $\overline{   \mathcal U } \bydef \left\{\left.\overline x \in \overline{   \mathcal X }\right| \overline a \left(\overline x\right)> 0\right\}$ is an open set.
	Suppose that  $\overline{   \mathcal U } \subset \overline{   \mathcal X }$ is homeomorphically mapped onto $\sU = \overline{p}\left(  \overline{   \mathcal U }\right)  \subset {   \mathcal X }$. Let us prove that $\overline a'\bydef \rho\left( \overline a\right)\in  B\left(\widehat \H_a \right)$ is $\pi_a$-special. Suppose  $\la_0 \in \La$, $\eps > 0$ and  $z \in A_{\la_0}^{\sim}$ and check that $\overline a'$
	satisfies  to the conditions (a), (b) of the Definition \ref{special_element_defn}.
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item[(a)] 	Let 
		$f_\eps: \R \to \R$ is a continuous function given by 
		\eqref{f_eps_eqn}. From \\$\supp f_\eps\left( z^*\overline a' z\right) \subset \supp z^*\overline a' z = \left( \supp z^*\overline a' z\right)^2 \subset \supp \overline a' \subset \overline\sU$ and the Remark \ref{comm_lift_desc_sum_strong_rem} it turns out that if $a_\la \bydef \desc_{\overline{p}_\la}\left(z^*\overline a' z \right)\in C_0\left(\sX_\la \right)$,   $\quad a^\eps_\la \bydef f_\eps\left( \desc_{\overline{p}_\la}\left(z^*\overline a' z \right)\right) \in C_0\left(\sX_\la \right)$ and $b_\la\bydef  \desc_{\overline{p}_\la}\left(z^*\overline a' z \right)^2\in C_0\left(\sX_\la \right)$. From the Lemma \ref{comm_lift_desc_sum_strong_lem} it follows that
		\be\label{top_specc_a_eps_eqn}
		\begin{split}
			\sum_{g\in G_\la } \pi_a \left(z\right)^*\left(  g\overline a'\right) \pi_a\left( z\right)   = \pi_a\left(a_\la\right) ,\\
			\sum_{g\in G_\la } f_\eps\left(\pi_a \left(z\right)^* \left( g\overline a'\right) \pi_a\left( z\right)\right)  = \pi_a\left(a^\eps_\la \right) ,\\
			\sum_{g\in G_\la  } \left(\pi_a \left(z\right)^* \left( g\overline a'\right) \pi_a\left( z\right)\right)^2    = \pi_a\left(b_\la \right)   
		\end{split}
		\ee
		where sums of the above series mean the strong convergence. The system of equations \eqref{top_specc_a_eps_eqn} is a specialization of \eqref{spec_a_eps_eqn}.
		\item[(b)] 	From the  Lemma \eqref{comm_lift_desc_sum_strong_lem} it turns out that
		\be\label{top_desc2_eqn}
		\begin{split}
			\forall \mu, \nu \in \La \quad	\nu \ge \mu \ge \la \quad \Rightarrow \\\Rightarrow \quad \sum_{g \in G\left(\left.\sX_\nu\right|\sX_\mu\right)} g\left( z^* a_\nu z\right)= \desc_{{p}^\mu_\nu}	\left( z^* a_\nu z\right)\text{ AND }\\
			\text{ AND }\sum_{g \in G\left(\left.\sX_\nu\right|\sX_\mu\right)} g\left( z^* a_\nu z\right)^2= \desc_{{p}^\mu_\nu}	\left( z^* a_\nu z\right)^2
		\end{split}
		\ee
		where $p^\mu_\nu: \sX_\mu \to \sX_\nu$ is the natural covering.
		The equation \eqref{top_desc2_mu_eqn} yields the following
		\be\label{top_mu_specialp_set_eqn}
		\forall \mu, \nu \in \La \quad	\nu \ge \mu \ge \la  \Rightarrow  \left\|\left(z^* a_\mu z\right)^2  - \sum_{g \in G\left(\left.\sX_\nu\right|\sX_\mu\right)} g\left( z^* a_\nu z\right)^2\right\| =0
		\ee
		which is a specialization of \eqref{special_set_eqn}.
		
	\end{enumerate}
	Now taking into account the Lemma	\ref{top_comp_sum_lem} one concludes that $C_c\left( \overline{\sX}\right)_+\subset \varphi\left( \overline{A}\right)$. Since $C_c\left( \overline{\sX}\right)$ is dense in $C_0\left( \overline{\sX}\right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{c_c_def_1}) and $\overline{   A}$ is $C^*$-norm closed  we have $C_0\left( \overline{\sX}\right)\subset \varphi\left( \overline{A}\right)$.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}\label{comm_main_lem}
	Suppose that $\mathcal X$ is a  locally compact, locally connected, Hausdorff space.	
	Let $\overline f \in D^*\left(\overline\sX \right)_+$ be a positive bounded discontinuous function such that following conditions hold:
	 \begin{itemize}
	 	\item [(a)]  If $f_\eps$ is given by \eqref{f_eps_eqn} then for any  $\eps \ge 0$, $\la \in \La$ then for any $\overline x \in \overline \sX$ there is a strongly convergent in $B\left(\H_{\overline x} \right)\cong B\left(\H_{\overline p\left( \overline x\right)}  \right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{strong_topology_defn}) series. 
	 	$$
	 \overline f^\eps  =	\sum_{g\in \ker\left( \widehat G\to  G\left(\left.\sX_\la~\right|~\sX \right)\right) }~~ \left( g f_\eps\left(\overline a \right) \right) \left(\overline x \right)
	 	$$
	 such that the function $\overline f^\eps = \lift^{\overline p_\la}_{\overline\sU} \left(f^\eps_\la \right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_lift_desc_defn}) and $f^\eps\in C_0\left( \sX_\la\right) $.
	 	\item[(b)] Denote by $f_\la \stackrel{\mathrm{def}}{=} f^{\eps = 0}_\la$.  For all $\delta > 0$ there is $\la_0 \in \La$ such that if $\la > \la_0$ and
	 	\be\label{comm_spec_h_eq_eqn}
	 	\begin{split}
	 		\sU_{\la_0} \bydef \left\{ \left.x_{\la_0} \in  \sX_{\la_0} \right| f_{\la_0}\left(x_{\la_0}  \right)  \ge \delta\right\},\\
	 		\sU_{\la} \bydef \left\{ \left.x_{\la} \in  \sX_{\la} \right| f_{\la}\left(x_{\la}  \right) \ge \delta\right\}
	 	\end{split}
	 	\ee
	 	then	the restriction $\left.p^\la_{\la_0}\right|_{	\sU_{\la}}: \sU_{\la}\xrightarrow{\approx} \sU_{\la_0}$ is bijective.	
	 \end{itemize}
	
Then one has $\overline f \in C_0\left(\overline \sX\right)$.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
	Suppose  $\la_0$ satisfies to the condition (b) of this lemma. If
\be\label{top_pm_eqn}
	\overline \sU = \bigcap_{\la \ge \la_0} \overline p^{-1}_\la \left(\sU_\la\right) 
\ee
	then the restriction $\left.\overline p_\la\right|_{\overline \sU}: \overline \sU \to \sU_\la$ is a bijection for any $\la \ge \la_0$. Really if there are $\overline x_1, \overline x_2 \in \overline \sU$ such that   $\overline p_\la\left( \overline x_1\right)  = \overline p_\la\left( \overline x_2\right)$ and $\overline x_1\neq \overline x_2$ then there is nontrivial $ g \in \widehat G$ such that $\overline x_2 = g\overline x_1$. So there is $\la > \la_0$ such that $h_\la \left(g\right) \in G\left(\left.\sX_\la\right| \sX_{\la_0} \right)$ is not trivial (where $h_\la$ is the natural surjective homomorphism $\widehat G \to  G\left(\left.\sX_\la\right| \sX_{\la_0} \right)$). It follows that $\overline p_\la\left( \overline x_1\right)  \neq \overline p_\la\left( \overline x_2\right)$ but from \eqref{top_pm_eqn} it follows that $\overline p_\la\left( \overline x_1\right) , \overline p_\la\left( \overline x_2\right)\in \sU_\la$. Otherwise $p^\la_{\la_0}\left(\overline p_\la\left( \overline x_1\right) \right) = p^\la_{\la_0}\left(\overline p_\la\left( \overline x_2\right) \right)$ so $\left.p^\la_{\la_0}\right|_{	\sU_{\la}}: \sU_{\la}\xrightarrow{\approx} \sU_{\la_0}$ is not bijective, it is a contradiction with (b). Let $\overline x\in\overline \sU$ be a point and $x = \overline p\left(\overline x \right)\in\sX$. There is open connected neighborhood $\sU$ of $x$ such that  $\sU$ is evenly covered by $\overline p$ and  $\sU \subset p_{\la_0}\left( \sU_\la\right)$. For any $\la \in \La$ we select a connected  neighborhood $\sU'_\la$ of $\overline p_\la\left(\overline x \right)\in \sX_\la$ which is homeomorphically mapped onto $\sU$. The set 
	$$
\overline\sU'\bydef	\bigcap_{\la \in \La}\overline p_\la^{-1}\left(\sU'_\la \right) 
	$$
	is open with respect to the given by the Lemma \ref{top_spec_top_constr_lem} topology, so from $\overline\sU'\subset \overline\sU$ it turns out that $\overline\sU$ is an open subset of $\overline\sX$.
	 From
	$
		\overline \sU = \left\{ \left.\overline x \in \overline \sX~\right| \overline f\left( \overline x\right) \ge \delta\right\}
	$, it follows that for any $\eps\ge \delta$ following conditions holds
	$$
\overline \sV= \left\{	 \left.\overline x \in \overline \sX~\right| f_\eps\left(\overline f \right)\left(\overline x \right)> 0 \right\} \subset 	\overline \sU.
	$$
	From the condition (a) of this lemma it follows that
	$$
	f_\eps\left(\overline f \right) = \lift^{\overline p_\la}_{\overline{   \mathcal U }}\left(f^\eps_\la \right) 
	$$
(cf. Definition \ref{top_lift_desc_defn}).	It follows that $f_\eps\left(\overline f \right)\in C_c\left( \overline{   \mathcal X }\right)$. From $\left\|f - f_\eps\left(\overline f \right)\right\|< \eps$ one has a $C^*$-norm limit $\overline f = \lim_{\eps \to 0}f_\eps\left(\overline f \right)$. On the other hand  from the Definition \ref{c_c_def_1} it turns out that $\overline f \in C_0\left( \overline{   \mathcal X }\right)$.
	
\end{proof}


\begin{thm}\label{comm_main_f_thm}
	Suppose that $\mathcal X$ is a  locally compact, locally connected, Hausdorff space.
Let $\overline f \in D^*\left(\overline\sX \right)_+$ be a positive bounded discontinuous function such that  following conditions hold:
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item[(a)] If $f_\eps$ is given by \eqref{f_eps_eqn} and  $\eps > 0$ and $\la \in \La$  then there are a pont-wise convergent  series 
	\be\label{comm_special_set1_eqn}
	\begin{split}
		\overline f_\la =	\sum_{g\in \ker\left( \widehat G\to  G\left(\left.\sX_\la~\right|~\sX \right)\right) }~~  g  \overline f ,\\
			\overline f^\eps_\la  =	\sum_{g\in \ker\left( \widehat G\to  G\left(\left.\sX_\la~\right|~\sX \right)\right) }~~  g f_\eps\left(\overline f \right),\\
				\overline h_\la  =	\sum_{g\in \ker\left( \widehat G\to  G\left(\left.\sX_\la~\right|~\sX \right)\right) }~~  g  \overline f^2.
	\end{split}
		\ee
 Moreover there are $f_\la,  f^\eps_\la, h_\la\in C_0\left(\sX_\la \right) $ are such that 
			\be\label{comm_special_set2_eqn}
		\begin{split}
\overline f_\la = \lift_{\overline p_\la}\left( f_\la  \right)  ,\\
\overline f^\eps_\la = \lift_{\overline p_\la}\left( f^\eps  \right),\\
\overline h_\la = \lift_{\overline p_\la}\left( h_\la  \right)
		\end{split}
		\ee
where $ \overline p_\la: \overline \sX \to \sX_\la$ is the natural covering and  $\lift_{\overline p_\la}$ is given by the equation \eqref{comm_lift_d_eqn}.		
		\item[(b)] For all $\eps > 0$ there is $\mu \in \La$ such that $\mu \ge \la_0$ and
		\be\label{comm_special_set_eqn}
		\forall \la  \in \La \quad	 \la \ge \mu  \Rightarrow  \left\|f_\la^2 - h_\la\right\| < \eps.
		\ee
	\end{enumerate}
	Then one has $\overline f \in C_0\left(\overline \sX\right)$.
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
Let $\eps > 0$ be given, and let $\mu \in \La$ be such that for any $\la\ge \mu \ge \la_0$ a following condition holds
	\begin{equation}\label{comm_delta_eqn}
	\begin{split}
\la\ge \mu \ge \la_0 \quad\Rightarrow\quad \left\|f_\la^2 - h_\la\right\|  < 2\eps^2.
	\end{split}
	\end{equation}	
	For all  $\la> \mu$ denote by  $p_\la\bydef  p^\la_{\mu}: \mathcal X_\la \to\mathcal X_{\mu}$.
Let $\widetilde{x}_1, \widetilde{x}_2 \in \mathcal X_{\la}$  be such that
	\begin{equation}\label{comm_neq_eqn}
	\begin{split}
	\widetilde{x}_1\neq \widetilde{x}_2,\\
	p_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) = p_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right)=x,\\
	f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) \ge  \eps; \quad f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right) \ge \eps.
	\end{split}
	\end{equation}
	From  the equations \eqref{comm_special_set1_eqn}, \eqref{comm_special_set2_eqn} it turns out that
	\begin{equation}\label{comm_mu_la_eqn}
	\begin{split}
f_{\mu}\left(x \right)  = \sum_{\widetilde{x} \in  p_\la^{-1}\left( x\right)  } f_{\la}\left( \widetilde{x}\right),\\
h_{\mu}\left(x \right)  = \sum_{\widetilde{x} \in  p_\la ^{-1}\left( x\right)  } h_{\la}\left( \widetilde{x}\right),\\
f_{\la}\left(\widetilde x \right)  = \sum_{\overline{x} \in  \overline p_\la^{-1}\left( \widetilde x\right)  } \overline f_{\la}\left( \overline{x}\right),\\
h_{\la}\left(\widetilde x \right)  = \sum_{\overline{x} \in \overline p_\la^{-1}\left(\widetilde x\right)  } \overline f^2\left( \overline{x}\right)
	\end{split}
	\end{equation}
for all $x \in \sX_\mu$ and $\widetilde x \in \sX_\la$.
	From the above equation  it turns out that
	\begin{equation*}
	\begin{split}
	f^2_{\la}\left(\widetilde x \right)= \sum_{\overline{x} \in \overline p_\la^{-1}\left( \widetilde x\right)  } \overline f^2\left( \overline{x}\right)
	+ \sum_{\substack{\left(\overline{x}', \overline{x}'' \right)\in\overline p_\la^{-1}\left(\widetilde x \right)\times\overline p_\la^{-1}\left(\widetilde x \right)\\\overline{x}' \neq \overline{x}'' }}~ \overline f\left(\overline{x}' \right) \overline f\left(\overline{x}'' \right)\ge\\\ge \sum_{\overline{x} \in  \overline p_\la^{-1}\left( \widetilde x\right)  } \overline f^2_{\la}\left( \overline{x}\right)= h_{\la}\left(\widetilde x \right).
	\\
	f_{\mu}^2\left(x \right)= \sum_{\widetilde{x} \in p_\la^{-1}\left( x\right)} f_\la^2\left( \widetilde{x}\right) + \sum_{\substack{\left(\widetilde{x}', \widetilde{x}'' \right)\in p_\la^{-1}\left(x \right)\times p_\la^{-1}\left(x \right)\\\widetilde{x}' \neq \widetilde{x}'' }}~ f_\la\left(\widetilde{x}' \right) f_\la\left(\widetilde{x}'' \right)\ge\\
	\ge
	\sum_{\widetilde{x} \in p_\la^{-1}\left( x\right)} f_\la^2\left( \widetilde{x}\right) + f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right)+f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right) f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right)\ge\\\ge \sum_{\widetilde{x} \in p_\la^{-1}\left( x\right)} h_\la\left( \widetilde{x}\right) + 2  f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right)\ge   h_\mu\left( {x}\right) + 2\eps^2, 
	\end{split}
	\end{equation*}
	hence one has 
	$$
\left\|f_\mu^2 - h_\mu\right\|  \ge 2\eps^2.
	$$
However the above equation 	contradicts with 
	\eqref{comm_delta_eqn}, so the situation \eqref{comm_neq_eqn} is impossible. 
It follows that for all $\la > \mu$ one has
	\begin{equation}\label{comm_x1_eq_x2_eqn}
	\begin{split}
	p_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) = p_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right)=x \text{ AND }
	f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) \ge \eps\text{ AND }f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right) \ge \eps\Rightarrow \widetilde{x}_1 = \widetilde{x}_2.
	\end{split}
	\end{equation}
	The equation \eqref{comm_x1_eq_x2_eqn} is equivalent to the condition (b) of the Lemma \ref{comm_main_lem}, so $\overline{f}$ satisfies conditions (a), (b) of the Lemma \ref{comm_main_lem}, hence one has $\overline f \in C_0\left(\overline \sX\right)$. 
 \end{proof}

will be implicitly used. As well as \eqref{spec_a_eps_eqn}  these inclusions enable us replace the equations \eqref{top_specc_a_eps_eqn} with the following equivalent system of equations

		\sum_{g\in G_\la  } \left(z^*\left(  g\overline a\right) z   \right)^2    \in C_0\left( \sX_\la\right) ,\\

where $G_\la \bydef \ker\left(G\left(\left.\overline\sX\right|\sX\right)\to G\left(\left.\sX_\la\right|\sX\right) \right)$ 	(cf. equations \eqref{comp_pt_pro_eqn}).

\begin{corollary}\label{comm_main_cor}
	Suppose that
	\be\nonumber
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{C_0\left(\sX \right) } = \\
	=\left(\left\{C_0\left( p_\la\right) : C_0\left(\sX \right)  \hookto C_0\left(\sX_\la \right)\right\}, \left\{C_0\left( p_\nu^\mu\right) : C_0\left(\sX_\nu \right) \hookto C_0\left(\sX_\mu \right)\right\}\right)
\end{split}
\ee
is a {pointed algebraical  finite covering category} given by the Lemma 	
	 \ref{top_base_point_lem}. If $\overline{A}$ is a  disconnected algebraicical inverse noncommutative limit of $\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}\right)}$ (cf. Definition \ref{disconnected_inf_defn}) then 
	$\overline{A}  \subset C_0\left( \overline{\sX}\right)$ (cf. equation \ref{comm_inc_eqn}).
		
\end{corollary}

\begin{proof}
	Suppose that $\overline a \in D^*\left(\overline\sX \right)$ corresponds to a special element of  $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{C_0\left(\sX \right) }$. If we select any $\la_0\in \La$ and put $z \bydef 1_{C_0\left(\sX_{\la_0}\right)^\sim}\in C_0\left(\sX_{\la_0}\right)^\sim$ then from the conditions (a) and (b) of the Definition \ref{special_element_defn} it turns out that $\overline f\bydef z^*\overline a z$ satisfies to the conditions (a) and (b) of the Theorem \ref{comm_main_f_thm}. It follows that $\overline f \in C_0\left(\overline\sX \right)$. However $\overline f=  1_{C_0\left(\sX_{\la_0}\right)^\sim}~\overline a~ 1_{C_0\left(\sX_{\la_0}\right)^\sim} = \overline a$, hence $\overline a \in C_0\left(\overline\sX \right)$. If  $\widehat x, \widehat y \in C_0\left( \widehat \sX\right)$ then because the natural map $\overline \sX \to\widehat \sX$ is continuous one can assume $\widehat x, \widehat y \in C_b\left( \overline \sX\right)$. It follows that  $\overline b = \widehat x\overline a \widehat y \in C_0\left( \overline \sX\right)$, i.e. any weakly special element $\overline b$ (cf. Definition \ref{weakly_spec_defn}) lies in $C_0\left( \overline \sX\right)$, i.e.  $\overline{b} \subset C_0\left( \overline{\sX}\right)$. On the other hand $\overline{A}$ is the generated by weakly special elements $C^*$-algebra, and $C_0\left( \overline{\sX}\right)$ is $C^*$-norm closed, it turns out that $\overline{A}  \subset C_0\left( \overline{\sX}\right)$.
\end{proof}

\begin{empt}\label{comm_transitive_empt} From the Lemma \ref{comm_c0_inc_lem} and the Corollary \ref{comm_main_cor}  it follows that  the disconnected inverse noncommutative limit of $\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}\right)}$ is isomorphic to $C_0\left( \overline{   \mathcal X }\right)$.

	\ee
	(cf. the Definition \ref{top_cov_trans_defn}  and the Corollary \ref{top_bijectt_cor})

	\be\label{comm_ag_eqn}

	Let $\widetilde{\mathcal X} \subset \overline{\mathcal X}$ be a connected component of $ \overline{\mathcal X}$ then the closed ideal $C_0\left(\widetilde{\mathcal X}\right)\subset C_0\left(\overline{\mathcal X}\right)$ is a maximal connected $C^*$-subalgebra of $C_0\left(\overline{\mathcal X}\right)$. If 
	$$
	G \subset 	G\left(\left.C_0\left(\overline \sX\right) \right|C_0\left(\sX\right)\right)
	$$
	is the maximal among subgroups  $G'
	\subset 	G\left(\left.C_0\left(\overline \sX\right) \right|C_0\left(\sX\right)\right)$ such that $G' C_0\left(\widetilde \sX\right) =C_0\left(\widetilde \sX\right)$ then $G$ is the maximal among subgroups $G''
	\subset G\left(\left.\overline \sX \right|\sX\right)$ such that $G''\widetilde  \sX = \widetilde \sX$ (cf. \eqref{comm_ag_eqn}), or equivalently

	 If $J\subset	G\left(\left.C_0\left(\overline \sX\right) \right|C_0\left(\sX\right)\right)$ is a set of representatives of \\$	G\left(\left.C_0\left(\overline \sX\right) \right|C_0\left(\sX\right)\right)/	G\left(\left.C_0\left(\widetilde \sX\right) \right|C_0\left(\sX\right)\right)$ then  from the \eqref{top_disconnected_repr_eqn} it follows that

$\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right)}$. On the other hand from proof of the Lemma \ref{top_universal_covering_lem}
one has $\varprojlim  \mathfrak{S}_{\left(\sX, x_0\right)}\bydef \widetilde\sX$.\\
		(ii) Follows from the   (i) of this lemma.

\begin{lemma}\label{top_inf_cov_oa_defn}
Consider the above situation. If $\widetilde M$ has a structure of smooth manifold which is induced by $M$ and the covering $\widetilde p:\widetilde M \to M$ then 	$
\left(\Coo_0\left(M\right),\Coo_0\left(\widetilde M\right)  G\left(\left.\widetilde M \right|  M\right)\right) 
$ is an {infinite noncommutative covering}  of $\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\Coo\left( M\right) }$ (cf. Definition \ref{inf_cov_oa_defn}).
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Firstly we prove that $\Coo_0\left(\widetilde M\right)$   {is subordinated to}  $	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\Coo_0\left( M\right) } $ (cf. Definition \ref{inf_cov_oa_sub_defn}), i.e. it satisfies to equations \eqref{inf_cov_oa_sub1_eqn}-\eqref{inf_cov_oa_sub3_eqn}. From
\bean
\Coo_0\left( M_\la\right)\Coo_0\left( \widetilde M\right) \subset \Coo_0\left( \widetilde M\right),\\
\Coo_0\left( \widetilde M\right)\Coo_0\left( M_\la\right) \subset \Coo_0\left(\widetilde M\right),\\
\eean 
it follows that $\Coo_0\left( \widetilde M\right)$ satisfies to the equations \eqref{inf_cov_oa_sub1_eqn}, \eqref{inf_cov_oa_sub2_eqn}. If  $\widetilde b \in K\left( C_0\left( \widetilde M\right)\right)\cong  C_c\left( \widetilde M\right)$ then $\supp \widetilde b$ is compact. Let $\widetilde f \in C_c\left( \widetilde M\right)$ be a covering sum for $\supp \widetilde b$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_covering_sum_defn}). One can select $\widetilde f$ such that $\widetilde f\in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde M\right)$ (cf. Proposition \ref{top_smooth_part_unity_prop}). A set $\supp \widetilde f$ is compact, from the Lemma \ref{top_comp_la_lem}  it turns out that there is $\la_0\in \La$ such that $\supp \widetilde f$ is homeomorphically mapped   onto $\widetilde p_{\la_0} \left(\supp \widetilde f \right) \subset M_{\la_0}$ where $\widetilde p_{\la_0}:\widetilde M\to M_{\la_0}$ is the natural covering. If $\desc_{\widetilde p_{\la_0}}$ is the $\widetilde p_{\la_0}$-descent (cf. Definition \ref{top_lift_desc_defn}) and
 $\widetilde a' = \widetilde a'' \bydef \desc_{\widetilde p_{\la_0}}\left( \widetilde f \widetilde a\right)\in \Coo_c\left(M_{\la_0} \right)\subset \bigcup_{\la\in \La}\Coo_0\left(M_\la \right)$ then one has 
 $$
 \widetilde b \widetilde a=\widetilde b \widetilde a', \quad \widetilde a \widetilde b = \widetilde a''.
 $$
 The above equation is a specialization of \eqref{inf_cov_oa_sub3_eqn}, i.e. $\Coo_0\left(\widetilde M\right)$   {is subordinated to}  $	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\Coo_0\left( M\right) } $ (cf. Definition \ref{inf_cov_oa_sub_defn}).
 
 If $\Coo_0\left(\widetilde M\right)$   {is not a maximal subordinated to}  $	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\Coo_0\left( M\right) }$ algebra then there is   a  subordinated to   $	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\Coo_0\left( M\right) }$ algebra $\widetilde A'\subset C_0\left(\widetilde M \right) $ such that $\Coo_0\left(\widetilde M\right)\subsetneqq \widetilde A'$. If $\widetilde a \in \widetilde A'\setminus \Coo_0\left(\widetilde M\right)$
then there is $\widetilde x_0$ such that $\widetilde a$ is not smooth at $\widetilde x_0$. There is $\widetilde b \in  \Coo_c\left(\widetilde M\right)$ such that one has a  neighborhood $\widetilde \sU$ of $\widetilde x_0$ which satisfies to the following condition $\widetilde b\left( \widetilde \sU\right) = \{1\}$. For all $\widetilde a\in\bigcup_{\la\in\La}\Coo_0\left( M_\la\right) $ the function $\widetilde b\widetilde a'$ is smooth. But  the function $\widetilde b\widetilde a$  is not smooth at  $\widetilde x_0$. So the algebra $\widetilde A'$ does not satisfy to \eqref{inf_cov_oa_sub3_eqn} it follows that  $\Coo_0\left(\widetilde M\right)$   {is  a maximal subordinated to}  $	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\Coo_0\left( M\right) }$ algebra.


 \end{proof}

\begin{lemma}\label{comm_lift_desc_sum_mu_strong_lem}
	Consider the  situation \ref{top_mu_empt}. Suppose that  $\mathcal U\subset \mathcal X$  is a connected open subset evenly {covered} by $\overline{\mathcal U}\subset \overline{\mathcal X}$. If $\overline a \in C_0\left(\overline\sX \right)$ be  an  element such that 
	$\supp \overline a \subset \overline \sU$ then the following conditions hold:
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item [(i)] The series 	
		\be\label{comm_lift_desc_sum_mu__strong_eqn}
		\sum_{g \in G\left(\left.\overline{\sX}~\right|\sX\right) } \pi_\tau\left( g\overline{a}\right).
		\ee 
		is convergent in the strong  topology of $B\left(L^2\left(\overline  \sX , \overline \mu\right)\right)$  (cf. Definition \ref{strong_topology_defn}).
		\item[(ii)] 
		\be\label{comm_desc_sum_mu_strong_eqn}
		\begin{split}
			\sum_{g \in G\left(\left.\overline{\sX}~\right|\sX\right) } \pi_\tau\left( g\overline{a}\right)  = \pi_\tau\left(  \desc_{\overline p}\left( \overline{a}\right)\right)
		\end{split}
		\ee
		where $\desc_{\overline p}$ means the descent (cf. Definition \ref{top_lift_desc_defn}).
	\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	(i) Let $\eps > 0$ and $\xi \in L^2\left(\overline  \sX , \overline \mu\right)$ be given. There is a compact set $\overline \sY\subset \overline\sX$ such that $\left\|\chi_{\overline  \sY } \xi\right\|  \left\|\overline a\right\| < \eps$ where $\chi_{\overline  \sY }\in L^\infty\left(\overline  \sX \right) $ is the characteristic function of $\overline  \sY$. Since $\overline \sY$ is compact there is a finite subset $G' \subset G\left(\left.\overline{\sX}~\right|\sX\right)$ such that $\overline  \sY\cap\left( \bigcup_{g\in  \left(G\left(\left.\overline{\sX}~\right|\sX\right)\setminus G'\right)} g \overline{\mathcal U}\right)  = \emptyset$. From the above construction it follows that for any finite set $G \subset G\left(\left.\overline{\sX}~\right|\sX\right)$ one has
	$$
	G'\subset G \quad \Rightarrow\quad \left\|\left( 	\sum_{g \in G } \pi_\tau\left( g\overline{a}\right)-	\sum_{g \in G' } \pi_\tau\left( g\overline{a}\right)\right) \xi\right\|< \eps.
	$$ 
	The above equations means that 	the series \eqref{comm_lift_desc_sum_mu__strong_eqn}
	is convergent in the strong  topology of $B\left(L^2\left(\overline  \sX , \overline \mu\right)\right)$.\\
	(ii) From the proof of (i) it turns out that for any finite set $G \subset G\left(\left.\overline{\sX}~\right|\sX\right)$ one has
	$$
	G'\subset G \quad \Rightarrow\quad \left\|\left( 	\sum_{g \in G } \pi_\tau\left( g\overline{a}\right)-\pi_\tau\left(  \desc_{\overline p}\left( \overline{a}\right)\right)\right) \xi\right\|< \eps.
	$$ 
	The above equation means that the strong limit of the series \eqref{comm_lift_desc_sum_mu__strong_eqn} equals to $\pi_\tau\left(  \desc_{\overline p}\left( \overline{a}\right)\right)$.
\end{proof}


\begin{lemma}\label{comm_disc_inc_mu_lem}

		\item[(b)] 	From the  equations \eqref{spec_mu_a_eps_eqn} it turns out that

		The equation \eqref{top_desc2_mu_eqn} yields the following
		\be\label{top_mu_specialp_l_set_eqn}
		\forall \mu, \nu \in \La \quad	\nu \ge \mu \ge \la  \Rightarrow  \left\|\left(z^* a_\mu z\right)^2  - \sum_{g \in G\left(\left.\sX_\nu\right|\sX_\mu\right)} g\left( z^* a_\nu z\right)^2\right\| =0
		\ee
		which is a specialization of \eqref{special_set_eqn}.
		
	\end{enumerate}
	Now taking into account the Lemma	\ref{top_comp_sum_lem} one concludes that $C_c\left( \overline{\sX}\right)_+\subset \varphi\left( \overline{A}\right)$. Since $C_c\left( \overline{\sX}\right)$ is dense in $C_0\left( \overline{\sX}\right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{c_c_def_1}) and $\overline{   A}$ is $C^*$-norm closed  we have $C_0\left( \overline{\sX}\right)\subset \varphi\left( \overline{A}\right)$.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}\label{comm_disc_inci_mu_lem}
	Consider the  situation \ref{top_mu_empt}. 	If $\overline A_{\pi_\tau}$ is the $\pi_\tau$-disconnected infinite noncommutative covering of $\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}\right)}$ then there is an inclusion of $C^*$- algebras
	\be\label{comm_inci_mu_eqn}
	\overline A_{\pi_\tau}\subset	\phi_\tau \left( C_0\left(\overline  \sX \right)\right)
	\ee
	where $\phi_\tau$ is given by the equation \eqref{top_phi_mu_eqn}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	Suppose that $\la_0 \bydef \la_{\text{min}}$ and $z \bydef 1_{C_0\left( \sX_{\la_0}\right)^\sim }\in{C_0\left( \sX\right)^\sim }$.
If $\overline a \in B\left(L^2\left(\overline  \sX , \overline  \mu \right)  \right)$ is $\pi_\tau$-special element the it should satisfy to conditions (a), (b) to Definition \ref{special_element_defn}. In particular one has
	\begin{enumerate}
	\item[(a)] 	If   $f_\eps: \R \to \R$ is a given by \eqref{f_eps_eqn} continuous function given by 
	then for all $\la \ge \la_0$  there are $ a_\la, b_\la, a^\eps_\la \in C_0\left( \sX_\la\right) $ such that
	\be\label{top_mu_spec_a_eps_eqn}
	\begin{split}
		\sum_{g\in G_\la } \pi_\tau \left(z\right)^*\left(  g\overline a\right) \pi_\tau\left( z\right) = 	\sum_{g\in G_\la }  g\overline a = \pi_\tau\left(a_\la \right),\\
		\sum_{g\in G_\la } f_\eps\left(\pi_\tau \left(z\right)^* \left( g\overline a\right) \pi_\tau\left( z\right)\right)=\sum_{g\in G_\la } f_\eps\left(g\overline a\right)     = \pi_\tau\left(a^\eps_\la \right),\\
		\sum_{g\in G_\la  } \left(\pi_\tau \left(z\right)^* \left( g\overline a\right)\pi_\tau\left( z\right)\right)^2=	\sum_{g\in G_\la } \left(g\overline a\right)^2     = \pi_\tau\left(b_\la \right).
	\end{split}
	\ee
	where sums of the above series mean the strong convergence in  $B\left(L^2\left(\overline  \sX , \overline  \mu \right) \right)$.
	\item[(b)] There is $\mu \in \La$ such that $\mu \ge \la_0$ and
	\be\label{top_mu_special_set_eqn}
	\forall \la  \in \La \quad	 \la \ge \mu  \Rightarrow  \left\|a_\la^2 - b_\la\right\| < \eps
	\ee
	where $a_\la, b_\la \in A_\la$ are given by \eqref{spec_a_eps_eqn}.
\end{enumerate}
 Denote by $	\overline f_\la, \overline f^\eps_\la, \overline h_\la\in C_b\left( \overline \sX\right)$ by the following way 
\be\label{comm_special_mu_set2_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\overline f_\la = \lift_{\overline p_\la}\left( a_\la  \right)  ,\\
	\overline f^\eps_\la = \lift_{\overline p_\la}\left( a^\eps  \right),\\
	\overline h_\la = \lift_{\overline p_\la}\left( b_\la  \right).
\end{split}
\ee
where $\overline p_\la: \overline \sX \to \sX_\la$ is the natural covering and  $\lift_{\overline p_\la}$ means the $\lift_{\overline p_\la}$-lift (cf. Definition \ref{top_lift_defn}).
If $\overline f : \overline \sX \to \R$ is given by
$$
\overline f\left(\overline x \right) \bydef \lim_{\la\in \La} a_{\la}\left( \overline p_\la\left( \overline x\right) \right) 
$$ 
then   $\overline f$ is  a Borel-measured function because it is a point-wise limit of the decreasing net $\left\{\overline f_\la\right\}$ of continuous maps. Otherwise
From the Lemma \ref{spec_strong_lim_lem} it follows that there is the following strong limit
\be\label{top_mu_spec_strong_lim_eqn}
\overline a = \lim_{\la \in \La}\pi_\tau\left(a_\la \right)
\ee
so  $\overline f$ is representative of $\overline a$.  Let $\eps$ be given, according to (b) one can select $\mu\in\La$ such that 
\be\label{top_nu_special_set_eqn}
\forall \la  \in \La \quad	 \la \ge \mu  \Rightarrow  \left\|a_\la^2 - b_\la\right\| < 2\eps^2.
\ee
For all  $\la> \mu$ denote by  $p_\la\bydef  p^\la_{\mu}: \mathcal X_\la \to\mathcal X_{\mu}$.
Let $\widetilde{x}_1, \widetilde{x}_2 \in \mathcal X_{\la}$  be such that
\begin{equation}\label{comm_mu_neq_eqn}
	\begin{split}
		\widetilde{x}_1\neq \widetilde{x}_2,\\
		p_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) = p_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right)=x,\\
		a_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) \ge  \eps; \quad a_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right) \ge \eps.
	\end{split}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{comm_mup_la_eqn}
\begin{split}
	a_{\mu}\left(x \right)  = \sum_{\widetilde{x} \in  p_\la^{-1}\left( x\right)  } a_{\la}\left( \widetilde{x}\right),\\
	b_{\mu}\left(x \right)  = \sum_{\widetilde{x} \in  p_\la^{-1}\left( x\right)  } b_{\la}\left( \widetilde{x}\right),\\
	a_{\la}\left(\widetilde x \right)  = \sum_{\overline{x} \in \overline p_\la ^{-1}\left( \widetilde x\right)  } \overline f_{\la}\left( \overline{x}\right).\\
	b_{\la}\left(\widetilde x \right)  = \sum_{\overline{x} \in \overline p_\la ^{-1}\left(\widetilde x\right)  } \overline f^2\left( \overline{x}\right).
\end{split}
\end{equation}
From the above equation  it turns out that
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}
	a^2_{\la}\left(\widetilde x \right)= \sum_{\overline{x} \in  \overline p_\la ^{-1}\left( \widetilde x\right)  } \overline f^2\left( \overline{x}\right)
	+ \sum_{\substack{\left(\overline{x}', \overline{x}'' \right)\in\overline p_\la^{-1}\left(\widetilde x \right)\times\overline p_\la^{-1}\left(\widetilde x \right)\\\overline{x}' \neq \overline{x}'' }}~ \overline f\left(\overline{x}' \right) \overline f\left(\overline{x}'' \right)\ge\\\ge \sum_{\overline{x} \in \left( \overline p_\la\right) ^{-1}\left( \widetilde x\right)  } \overline f^2_{\la}\left( \overline{x}\right)= h_{\la}\left(\widetilde x \right).
	\\
	a_{\mu}^2\left(x \right)= \sum_{\widetilde{x} \in p_\la^{-1}\left( x\right)} a_\la^2\left( \widetilde{x}\right) + \sum_{\substack{\left(\widetilde{x}', \widetilde{x}'' \right)\in p_\la^{-1}\left(x \right)\times p_\la^{-1}\left(x \right)\\\widetilde{x}' \neq \widetilde{x}'' }}~ a_\la\left(\widetilde{x}' \right) a_\la\left(\widetilde{x}'' \right)\ge\\
	\ge
	\sum_{\widetilde{x} \in p_\la^{-1}\left( x\right)} a_\la^2\left( \widetilde{x}\right) + a_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) a_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right)+a_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right) a_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right)\ge\\\ge \sum_{\widetilde{x} \in p_\la^{-1}\left( x\right)} b_\la\left( \widetilde{x}\right) + 2  a_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) a_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right)\ge   b_{\mu}\left( {x}\right) + 2\eps^2, 
\end{split}
\end{equation*}
hence one has 
$$
\left\|a^2_{\mu} -b_{\mu}\right\|  \ge 2\eps^2.
$$
However the above equation 	contradicts with 
\eqref{top_nu_special_set_eqn}, so the situation \eqref{comm_mu_neq_eqn} is impossible. 
It follows that for all $\la > \mu$ one has
\begin{equation}\label{comm_x1_mu_eq_x2_eqn}
\begin{split}
	p_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) = p_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right)=x \text{ AND }
	f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_1\right) \ge \eps\text{ AND }f_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_2\right) \ge \eps\Rightarrow \widetilde{x}_1 = \widetilde{x}_2.
\end{split}
\end{equation}
Now from the Lemma \ref{comm_main_lem} it follows that $\overline f\in C_0\left(\overline\sX\right)$. If $\widehat{C_0\left(\sX \right) }\bydef C^*$-$\varinjlim_{\la\in\La} C\left(\sX_\la \right)$ then there is the natural inclusion   $\widehat{C_0\left(\sX \right) }\subset C_b\left(\overline\sX \right)$ which complies with both inclusions $\widehat{C_0\left(\sX \right) }\subset B\left(L^2\left(\overline  \sX , \overline  \mu \right)\right) $ and $C_b\left(\overline\sX \right)\subset B\left(L^2\left(\overline  \sX , \overline  \mu \right)\right)$. If $\overline b\in B\left(L^2\left(\overline  \sX , \overline  \mu \right)\right)$ is $\pi_\tau$-weakly special (cf. Definition \ref{weakly_spec_defn}) then	\be\nonumber
\overline b=	\pi_\tau\left(\widehat{x}\right)\overline a \pi_\tau\left(\widehat{y}\right)
\ee
where $\widehat{x}, \widehat{y}\in \widehat{C_0\left(\sX \right) }$ and $\widehat a$ is special. From the above construction it follows that there is $\overline g\in C_0\left(\overline\sX\right)$ such that  
$$
\overline b = \varphi_\tau\left( \overline g\right).
$$
or $\overline b = \varphi_\tau\left( \overline g\right)\in\varphi_\tau\left( C_0\left(\overline\sX\right)\right)$. Since 
	$\overline A_{\pi_\tau}$ is the generated by $\pi_\tau$-weakly special elements $C^*$-algebra and $C_0\left(\overline\sX\right)$ is $C^*$-norm closed one has $	\overline A_{\pi_\tau}\subset	\phi_\tau \left( C_0\left(\overline  \sX \right)\right)$.
\end{proof}

\begin{theorem}\label{comm_main_mu_thm}
	Let	$\mathfrak{S}_{\left(\sX, x_0\right)}= \left\{p_\la:\left( \sX_\la, x^\la_0\right) \to \left( \sX, x_0\right)\right\}_{\la \in \La} \in \mathfrak{FinTop}^{\mathrm{pt}}$ be a pointed topological finite covering category such that for any $\mu > \nu$ there is the unique  pointed  covering $p^\mu_{ \nu}: \left(\sX_{\mu}, x^\mu_0 \right) \to \left(\sX_{\nu}, x^\nu_0 \right)$.
	is the unique  pointed  covering $p^\mu_{ \nu}: \left(\sX_{\mu}, x^\mu_0 \right) \to \left(\sX_{\nu}, x^\nu_0 \right)$. Let
	\be\nonumber
	\begin{split}
		\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{C_0\left(\sX \right) } = \\
		=\left(\left\{C_0\left( p_\la\right) : C_0\left(\sX \right)  \hookto C_0\left(\sX_\la \right)\right\}, \left\{C_0\left( p_\nu^\mu\right) : C_0\left(\sX_\nu \right) \hookto C_0\left(\sX_\mu \right)\right\}\right)
	\end{split}
	\ee
	be a given by the Lemma  \ref{top_base_point_lem} {pointed algebraical  finite covering category} (cf. Definition \ref{pointed_defn}). If 	$\pi_\tau: C^*\text{-}\lim_{\la\in \La} C_0\left(  \sX_\la \right)\hookto B\left(L^2\left(\overline  \sX , \overline \mu\right) \right)$
	is a given by \eqref{top_pi_mu_eqn} equivariant  representation
	 then following conditions hold:
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item [(i)] $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right)}$ is $\pi_\tau$-good (cf. Definition \ref{good_defn} !!! ABC to AB GOOD EXER ADD !!!).
		\item[(ii)] The triple\\ $\left(C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right), C_0\left(\varprojlim  \mathfrak{S}_{\left(\sX, x_0\right)}\right),G\left(\left.\varprojlim  \mathfrak{S}_{\left(\sX, x_0\right)}~\right| \mathcal X\right)\right)$ is  the  $\pi_\tau$-infinite noncommutative covering of $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right)}$ (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}).
	\end{enumerate}
	
	
	
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
	A modification of the proof of the Theorem \ref{top_main_thm} yields a proof of this theorem.
	The modification includes replacement of references to the Lemma \ref{comm_c0_inc_lem} and the Corollary \ref{comm_main_cor} with Lemmas \ref{comm_disc_inc_mu_lem} and \ref{comm_disc_inci_mu_lem} respectively.
\end{proof}






\subsection{Universal  coverings and  fundamental groups}
\paragraph*{}
Following theorem gives universal  coverings of commutative $C^*$-algebras. 


\begin{theorem}\label{comm_uni_lim_thm}
	Let $\mathcal X$ be a connected, locally connected, locally compact,  Hausdorff space. If there is   the universal topological covering $\widetilde{p}:\widetilde{\sX}\to \mathcal X$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_uni_cov_defn}) such that $G\left( \left.{\widetilde{\sX}}~\right|\sX\right)$ is residually finite group (cf. Definition \ref{residually_finite_defn}) then $C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right)$ is the universal covering of $C_0\left( {\sX}\right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{fg_bas_defn}).
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
	If $\left\{p_\la: \sX_\la\to \sX\right\}_{\la \in \La}$ is a family of all transitive finite-fold coverings of $\sX$ then from the Theorem \ref{top_fin_thm}  !!! REPLACE \ref{top_fin_cor} it follows that the family of all noncommutative finite-fold coverings of $C_0\left( \sX\right)$ is given by $$\left\{C_0\left( p_\la\right) : C_0\left( {\sX}\right) \hookto C_0\left( {\sX}_\la\right)\right\}_{\la \in \La}.$$ Since $\widetilde{\sX}$ is the universal covering for any $\la \in \La$ there is a covering $\widetilde{p}_\la: \widetilde{\sX} \to \sX_\la$ such that $\widetilde{p}= \widetilde{p}_\la\circ p_\la$.  From the Lemma \ref{comm_t_a_lem} it turns out that $\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left(\sX \right) }=\left\{C_0\left( p_\la\right) : C_0\left( {\sX}\right) \hookto C_0\left( {\sX}_\la\right)\right\}_{\la \in \La}$ is an algebraical finite covering category. From the Lemma \ref{top_res_fin_lem} it follows that any $\widetilde{x}_0 \in \widetilde{\sX}$ yields a  pointed a topological finite covering category $$\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \sX, \widetilde{p}\left(\widetilde{x}_0 \right)  \right) }=\left\{ p_\la: \left( \sX_\la, x^\la_0 \right) \to \left( \sX, x_0 \right)\right\}$$ such that  $\left( \widetilde{\sX}, \widetilde{x}_0\right) $ is the topological inverse noncommutative limit of $\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \sX, \widetilde{p}\left(\widetilde{x}_0 \right)  \right) } $. From the Lemma \ref{top_base_point_lem} the category  $\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \sX, \widetilde{p}\left(\widetilde{x}_0 \right)  \right) }$ yields the pointed algebraical  finite covering category
	\be\label{top_pointed_c_eqn}
	\left(\left\{C_0\left( p_\la\right) : C_0\left( {\sX}\right) \hookto C_0\left( {\sX}_\la\right)\right\}_{\la \in \La}, \left\{C_0\left( p^\mu_\nu\right)  \right\}_{\substack{ \mu, \nu \in \La \\ \mu > \nu}} \right) 
	\ee
	(cf. Definition \ref{pointed_defn}). From the  Theorem \ref{top_main_thm} it follows that $C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$ is the inverse noncommutative limit of the pointed noncommutative finite covering category \eqref{top_pointed_c_eqn}. Taking into account the Definition \ref{fg_bas_defn} we conclude that $C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right)$ is the universal covering of $C_0\left( {\sX}\right)$.
\end{proof}

\begin{cor}\label{comm_uni_lim_cor}
	If $\left( \mathcal X, x_0\right)$ is	a connected, locally path connected, semilocally 1-connected (cf. Definition \ref{top_semi1_defn}),  locally compact,  Hausdorff space such that the fundamental group $\pi_1\left(\sX, x_0 \right)$  is residually finite then following conditions hold:
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item [(i)] $C_0\left(\sX \right) $ {has the algebraical universal  covering}.
		\item[(ii)] There is a pointed algebraical finite covering category $\left(\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left( \sX\right) }, \left\{C_0\left(p^\mu_\nu \right) \right\} \right)$ and the natural  
		group isomorphism 
		\be\label{comm_fg_iso_eqn}
		\pi_1\left( \sX, x_0\right)\cong\pi_1\left( C_0\left(\sX \right), \left\{C_0\left(p^\mu_\nu \right) \right\}\right).
		\ee
	\end{enumerate}
\end{cor}
\begin{proof}
	(i) From the Lemmas \ref{top_simply_con_cov_lem} and \ref{top_uni_exist_spa_lem} it turns out that there is the universal covering $\widetilde{\sX} \to \sX$. From the Corollary \ref{top_cov_pi1_cor} it turns out that $\pi_1\left(\sX, x_0 \right)\approx  G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX\right)$, hence $G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX\right)$ is residually finite. From the Theorem \ref{comm_uni_lim_thm} it follows that $C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$ is the universal covering of $C_0\left(\sX\right)$.\\
	(ii) Let  $\widetilde{p}:\widetilde{\sX} \to \sX$ be the universal covering of $\sX$ and let $\widetilde{x}_0\in \widetilde{\sX}$ be such that $\widetilde{p}\left( \widetilde{x}_0 \right) = x_0$. If $\widetilde{p}_\la: \widetilde{\sX} \to \sX_\la$ are natural coverings and $x^\la_0 = \widetilde{p}_\la\left( \widetilde{x}_0\right)$ then there is a pointed topological finite covering category $ \mathfrak{S}_{\left( \sX, \widetilde{p}\left(\widetilde{x}_0 \right) \right)}= \left\{p_\la:\left( \sX_\la, x^\la_0\right) \to \left( \sX, x_0\right)\right\}$. From the Lemma \ref{top_base_point_lem} there is the associated to $\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \sX, \widetilde{p}\left(\widetilde{x}_0 \right) \right)}$ pointed algebraical finite covering category $\left(\left\{C_0\left( p_\la\right): C_0\left( \sX\right)  \to C_0\left( \sX_\la\right)\right\}, \left\{C_0\left( p^\mu_\nu\right)  \right\}_{\substack{ \mu, \nu \in \La \\ \mu > \nu}} \right)$ such that $C_0\left(\widetilde\sX \right)$ is the inverse limit of it (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}). From \eqref{fg_bas_eqn} it follows that
$$
\pi_1\left(C_0\left(\sX \right) , \left\{C_0\left( p^\mu_\nu\right) \right\} \right) = G\left(\left.C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right) ~\right|~C_0\left( \sX\right)  \right).
$$
Otherwise from the Corollary \ref{top_cov_pi1_cor} it follows that $\pi_1\left( {\mathcal X}, x_0\right)\approx G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX\right)$ and taking into account $G\left(\left.C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right) ~\right|~C_0\left( \sX\right)  \right)\cong G\left(\left. \widetilde{\sX} ~\right| \sX  \right)$ one has
	\be\nonumber
\pi_1\left( \sX, x_0\right)\cong\pi_1\left( C_0\left(\sX \right), \left\{C_0\left(p^\mu_\nu \right) \right\}\right).
\ee
	

	
	% If $\ga:\left[0, 1\right] \to \sX$ is a representative of $\left[\ga\right] \in \pi_1\left( \sX, x_0\right)$ the there is the unique continuous map $\widetilde{ \ga}: \left[0, 1\right] \to \widetilde{\sX}$ such that $\widetilde{ \ga}\left( 0\right)= \widetilde{x}_0$ and $\widetilde{p}\circ \widetilde{\ga}  =\ga$. Since $\widetilde{\sX}$ is simply connected the point $\widetilde{x}'_0$ does not depend on representative of $\left[\ga\right]$. There is the associated to $\widetilde{x}'_0$ pointed algebraical finite covering category $$\left(\left\{C_0\left( p_\la\right): C_0\left( \sX\right)  \to C_0\left( \sX_\la\right)\right\}, \left\{C_0\left( q^\mu_\nu\right)  \right\} \right)$$ (cf. Definition \ref{fg_bas_defn} ). From the \ref{base_point_change_lem} it follows that there is $$\widehat{g} \in \widehat{G}=\varprojlim G\left(\left.C_0\left( \sX_\la\right)~\right|C_0\left( \sX\right) \right)$$ such that
	%\be\label{comm_base_point_change_p_lem_eqn}
%	C_0\left( q^\mu_\nu\right) = h_\mu\left(\widehat{g} \right) \circ 	C_0\left( p^\mu_\nu\right)
%	\ee
%	where $h_\mu: \widehat{G} \to G\left( \left.{{\sX}}_\la~\right|\sX\right)$ is the natural surjective homomorphism and the equation \ref{comm_base_point_change_p_lem_eqn} comes from \eqref{base_point_change_lem_eqn}. One can prove that $\widehat{g} \in G\left( \left.{\widetilde{\sX}}~\right|\sX\right)$ and $\widetilde{x}'_0 = \widehat{g}\widetilde{x}_0$. So there is a map
%	\be\label{comm_fg_bas_eqn}

%		\left[\ga\right] \mapsto \widehat{g}

\end{proof}

\subsection{Coverings of pro-$C^*$-algebras}
\paragraph*{}
Suppose that
\be\nonumber
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \sX, x_0\right) }\bydef\\
\bydef \left\{\left\{p_\la:\left( \sX_\la, x^\la_0\right) \to \left( \sX, x_0\right)\right\}_{\la\in\La}, \left\{p^\mu_{ \nu}:\left( \sX_\mu, x^\mu_0\right) \to \left( \sX_\nu, x^\nu_0\right)\right\}_{\substack{\mu,\nu\in\La\\
		\mu\ge\nu}} \right\}\\
%\in \\
\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \sX, x_0\right) }\in \mathfrak{FinTop}^{\text{pt}}.

\ee

\subsection{Coverings of $O^*$-algebras and quasi $*$-algebras}\label{top_inf_o_sec}
\paragraph*{}
Let $M$ be a finite-dimensional smooth manifold, and let 

\be\label{top_secm_p_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}_{\left( M, x_0\right) }\bydef\\
	\bydef \left\{\left\{p_\la:\left( M_\la, x^\la_0\right) \to \left( M, x_0\right)\right\}_{\la\in\La}, \left\{p^\mu_{ \nu}:\left( M_\mu, x^\mu_0\right) \to \left( M_\nu, x^\nu_0\right)\right\}_{\substack{\mu,\nu\in\La\\
			\mu\ge\nu}} \right\}\\
	%\in \\
	\mathfrak{S}_{\left( M, x_0\right) }\in \mathfrak{FinTop}^{\text{pt}}.
\end{split}
\ee
be a pointed  topological finite covering category  (cf. Definition \ref{top_sec_p_defn}). From the Theorem \ref{top_d_fin_thm} it turns out that there is  a {pointed algebraic finite covering category of $O^*$-algebras} (cf. Definition \ref{comp_o*_defn}) given by
\be\label{top_comp_pt_o*_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{D\left(M \right) } = \left(\left\{\pi_\la: D\left( M\right)  \hookto D\left( M_\la \right) \right\}, \left\{\pi^\mu_\nu\right\}\right).
\end{split}
\ee
such that  $D\left( M \right)$ and  $D\left( M_\la \right)$ are a *-algebras of differential operators $P:\Coo\left( M\right) \to \Coo\left( M\right)$ and $P_\la:\Coo\left( M_\la\right) \to \Coo\left( M_\la\right)$ on $M$ and $M_\la$ respectively (cf. Definition \ref{do_man_defn})   for all $\la\in\La$. Note that for every $\la\in\La$ the smooth structure of $M_\la$ comes from the smooth structure on $M$ and the covering $M_\la\to M$. Injective *-homomorphisms $\pi_\la: D\left( M \right)\hookto D\left( M_\la \right)$ and $\pi^\nu_\mu: D\left( M_\nu \right)\hookto D\left( M_\mu \right)$ come from the coverings $p_\la$ and $p^\mu_\nu$ respectively.  If $\overline M$ is the disconnected inverse limit of $\mathfrak{S}_{\left( M, x_0\right) }$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_topological_inv_lim_defn}) then there are natural coverings $\overline p: \overline M\to M$, $\overline p_\la: \overline M\to M_\la$ which induce the structure of smooth manifold on $\overline M$. So for all $\la \in \La$ there is a natural injective *-homomorphism $D\left( M_\la \right)\hookto D\left(\overline M_\la \right)$. If these injective *-homomorphisms are regarded as inclusions and $\widehat A \bydef \bigcup_{\la \in \La}D\left( M_\la \right)$ then there is the following inclusion
\be\label{top_dinc_eqn}
\widehat A\hookto D\left( \overline M \right)
\ee
Let $\tau : C_0\left(M \right) \to \C$ be a faithful state  and let $L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)$ be explained in  \eqref{top_mu_empt} Hilbert space. 
Then 
\be\label{top_tdd_eqn}
\widehat \D\bydef  \Coo_c\left(\overline M \right)
\ee
 is a dense subspace of $L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)$. There is the natural inclusion
\be D\left( \overline M\right) \subset \L^\dagger\left(\widehat\D \right)
\ee 
(cf. equation \eqref{l_dag_eqn}) and taking into account  \eqref{top_comp_pt_o*_eqn}  one has an inclusion 
\be\label{top_pi_eqn}
\pi: \widehat A\hookto \L^\dagger\left(\widehat\D \right).
\ee
If $\widehat G \bydef \varprojlim G\left(\left.M_\la\right|M\right)$ is the inverse limit (cf. Definition \ref{group_inv_lim_defn}) then the natural action $\widehat G\times \overline M\to \overline M$ induces the action $\widehat G\times L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)\to L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)$ which satisfies to \eqref{o*_dinv_eqn}. Similarly to the Section \ref{top_pd_fin_sec} the bounded part of $D\left( M_\la\right)$ equals to $\Coo\left(M_\la \right) \cap C_b\left(M_\la \right)$ where we natural inclusion $\Coo \left(M_\la \right)\subset  D\left( M_\la\right)$ is implied. The $C^*$-norm completion of  $\Coo\left(M_\la \right) \cap C_b\left(M_\la \right)$ equals to $C_b\left(M_\la \right)$ and $B_\la \bydef C_0\left(M_\la \right)$ is an essential ideal of $C_b\left(M_\la \right)$. Similarly to  \eqref{bl_cat_eqn}
one has  a pointed algebraical  finite covering category
\be\label{top_bl_cat_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}_b\bydef\left\{ \left( B ,  B_{\la} , G\left(\left.M_\la~\right|M \right) , \overline\pi_{\la}\right) \right\}_{\la \in \La}= \\ =\left\{ \left(C_0\left(M \right)  ,  C_0\left( M_{\la}\right)  , G\left(\left.M_\la~\right|M \right) , \overline\pi_{\la}\right) \right\}_{\la \in \La}.
\end{split}
\ee
If $\widehat B\bydef C^*$-$\varinjlim B_\la$ then there is the natural given by \eqref{top_pi_mu_eqn} equivariant representation $\pi_\tau: \widehat{B}\hookto B\left( L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)\right)$. From the Theorem \ref{comm_main_mu_thm} it turns out  that the given by \eqref{top_bl_cat_eqn} pointed algebraical  finite covering category is $\pi_\tau$-good (cf. Definition \ref{good_defn} !!! ABC to AB GOOD EXER ADD !!!) and if $\widetilde M$ is a topological inverse limit of $	\mathfrak{S}_{\left( M, x_0\right) }$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_topological_inv_lim_defn} of then the triple\\ $\left(C_0\left(M\right), C_0\left(\widetilde M\right),G\left(\left.\widetilde M~\right| M\right)\right)$ is  the  $\pi_\tau$-infinite noncommutative covering of $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_b$ (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn} and Theorem \ref{comm_main_mu_thm}). If $\widetilde \H$ is the norm completion of $C_0\left(\widetilde M\right)L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)$ then one has
\be
\begin{split}
	\widetilde \H \cong L^2\left( \widetilde M, \widetilde\mu\bydef \overline\mu|_{\widetilde M}\right) ,\\
	\widetilde \D\bydef \widehat\D \cap \widetilde \H \cong \Coo_c\left( \widetilde M\right) 
\end{split}
\ee
Above construction is a version of the described in \ref{comp_pt_o*_empt} general construction.

\begin{theorem}\label{top_inf_o*_thm}
	In the described above situation if $\pi$ is given by \eqref{top_pi_eqn} then the triple
	$\left(D\left(M \right) , D\left( \widetilde{M}\right) , G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}\right|M\right)\right) $ is the 
	${\pi}$- inverse noncommutative limit (cf. Definition \ref{inv_o*_lim_defn}) of the given by
	\eqref{top_comp_pt_o*_eqn} {pointed algebraic finite covering category of $O^*$-algebras} $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{D\left( M\right) }$  (cf. Definition \ref{comp_o*_defn}) 
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
	For any $\la\in\La$ denote by $\widetilde p_\la: \widetilde{M}\to M_\la$ the natural covering. 
	Let us prove that $D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ is $\pi$-admissible, i.e. it satisfies to the equations \eqref{inv_o*_lim_eqn} CHANGE TO \eqref{inf_cov_o*_sub1_eqn}-\eqref{inv_o*_rlim_eqn}; that is
	\bea\label{top_inv_o*_lim_eqn}
	G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}\right|M\right) D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)  = D\left( \widetilde{M}\right),\\
	\label{top_inv_o*_blim_eqn}
	\widetilde A'_b\bydef C_b\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \cap \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)  \subset M\left(\widetilde{B}_{\pi_\tau}= M\left( C_0\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)  \right)\cong C_b\left( \widetilde{M}\right), \\
	\label{top_inv_o*_llim_eqn}	
	\mathrm{span}~\Coo_c\left(\widetilde{M} \right)  D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)= \mathrm{span}~\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\left(  \bigcup_{\la \in \La}D\left( M_\la \right)\right) ,\\	
	\label{top_inv_o*_rlim_eqn}
	\mathrm{span}~D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\Coo_c\left(\widetilde{M} \right)  = \mathrm{span}~\left( \bigcup_{\la \in \La}D\left( M_\la \right)\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right).	
	\eea
	\begin{itemize}
		\item The equation \eqref{top_inv_o*_lim_eqn} holds because any $g \in G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}\right|M\right)$ corresponds to a diffeomorphism of $\widetilde{M}$.
		\item The equation \eqref{top_inv_o*_blim_eqn} follows from an evident dense inclusion $C_b\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \cap \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)  \subset C_b\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$.
		\item The equation  \eqref{top_inv_o*_llim_eqn}. From $  \left( \bigcup_{\la \in \La}D\left( M_\la \right)\right)\subset   D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ it follows that \\$ \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \left( \bigcup_{\la \in \La}D\left( M_\la \right)\right)\subset \Coo_c\left(\widetilde{M} \right)  D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$.		
		Let  $\widetilde f \in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ and $\widetilde d \in  D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$. There is $\widetilde h \in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ such that $\widetilde h\left(\supp \widetilde f \right)= \{1\}$. From the Lemma \ref{top_comp_la_lem} it follows that there is $\la\in\La$ such that $\supp \widetilde h$ is homeomorphically mapped onto $\widetilde p_\la\left(\supp\widetilde h \right)$. If $d_\la \bydef \desc_{\widetilde p_\la} \left(\widetilde h \widetilde d \right)$ then  $\widetilde f \widetilde d= \widetilde f d_\la$.
		\item The equation  \eqref{top_inv_o*_rlim_eqn} can prove similarly to \eqref{top_inv_o*_llim_eqn} one.
	\end{itemize}

	Now one should prove that any admissible algebra $\widetilde A'$ is a subalgebra of $D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$. If $\widetilde \sU \subset  \widetilde M$ is an open subset then there is an equivalence relation $\sim_{\widetilde\sU}$ on $\widetilde A'$ given by
		$$
		\forall \widetilde a', \widetilde a'' \in \widetilde A' \quad  \widetilde a'\sim_{\widetilde\sU} \widetilde a'' \quad\Leftrightarrow\left( \quad \forall \widetilde b\in \Coo_c\left(\widetilde M \right) \quad \supp \widetilde b \subset  \widetilde\sU\quad \Rightarrow \quad\widetilde a'\widetilde b = \widetilde a''\widetilde b\right). 
		$$
		One can proof than the map
		$\widetilde \sU \mapsto \widetilde A'/\sim_{\widetilde\sU}$ satisfies to the Definition  \ref{presheaf_defn}, i.e. one has a presheaf.  Let $\widetilde{\mathscr A}'$ be an associated sheaf (cf. \ref{sheaf_prdf}). On the other hand from the Example \ref{top_diff_smooth_exm} it follows that there is a sheaf $\mathscr D$ of differential operators $\Coo\left(\widetilde M\right)\to \Coo\left(\widetilde M\right)$.
		If $\widetilde x_0\subset \widetilde M$ that any stalk 
		(cf. Definition \ref{stalk_defn}) of $\widetilde{\mathscr A}'$ at  $\widetilde x_0$ can be represented  by a pair $\left( \widetilde \sU, \widetilde a_{\widetilde \sU}\right) $ 
		where  $\widetilde \sU$ is an open neighborhood of $\widetilde x_0$ and $a_{\widetilde \sU} \in \widetilde A'/\sim_{\widetilde\sU}$. Moreover from the Definition \ref{stalk_defn} one can assume that the closure $\widetilde \sY$ of $\widetilde \sU$ is compact. Let $\widetilde f\in  C_c\left( \widetilde M\right)$ be a covering sum for $ \widetilde \sY$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_covering_sum_defn}). One can suppose that $\widetilde f$ is smooth (cf. Remark \ref{top_smooth_part_unity_rem}).
		If $\widetilde a_{\widetilde \sU}$ is represented by $\widetilde a$ then from 
		$\widetilde f \left(\widetilde \sU \right)=\{1\}$ it follows that  $\widetilde a_{\widetilde \sU}$ can be also represented by $\widetilde a\widetilde f$. From the equation \eqref{hilb_adm_eqn} it follows that there is $a^\cup \in \cup~ A_\la = \cup~D\left(M_\la \right)$ such that $\widetilde a\widetilde f=  a^\cup\widetilde f$. However $ a^\cup\widetilde f\in \Coo_c\left(\widetilde M \right)$, it follows that any stalk at $\widetilde x_0$ corresponds to a stalk of $\mathscr D$. On the other hand from \eqref{adm_inc_eqn} if follows that any stalk of $\mathscr D$
		 can be represented by the stalk of $\widetilde{\mathscr A}'$. It follows that
		$$
		\widetilde{\mathscr A}' = \mathscr D.
		$$
		On the other hand any $\widetilde a' \in \widetilde A'$ corresponds to a global sections of $\widetilde{\mathscr A}'$, i.e. there is an inclusion
		$$
		\widetilde A'\subset\widetilde{\mathscr D}\left(\widetilde M\right)= D\left(\widetilde M\right).
		$$
\end{proof}
Similarly to \eqref{top_comp_pt_o*_eqn} one has 
{pointed algebraic finite covering category of $O^*$-algebras} (cf. Definition \ref{comp_o*_defn}) given by

one can proof the following Theorem
\begin{theorem}\label{top_inf_o*_m_thm}

\begin{lemma}
The given by \eqref{top_comp_pt_qo*_eqn} family $ \mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\left(\Coo_c\left(M \right)', \Coo\left(M \right)    \right) }$  is a \textit{pointed algebraic finite covering category of quasi-$*$-algebras} (cf. Definition \ref{comp_qo*_defn})
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	In this lemma the pair $\left( \mathfrak A, \mathfrak A_0 \right)$ (resp. $\left( \mathfrak A^\la, \mathfrak A^\la_0 \right)$) of the Definition \ref{comp_qo*_defn} corresponds to $\left(\Coo_c\left(M \right)', \Coo\left(M \right)\right) $ (resp. $\left(\Coo_c\left(M_\la \right)', \Coo\left(M_\la \right)\right)$). The given by \eqref{comp_pt_qo*_eqn} {pointed algebraic finite covering category of quasi-$*$-algebras} corresponds to  $\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\left(\Coo_c\left(M \right)', \Coo\left(M \right)    \right) }$.
Now one needs check that the family $ \mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\left(\Coo_c\left(M \right)', \Coo\left(M \right)    \right) }$ satisfies to the conditions (a)-(c) of the Definition \ref{comp_qo*_defn}. However these conditions directly follow from the given by \eqref{top_comp_pt_qo*_eqn} definition of $
	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\left(\Coo_c\left(M \right)', \Coo\left(M \right)    \right) }$.
\end{proof}
