\begin{theorem}\label{top_inf_q*_thm}
	In situation \ref{top_comp_qo*_empt} the triple
	$$
\left(\left(\Coo_c\left(M \right)', \Coo\left(M \right)    \right), \left(\Coo_c\left(\widetilde M \right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde M \right)    \right), G\left(\left. \widetilde M\right| M\right)\right)
$$
 is the 
	${\pi}$- inverse noncommutative limit  (cf. Definition \ref{inv_qo*_lim_defn} MAXI !!! MAXI !!! MAXI !!!) of  the given by \eqref{top_comp_pt_qo*_eqn} {pointed algebraic finite covering category of quasi $*$-algebras} $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{\left(\Coo_c\left(M \right)', \Coo\left(M \right)    \right)  }$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}

	Firstly note that the specific version of the equations \eqref{inv_qo*_rzero_eqn} -\eqref{inv_qo*_rlim_eqn} !!! REPLACE is presented below
	\bea
	\label{top_inv_qo*_rzero_eqn}
	\forall\widetilde a\in \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\quad \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \widetilde{a}= \{0\}\quad \Rightarrow\quad \widetilde{a}= 0,~\quad\quad \\
	\label{top_inv_qo*_lzero_eqn}
	\forall\widetilde a\in  \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\quad \widetilde{a}\Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) = \{0\}\quad \Rightarrow\quad \widetilde{a}= 0,~ \quad\quad\\
	\label{top_inv_qo*_llim_eqn}	\mathrm{span}\left\{ \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)  \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\right\} =\mathrm{span}\left\{  \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \right\},~\quad\quad \\	
	\label{top_inv_qo*_rlim_eqn}\mathrm{span}\left\{ 	 \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \right\} =\mathrm{span}\left\{ \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \right\}.~\quad\quad 
	\eea
	If  $\left\{f_\a\right\}_{\a\in \mathscr A}\subset C_c\left(\widetilde{M} \right)$ is  a family of functions is a given by the  \eqref{comm_direct_empt} then for any compact $\widetilde{\sY}\subset \widetilde{M}$ there is $\a_{\widetilde{\sY}}$ such that for all $\a\ge \a_{\widetilde{\sY}}$ one has $\widetilde f_\a\left( \widetilde \sY\right) = \{1\}$ (cf. Lemma \ref{comm_direct_lem}). Similarly to the Proposition \ref{top_smooth_part_unity_prop} one can assume that $\left\{\widetilde f_\a\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}\subset \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)_+$. If $\left( \widetilde{\mathfrak A}', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right) $ is an admissible quasi *-algebra (cf. Definition \ref{comp_pt_qo*_defn}) then from the equation \ref{inv_qo*_llim_eqn} which in this specialization is equivalent to \ref{top_inv_qo*_llim_eqn}  it follows that
\bean
\forall \widetilde a\in \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\quad \forall \a\in \mathscr A\quad	\widetilde f_\a\widetilde a \in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\left( \bigcup_{\la\in\La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \subset\\
\subset  \text{span} \left\{ \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\left( \bigcup_{\la\in\La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \right\} .
\eean
	On the other hand from $\bigcup_{\la\in\La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\subset \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'$ it turns out that $\widetilde f_\a \widetilde a\in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'$.  For any  $\widetilde b \in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ there is $\a_{\supp \widetilde b}$ such that $f_{\a_{\supp \widetilde b}}\left( \supp \widetilde b\right)= \{1\}$. One has
	\be\label{top_sw_lim_eqn}
\a\ge \a_{\supp b}\quad \Rightarrow \quad \widetilde f_{\a} \ge \widetilde f_{\a_{\supp \widetilde b}}  \quad \Rightarrow \quad	\left\langle \widetilde f_\a\widetilde a , \widetilde b \right\rangle = 	\left\langle \widetilde f_{\a_{\supp \widetilde b}} \widetilde a , \widetilde b \right\rangle
\ee
where $\left\langle \cdot , \cdot \right\rangle: \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'\times \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\to \C$ is the natural pairing.
The equation \eqref{top_sw_lim_eqn} means that the net $ \left\{ \left\langle \widetilde f_\a\widetilde a , \widetilde b \right\rangle\right\} \subset\C$ is convergent, so the net  $ \left\{ \widetilde f_\a \widetilde a\right\} \subset\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'$ is convergent with respect to the weak topology of $\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'$ (cf. Definition \ref{w_topology_defn}). Thus there is a map
\bean
\Psi : \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\to \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)',\\
\widetilde a\mapsto\lim_{\a\in \mathscr A} \widetilde f_\a \widetilde a
\eean 
 If $\widetilde a\in \ker \Psi$ then $\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\widetilde a= \{0\}$ so from \eqref{inv_qo*_rzero_eqn} (or equivalently \eqref{top_inv_qo*_rzero_eqn}) it follows that $\widetilde a=0$. So one has $\ker \Psi = \{0\}$, $\Psi$ is an invective map and any admissible *- algebra $\left( \widetilde{\mathfrak A}', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right) $ is a quasi *-subalgebra  of 
$\left( \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)$.  Thus if we prove that  $\left( \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)$ is admissible then the proof of this lemma would be completed (cf. Definition \ref{inv_qo*_lim_defn} MAXI !!! MAXI !!! MAXI !!!). It means that $\left( \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)$ satisfies to the conditions (a)-(c) of the Definition \ref{comp_pt_qo*_defn}.
\begin{enumerate}
	\item[(a)] The action $G\left(\left. \widetilde M\right| M\right)\times \widetilde M\to \widetilde M$ naturally induces the action $G\left(\left. \widetilde M\right| M\right)\times \left( \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)\to \left( \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)$.
	\item[(b)] The existence of injective *-homomorphism 
	$$
	\varphi: \bigcup_{\La \in \la} \left( \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)', \Coo\left( {M}_\la\right)\right)\hookto \left( \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right) 
	$$ 
	follows from the natural inclusions $ \left( \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)', \Coo\left( {M}_\la\right)\right)\hookto \left( \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)$ for all $\la\in\La$.
	\item[(c)]  The specific version of equations \eqref{inv_qo*_rzero_eqn} -\eqref{inv_qo*_rlim_eqn} !!! REPLACE is presented below

		\bea
	\label{top_inv_qo*_rzerop_eqn}
	\forall\widetilde a\in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)'\quad \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \widetilde{a}= \{0\}\quad \Rightarrow\quad \widetilde{a}= 0,~\quad\quad \\
	\label{top_inv_qo*_lzerop_eqn}
	\forall\widetilde a\in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)'\quad \widetilde{a}\Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) = \{0\}\quad \Rightarrow\quad \widetilde{a}= 0,~ \quad\quad\\
	\label{top_inv_qo*_llimp_eqn}	\mathrm{span}\left\{ \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'\right\} =\mathrm{span}\left\{  \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \right\},~\quad\quad \\	
	\label{top_inv_qo*_rlimp_eqn}\mathrm{span}\left\{ 	\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \right\} =\mathrm{span}\left\{ \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \right\}~\quad\quad 
	\eea
	so one needs check equations
 \eqref{top_inv_qo*_rzerop_eqn} -\eqref{top_inv_qo*_rlimp_eqn}.
Suppose that $\widetilde a\in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)'$ is such that $\Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right) \widetilde{a}= \{0\}$. For all  $\widetilde b\in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)$, there is $ \widetilde{c} \in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)_+$ such that $\widetilde{c}\left( \supp \widetilde{b}\right) = \{1\}$. It follows that 
$$
\left\langle \widetilde a, \widetilde b \right\rangle = \left\langle \widetilde a, \widetilde{c}\widetilde b \right\rangle = \left\langle \widetilde a \widetilde{c},\widetilde b \right\rangle,
$$
so if $\widetilde a \widetilde{c}=0$ then $\left\langle \widetilde a, \widetilde b \right\rangle= 0$. Thus the equation \eqref{top_inv_qo*_rzerop_eqn} is proven. The equation \eqref{top_inv_qo*_lzerop_eqn}  is equivalent to \eqref{top_inv_qo*_rzerop_eqn}.  From $\bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\subset \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'$ it follows that 
\be\label{top_cc_l_inc_eqn}
\mathrm{span}\left\{  \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \right\}\subset \mathrm{span}\left\{ \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'\right\} 
\ee
If  $\widetilde a \in \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)$ and $\widetilde b \in \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'$, then there is $ \widetilde{c} \in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)_+$ such that $\widetilde{c}\left( \supp \widetilde{a}\right) = \{1\}$. It follows that $\widetilde{c}\widetilde{a}\widetilde{b}= \widetilde{a}\widetilde{b}$. From the Lemma \ref{top_comp_la_lem} it follows that there is $\la\in\La$ such that $\supp \widetilde{c}$ is homeomorphically mapped onto  $\widetilde p_\la\left(\supp \widetilde{c} \right) $, where  $\widetilde p_\la: \widetilde M\to M_\la$ is the natural covering. It turns out that there is the descent of 
$\desc_{\widetilde p_\la}\left(\widetilde{c}\widetilde{a} \right) \in  \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'$ such that 
$$
\widetilde{b}\desc_{\widetilde p_\la}\left(\widetilde{c}\widetilde{a} \right) =\widetilde{b}\widetilde{c}\widetilde{a}.
$$
It follows that 
\be\label{top_cc_r_inc_eqn}
\mathrm{span}\left\{ \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'\right\} \subset\mathrm{span}\left\{  \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \right\}
\ee	
The equation \eqref{top_inv_qo*_llimp_eqn} follows from \eqref{top_cc_l_inc_eqn} and \eqref{top_cc_r_inc_eqn}. The equation \eqref{top_inv_qo*_rlimp_eqn} is equivalent to the equation \eqref{top_inv_qo*_llimp_eqn}.
\end{enumerate}

\end{proof}

\subsection{Infinite coverings and unbounded operators on Hilbert modules}
\paragraph{}
Here we consider two  specializations of described in the Section \ref{unb_hilb_sec} theory.

\subsubsection{Algebras of unbounded functions}

\paragraph{}
Let $\left( \sX, x_0\right) $ be a pointed connected, locally connected, locally compact, Hausdorff space. Let $B \bydef  C_0\left(\sX \right)$, and let $A\bydef Cont\left(\sX \right) $ be a *-algebra of continuous (possibly unbounded)  maps from $\sX$ to $\C$. From the Lemma \ref{top_base_point_lem} one has a {pointed algebraical  finite covering category} (cf. Definition \ref{pointed_defn}), given by
\be\nonumber
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{B} \bydef \left(\left\{\rho_\la: B \hookto B_\la \right\}_{\la \in \La}, \left\{\rho^\mu_\nu: B_\mu \hookto B_\nu\right\}_{\substack{\mu, \nu \in \La\\ \nu > \mu}}\right)\bydef \\ \left(\left\{C_0\left( p_\la\right) : C_0\left(\sX \right)  \hookto C_0\left(\sX_\la \right)\right\}, \left\{C_0\left( p_\nu^\mu\right) : C_0\left(\sX_\nu \right) \hookto C_0\left(\sX_\mu \right)\right\}\right).
\end{split}
\ee
From the Theorem \ref{top_main_thm} it follows that $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_B$ is good  (cf. Definition \ref{good_defn} !!! ABC to AB GOOD EXER ADD !!!). Moreover and there is a space $\widetilde \sX$  and a transitive covering $\widetilde p: \widetilde \sX\to  \sX$ such that a triple 
$\left(C_0\left(\sX\right), C_0\left(\widetilde \sX\right),G\left(\left.\widetilde \sX~\right| \mathcal X\right)\right)
$ is  an  { infinite noncommutative covering} of $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right)}$ (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}). This triple we also denote by $\left(B, \widetilde B,G\left(\left.\widetilde B~\right| B\right)\right)
$.  For all $\la\in \La$ denote by $A_\la\bydef Cont\left(\sX_\la \right) $ a *-algebra of continuous (possibly unbounded) maps from $\sX_\la$ to $\C$.  From the Theorem \ref{top_fin_hilb_thm} it turns out that	
\bean
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_A \bydef \left(\left\{\pi_\la: A \hookto A_\la \right\}_{\la \in \La}, \left\{\pi^\mu_\nu: A_\mu \hookto A_\nu\right\}_{\substack{\mu, \nu \in \La\\ \nu > \mu}}\right)
\end{split}
\eean
is a pointed category of $*$-algebras such that for any $\la, \mu, \nu\in \La$ the triples\\ $\left(A, A_\la, G\left(\left. A_\la\right| A\right)\bydef G\left(\left. B_\la\right| B\right), \pi_\la \right)$ and $\left(A_\mu, A_\nu, G\left(\left. A_\mu\right| A_\nu\right)\bydef G\left(\left. B_\mu\right| B_\nu\right), \pi^\mu_\nu \right)$ are associated with $\left(B, B_\la, G\left(\left. B_\la\right| B\right), \rho_\la \right)$ and $\left(B_\mu, B_\nu,G\left(\left. B_\mu\right| B_\nu\right), \rho^\mu_\nu \right)$ noncommutative finite-fold covering of *-algebras (cf. Definition \ref{fin_chull_defn} !!! CHECK (a) (b)).  The  Pedersen's ideal $\widetilde{\mathfrak B}\bydef K\left( \widetilde B\right)= C_c\left(\widetilde \sX \right) $ (cf. Definition \ref{peder_id_defn} and equation \eqref{peder_c0_eqn}) is dense in ${\widetilde B}$.

 \begin{exercise}\label{top_hilb_adm_exer}
	Prove following statements:
	\begin{itemize}
		\item The right  $\widetilde B$-module $ \widetilde{\mathfrak B}'$ satisfies to all conditions described in \ref{comp_chull_empt}.
		\item If $\widetilde A\bydef Cont\left(\widetilde\sX\right)$ is a commutative *-algebra of (possibly unbounded) $\C$-valued continuous maps from  $\widetilde{ {\sX}}$ to $\C$ then $\widetilde A$ is $G\left(\left.\widetilde B\right| B\right)$-equivariant. Moreover there is the natural inclusion $\widetilde A \subset \End^*_{\widetilde { B}}\left(\widetilde {\mathfrak B}'\right)$
 		which satisfies to the equation \eqref{hilb_adm_cup_eqn} and \eqref{hilb_adm_eqn}, i.e. $\widetilde A$ is admissible.
	\end{itemize}
\end{exercise}
\begin{lemma}
	In the described above situation 
	the triple $\left(A, \widetilde{A}, G\left(\left.\widetilde A \right| A\right)\cong G\left(\left.\widetilde B \right| B\right)\right)$ is a {unique infinite noncommutative covering of $\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_A$ associated with $\mathfrak{S}_B^{\mathrm{pt}}$} (cf. Definition \ref{main_ch_defn} MAXI !!!).
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	From the Exercise \ref{top_hilb_adm_exer} it follows that $\widetilde A$ is admissible. So one should proof that any admissible algebra $\widetilde A'$ is a subalgebra of $\widetilde A$
If $\widetilde \sU \subset  \widetilde \sX$ is an open subset then there is an equivalence relation $\sim_{\widetilde\sU}$ on $\widetilde A'$ given by
	 $$
	 \forall \widetilde a', \widetilde a'' \in \widetilde A' \quad  \widetilde a'\sim_{\widetilde\sU} \widetilde a'' \quad\Leftrightarrow\left( \quad \forall \widetilde b\in C_c\left(\widetilde \sX \right) \quad \supp \widetilde b \subset  \widetilde\sU\quad \Rightarrow \quad\widetilde a'\widetilde b = \widetilde a''\widetilde b\right). 
	 $$
	 One can proof than the map
$\widetilde \sU \mapsto \widetilde A'/\sim_{\widetilde\sU}$ satisfies to the Definition  \ref{presheaf_defn}, i.e. one has a presheaf.  Let $\widetilde{\mathscr A}'$ be an associated sheaf (cf. \ref{sheaf_prdf}). If $\widetilde x_0\subset \widetilde \sX$ that any stalk 
(cf. Definition \ref{stalk_defn}) of $\widetilde{\mathscr A}'$ at  $\widetilde x_0$ can be represented  by a pair $\left( \widetilde \sU, \widetilde a_{\widetilde \sU}\right) $ 
where  $\widetilde \sU$ is an open neighborhood of $\widetilde x_0$ and $a_{\widetilde \sU} \in \widetilde A'/\sim_{\widetilde\sU}$. Moreover from the Definition \ref{stalk_defn} one can assume that the closure $\widetilde \sY$ of $\widetilde \sU$ is compact. Let $\widetilde f\in  C_c\left( \widetilde \sX\right)$ be a covering sum for $ \widetilde \sY$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_covering_sum_defn}).
If $\widetilde a_{\widetilde \sU}$ is represented by $\widetilde a$ then from 
$\widetilde f \left(\widetilde \sU \right)=\{1\}$ it follows that  $\widetilde a_{\widetilde \sU}$ can be also represented by $\widetilde a\widetilde f$. From the equation \eqref{hilb_adm_eqn} it follows that there is $a^\cup \in \cup~ A_\la = \cup~Cont\left(\sX_\la \right)$ such that $\widetilde a\widetilde f=  a^\cup\widetilde f$. However $ a^\cup\widetilde f\in C_c\left(\widetilde \sX \right)$. It follows that any stalk at $\widetilde x_0$ corresponds to a stalk of the given by \eqref{top_cont_sheaf} 
sheaf of $\mathscr C \left(\widetilde{\sX}, \left\{\C_{\widetilde{x}}\right\}, C_0\left(\widetilde\sX\right) \right)
$ continuous functions. On the other hand from \eqref{hilb_adm_cup_eqn} if follows that any stalk of $\mathscr C \left(\widetilde{\sX}, \left\{\C_{\widetilde{x}}\right\}, C_0\left(\widetilde\sX\right) \right)
$ can be represented by the stalk of $\widetilde{\mathscr A}'$. It follows that
$$
\widetilde{\mathscr A}' = \mathscr C \left(\widetilde{\sX}, \left\{\C_{\widetilde{x}}\right\}, C_0\left(\widetilde\sX\right) \right).
$$
On the other hand any $\widetilde a' \in \widetilde A'$ corresponds to a global sections of $\widetilde{\mathscr A}'$, i.e. there is an inclusion
$$
\widetilde A'\subset\widetilde{\mathscr A}'\left(\widetilde\sX\right) = \mathscr C \left(\widetilde{\sX}, \left\{\C_{\widetilde{x}}\right\}, C_0\left(\widetilde\sX\right) \right) \left(\widetilde\sX\right) = Cont\left(\widetilde\sX\right) \bydef \widetilde A.
$$
The above equation means that $\widetilde A$ is the unique maximal admissible *-algebra.
	
\end{proof}

\subsubsection{Polynomials in one variable}

\paragraph{}

Suppose
\bean%\label{top_hull_top_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \sX, x_0\right) }\bydef\\
	\bydef \left\{\left\{p_\la:\left( \sX_\la, x^\la_0\right) \to \left( \sX, x_0\right)\right\}_{\la\in\La}, \left\{p^\mu_{ \nu}:\left( \sX_\mu, x^\mu_0\right) \to \left( \sX_\nu, x^\nu_0\right)\right\}_{\substack{\mu,\nu\in\La\\
			\mu\ge\nu}} \right\}
\end{split}
\eean
is  a pointed topological finite covering category (cf. Definition \ref{top_sec_p_defn}). If $\left( \sY, y_0\right) \bydef \left(  \sX \times \R, \left(x_0, \{0\} \right)\right) $, $~ \left( \sY_\la, y^\la_0\right) \bydef \left(  \sX_\la \times \R, \left(x^\la_0, \{0\} \right)\right) $ then there  is  a pointed topological finite covering category

\subsection{Strong Morita equivalence of infinite coverings}
	\paragraph*{} Here we consider a specialization of the explained in the Section \ref{inf_mor_sec} theory.
\begin{lemma}\label{comm_allows_lem}
	If $\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \mathcal X, x_0\right) } = \left\{\left( \mathcal{X}_\la,x_0^\la\right)  \to \left( \mathcal X, x_0\right) \right\}_{\la \in \La} \in \mathfrak{FinTop}^{\mathrm{pt}}$, \\
	$\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right) }\left( \mathcal X, x_0\right) =
	\left( \left\{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}\right) \hookto  C_0\left( \mathcal{X}_\la\right) \right\}, \left\{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}_\mu\right) \hookto  C_0\left( \mathcal{X}_\nu\right) \right\} \right) $ then $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right) }$ allows inner product (cf. Definition \ref{inf_hilb_prod_defn}). 
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	%	Denote by $G_\la = G\left(\mathcal X_\la~|~\mathcal X \right)$ groups of covering transformations and $\widehat{G} = \varprojlim G_\la$. 
	Denote by $\overline{p}:\left( \overline{  \mathcal X}, \overline x_0\right)  \to\left(  \mathcal X, x_0\right) $, $\overline{p}_\la:\left( \overline{  \mathcal X}, \overline x_0\right)  \to\left(  \mathcal X_\la, x^\la_0\right) $, $p^\la: \left(  \mathcal X_\la, x^\la_0\right)  \to \left( \mathcal X, x_0\right) $, $p^\mu_\nu:  \left( \mathcal X_\mu, x^\mu_0 \right) \to \left( \mathcal X_\nu, x^\nu_0\right) $ ($\mu > \nu$) the natural pointed coverings.
	If $\widetilde{\sX}= \varprojlim \mathfrak{S}_{\left(\sX, x_0 \right)}$ then  	from the Theorem \ref{top_main_thm} it turns out	
	$$\left(C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right), C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX}\right),G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right)\right)$$ is  the { infinite noncommutative covering} of $\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right)}$ (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}). 	 	It is shown in \cite{pedersen:mea_c} that the Pedersen's ideal $K\left(C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)\right) $ of $C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$ coincides with $C_c\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$. If $\widetilde{a}, \widetilde{b} \in C_c\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$ then $\supp \overline{a}$ is compact. 	
	From the Lemma \ref{top_comp_la_lem} it follows that there is $\la_0 \in \La$ such that for all $\la \ge \la_0$ the restriction $\left.\overline{p}_\la\right|_{\supp \overline{a}}$ is injective. From 1. of the Exercise  \ref{comm_lift_desc_sum_exer} it follows that
	\begin{equation}\nonumber
		\begin{split}
			c_{\la} = \sum_{g \in \ker\left(G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX \right)  \to  G\left( \sX_{\la}~|~\sX \right)\right)} g \left(\widetilde{a}^* \widetilde{b}  \right) = \desc_{\overline{p}_\la}\left( \widetilde{a}\widetilde{b}\right) 
		\end{split}
	\end{equation}
	where sum of the series implies the strict topology of $M\left(C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)  \right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{strict_topology}), and the  notation  $\desc_{\overline{p}_\la}$ means  the descent	(cf. Definition \ref{top_lift_desc_defn}). 
	From the properties of the descent it turns out that $\desc_{\overline{p}_\la}\left( \widetilde{a}\widetilde{b}\right) \in C_0\left( \sX_{\la}\right)$, i.e. $c_\la \in C_0\left( \sX_{\la}\right)$.  Taking into account the Remark \ref{inf_hilb_prod_low_rem} we conclude that  $c_\la \in C_0\left( \sX_{\la}\right)$ for all $\la \in \La$.
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
	The Lemma \ref{comm_allows_lem} yields a specialization 
	 $X =X_{C_0\left({\sX}\right)}=$\\$= _{C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX}\right)}X_{C_0\left({\sX}\right)}$ of the given  by \eqref{inf_hilb_inc_eqn} $C^*$-Hilbert $C_0\left({\sX}\right)$-module which is relevant to the   
	{ infinite noncommutative covering} 	$$\left(C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right), C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX}\right),G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right)\right)$$ of $\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right)}$  (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}). 
\end{rem}
\begin{lemma}\label{top_all_lem}
	The Hilbert ${C_0\left({\sX}\right)}$-module $X_{C_0\left({\sX}\right)}$ satisfies to the 
conditions (a),(b)  of the Section \ref{inf_mor_sec}.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
(a) Let $\left(\widetilde{a}, g\right) \in C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right)\times G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right)$ and let $h_{\widetilde{a}, g}\in \End^*_{C_0\left(\sX \right) }\left(X \right)$ is given by \eqref{hm_inc_eqn} i.e. 
\be\label{topo_hm_inc_eqn}
\begin{split}
	h_{\widetilde{a}, g}\left(\xi \right) 
	 = g\left(\xi \widetilde{a} \right) \quad \forall \xi\in X
\end{split}
\ee
For any $\eps > 0$ the set
$$
\widetilde\sY\bydef \left\{ \widetilde x\in \widetilde\sX \left|\left| \widetilde a\left(\widetilde x\right) \right|\ge \frac{\eps}{2} \right.\right\}
$$
If  $ \widetilde p: \widetilde\sX \to \sX$ is the natural covering and  $\sum_{j = 1}^n f_j$  is a covering sum for $\widetilde\sY$ {subordinated to} $\widetilde p$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_covering_sum_domi_defn}). then one has
$$
\left\|  \widetilde a -  \widetilde a\sum_{j = 1}^n f_j\right\| < \eps.
$$
From the above equation it turns out that
\be\label{top_hg_e_eqn}
\left\|  	h_{\widetilde{a}, g}-\sum_{j = 1}^n h_{f_j \widetilde a, g}\right\| < \eps.
\ee
On the other hang $h_{f_j \widetilde a, g}=\theta_{\sqrt{f_j}, g\left( \sqrt{f_j}\widetilde{a}\right)  } = \sqrt{f_j}\left\rangle \right\langle g\left( \sqrt{f_j}\widetilde{a}\right)$ is a rank-one operator (cf. equation \eqref{rank_one_eqn}). 
The number $\eps$ is arbitrary small, so from the equation  \eqref{top_hg_e_eqn} and the Definition \ref{comp_aop_defn} one concludes that 	$h_{\widetilde{a}, g}$ is compact, i.e. 
$h_{\widetilde{a}, g}\in \K\left(X_{C_0\left( \sX\right) } \right)$. Since $C_c\left(G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right), C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right) \right)$ is generated  by operators $h_{\widetilde{a}, g}$ one has $C_c\left(G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right), C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right) \right) \subset \K\left(X_{C_0\left( \sX\right) } \right)$.\\
(b) If $\widetilde a, \widetilde b \in K\left(C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right)  \right) = C_c\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right)$ then both sets $\supp\widetilde a$ and  $\supp\widetilde b$ are compact. Let  $ \widetilde p: \widetilde\sX \to \sX$ be the natural covering and  $\sum_{j = 1}^n f_j$  is a covering sum for $\supp \widetilde a$ {subordinated to} $\widetilde p$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_covering_sum_domi_defn}).
If $j \in \left\{1,..., n\right\}$ and the set
$$
G_j \bydef \left\{\left. g G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right)\in \right| g\supp f_j \cap \supp \widetilde b\neq \emptyset \right\}
$$
is not finite then the compact set $\supp \widetilde b$ contains an infinite disjoint union
$$
\bigsqcup_{g \in G_j} g\supp f_j \cap \supp \widetilde b
$$
of compact subsets. It is impossible, so $G_j$ is  finite for all  $j=1,..., n$.
If $\ka_j \bydef f_j \widetilde a \left\rangle \right\langle \widetilde b\in  \K\left(X_{C_0\left( \sX\right) } \right)$ is a rank-one operator (cf. equation \eqref{rank_one_eqn}) then $a \left\rangle \right\langle b = \sum_{j=1}^n \ka_j$. For any $\widetilde c \in \K\left(X_{C_0\left( {\sX}\right)}  \right)$ one has
$$
\ka_j \widetilde c = \sum_{g \in G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right)} g\left(  \widetilde c f_j\widetilde a^*\right) \widetilde b=  \sum_{g \in G_j} g\left(  \widetilde cf_j\widetilde a^*\right) \widetilde b
$$
On the other hand from
$$
g_j\left(  \widetilde cf_j\widetilde a^*\right) \widetilde b = h_{f_j\widetilde a^*g_j^{-1}\widetilde b, g_j}\left(\widetilde c \right) 
$$
it follows that
$$
\ka_j = \sum_{g \in G_j}h_{f_j\widetilde a^*g_j^{-1}\widetilde b, g_j}\in C_c\left(G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right), C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right) \right)
$$
and taking into account $\widetilde a \left\rangle \right\langle \widetilde b = \sum_{j=1}^n \ka_j$ one has $\widetilde a \left\rangle \right\langle \widetilde b\in  C_c\left(G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right), C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right) \right)$. The $\C$-space  $K\left(C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right)  \right)$  is dense in $X_{C_0\left( {\sX}\right)}$, so for any $\xi, \eta \in X_{C_0\left( {\sX}\right)}$ and $\eps > 0$ there are $\widetilde a, \widetilde b \in K\left(C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right)  \right)$ such that
$$
\left\|  \widetilde a \left\rangle \right\langle \widetilde b-\xi \left\rangle \right\langle \eta\right\|< \eps.
$$
Taking into account $\widetilde a \left\rangle \right\langle \widetilde b\in  C_c\left(G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right), C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right) \right)$ one concludes that the rank-one operator $\xi \left\rangle \right\langle \eta$ lies in the $C^*$-norm completion of $C_c\left(G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right), C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right) \right)$.
On the other hand from the Definition \ref{comp_aop_defn} it follows that $\K\left(X_{C_0\left( \sX\right) } \right)$ is the $C^*$-norm completion of the algebraical linear span of rank-one operators, so\\ $C_c\left(G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right), C_0\left( \widetilde{\sX}\right) \right)$ is dense in $\K\left(X_{C_0\left( \sX\right) } \right)$.
\end{proof}
\begin{exercise}\label{top_all_exer}
Prove that the linear span of  $\left\langle X, X \right\rangle_{C_0\left( \sX\right)}$  is dense in $C_0\left( \sX\right)$, i.e.
$$\left(C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right), C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX}\right),G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right)\right)$$ allows strong Morita equivalence  (cf. Definition \ref{allows_morita_defn}).  
\end{exercise}
\begin{remark}
The Exercise \ref{top_all_exer} corresponds to the Proposition \ref{top_allows_morita_prop} (cf. Remark \ref{top_allows_morita_rem}).
\end{remark}

\subsection{Induced representations}\label{comm_induced_infinite_sec}

\paragraph*{} 
Similarly to the section \ref{comm_induced_finite_sec} consider a compact  Riemannian manifold $M$ with a  spinor bundle $S$ (cf. \ref{comm_sp_tr_sec}). 
Let $\tau:C\left( M\right) \to \C$ be a faithful state such that 
$$
\tau\left(a \right) = \int_{M} a~ d\mu.
$$
Similarly to the Section \ref{comm_induced_finite_sec} there is a Hilbert space $ L^2\left(  M, S\right)\cong  L^2\left(  M, S, \mu\right)$ and   the natural representation
\be\label{comm_m_bundle_inf_repr_eqn}
\rho: C\left(M\right) \to B\left( L^2\left(  M, S\right)\right). 
\ee
Let $p: \widetilde M \to M$ be an infinite transitive covering, such that the group $G\left(\left.\widetilde M   ~\right| M\right)$ is residually finite. From the Lemma \ref{top_res_fin_lem} and the  Theorem \ref{top_main_thm} it turns out that the triple  $\left(C\left( M\right) , C_0\left( \widetilde M\right) G\left(\left.\widetilde M   ~\right| M\right)\right)$ is an infinite noncommutative covering (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}). Similarly to \eqref{top_ot_eqn} one can construct a functional
\bean
\widetilde\tau: C_c\left(\widetilde M \right) \to \C. 
\eean 
Define the $\C$-valued product
\be
\begin{split}
	\left( \cdot, \cdot \right): \Ga_c\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S\right)\times \Ga_c\left( \widetilde M, \widetilde S\right) \to \C,\\
	\left(\widetilde\xi,\widetilde \eta \right) \mapsto \widetilde \tau\left( \left\langle\widetilde\xi, \widetilde\eta \right\rangle_c \right) 
\end{split}
\ee
where the pairing $	\left\langle \cdot, \cdot \right\rangle_c:  \Ga_c\left(\widetilde M,\widetilde S\right)\times \Ga_c\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S\right)\to C_c\left(\widetilde M \right) $ is given by \eqref{top_ggc_eqn}.
This product yields the structure of pre-Hilbert space on $\Ga_c\left(\widetilde M,\widetilde S\right)$. Denote by $ L^2\left(\widetilde  M,\widetilde S\right)\cong  L^2\left( \widetilde M, \widetilde S, \widetilde \mu\right)$ the Hilbert norm completion of $\Ga_c\left(\widetilde M,\widetilde S\right)$. The natural action $C_0\left(\widetilde M\right) \times \Ga_c\left(\widetilde M,\widetilde S\right)\to \Ga_c\left(\widetilde M,  \widetilde S\right)$ induces  the natural representation
\be\label{comm_bundlei_repr_eqn}
C_0\left(\widetilde M\right) \to B\left( L^2\left(\widetilde  M, \widetilde S\right)\right). 
\ee 




From the Lemma \ref{comm_allows_lem} it follows that the  induced by $\left(\rho, \left(C\left( M\right) , C_0\left( \widetilde M\right) G\left(\left.\widetilde M   ~\right| M\right)\right)\right)$ representation $\widetilde \rho: C_0\left( \widetilde M\right)\hookto B\left( \widetilde \H\right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{induced_repr_inf_defn}), such that $\widetilde \H$ is the Hilbert norm completion of
$$
K\left( C_0\left( \widetilde M\right)\right)\otimes_{C\left( {M}\right)} L^2\left(  M, S\right)
$$
where $K\left( C_0\left( \widetilde M\right)\right)$ is Pedersen's ideal of $C_0\left( \widetilde M\right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{peder_id_defn} and Remark \ref{ap_act_hilb_rem}). On the other hand 	it is proven in \cite{pedersen:mea_c} that the Pedersen's ideal $K\left(C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)\right) $ of $C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$ coincides with $C_c\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$.  If
$$
\Ga_c\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)\bydef C_c\left( \lift_p\left[C\left(M, \left\{S_x\right\}, \Ga\left(M, S\right)\right)\right]\right)  
$$
then from the Lemma \ref{top_tensor_lcompact_lem} it follows that there is the given by \eqref{top_tensor_lccompact_iso_eqn} isomorphism
$$
C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)}\Ga\left(M,S \right) \xrightarrow{\approx}\Ga_c\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)
$$
of left $C_0\left(\widetilde M \right)$-modules. On the other hand 
then from \ref{top_herm_bundle_empt} it follows that there is the dense with respect to the Hilbert norm inclusion $\Ga_c\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)\subset L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)$, hence there is  the homomorphism
\be\label{top_lift_g_inf_eqn}
\phi: C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)}\Ga\left(M,S \right) \to L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)
\ee
of left $C_0\left(\widetilde M \right)$-modules.
\begin{lemma}\label{top_hilb_inf_lem}
	Following conditions hold:
	\begin{itemize}
		\item [(i)] The map \eqref{top_lift_g_inf_eqn} can be extended up to the following homomorphism 
		$$
		C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)} L^2\left(M, \sS\right) \xrightarrow{\approx} L^2\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)
		$$
		of left $C_0\left(\widetilde M\right)$-modules.
		\item[(ii)] The image of $C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)} L^2\left(M, \sS\right)$ is dense in $L^2\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)$.
	\end{itemize}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}(i)
	Let $\sum_{j = 1}^n \widetilde a_j \otimes \xi_j\in 	C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)} L^2\left(M, \sS\right)$ be any element. From \ref{top_herm_bundle_empt}  it turns out that $L^2\left( M, S, \mu\right)$ is the Hilbert norm completion of $\Ga\left(M, \sS\right)$. Hence for any $j =1,..., n$ there is a net $\left\{\xi_{j\a}\right\}\subset \Ga\left(M, \sS\right)$ such that $\xi_j = \lim_\a \xi_{j\a}$ where we mean the convergence with respect to the Hilbert norm $\left\| \cdot\right\|_{L^2\left(M, \sS\right)}$. If $C = \max_{j = 1,...,n}\left\|\widetilde a_j\right\|$ then there is $\a_0$ such that
	$$
	\a \ge \a_0 \quad \Rightarrow \left\| \xi_j - \xi_{j\a}\right\|_{L^2\left(M, \sS\right)} < \frac{\eps}{nC},
	$$
	so one has
	$$
	\a \ge \a_0 \quad \Rightarrow \left\| \sum_{j = 1}^n \widetilde a_j \otimes \xi_{j\a_0} - \sum_{j = 1}^n \widetilde a_j \otimes \xi_{j\a}\right\|_{L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde\sS\right)} < \eps.
	$$
	The above equation it follows that the net $\left\{\sum_{j = 1}^n \widetilde a_j \otimes \xi_{j\a}\right\}_\a$ satisfies to the Cauchy condition, so it is convergent with respect to the topology of $L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde\sS\right)$.\\
	(ii) From the Lemma \eqref{top_tensor_lcompact_lem} it follows that the image of $C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)} L^2\left(M, \sS\right)$ in $L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde\sS\right)$ contains $\Ga_c\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)$, however $\Ga_c\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)$ is dense in $L^2\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)$. It follows that  $\phi\left(  C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)} L^2\left(M, \sS\right)\right)$ is dense in $L^2\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)$. 
\end{proof}

From the Proposition \ref{comm_cov_mani_prop} it follows that $\widetilde{M}$ and $M_\la$ ($\forall \la \in \La$)  have natural structure of the Riemannian manifolds. of spectral triples. Let $\overline M$ be the disconnected inverse limit of the given by \eqref{top_topological_inv_lim_defn} a (topological)  finite covering category

\chapter{Hausdorff blowing-up and coverings}\label{blowing_chap}
\paragraph*{}
If the spectrum of  $C^*$-algebra $A$ is Hausdorff then $A$ possesses  a family of good properties. For example noncommutative coverings of $C^*$-algebras with Hausdorff spectra correspond to coverings of their spectra (cf. Chapters \ref{top_chap} and \ref{ctr_chap}). Sometimes the spectrum of $C^*$-algebra can by replaced by its Hausdorff blowing-up and some results concerning $C^*$-algebras with  Hausdorff spectrum can be applied to $C^*$-algebras with Hausdorff blowing-up. We prove that noncommutative coverings of $C^*$-algebras correspond to coverings of Hausdorff blowing-up. The results of this chapter are used in both $C^*$-algebras with continuous trace (Hausdorff spectrum) and algebras of foliations   (non - Hausdorff spectrum). 
The "blowing-up" word is inspired by following reasons:
\begin{itemize}
	\item There is  the natural partially defined multi-valued surjective  map from the Hausdorff blowing-up to the spectrum (cf. \ref{blowing_empt}).
	\item  In the algebraic geometry   "blowing-up" means  excluding of singular points  (cf. \cite{hartshorne:ag}).
\end{itemize}

\section{Basic definitions}

\paragraph*{}
Before the  definition of blowing we consider an illustrative example.
For all $\th\in \R_+$ there  is the natural action of group  $G\bydef \Z\th/ \Z$ on the circle
$\sX\bydef S^1\cong \R/\Z$. If $\th$ is rational then the space $\sX/G$ is Hausdorff otherwise it is not Hausdorff. How can we obtain $\sX/G$ algebraically? The Table \ref{hnh_alg_table} shows different methods of obtaining of the spectra.
\newline
\begin {table}[H]
\caption {Comparison of an invariant algebra and a crossed product} \label{hnh_alg_table}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
	\hline
	&$\sX/G$ is Hausdorff & $\sX/G$ is not Hausdorff\\
	\hline
	&&\\
	$C\left( \sX\right)^G$ 	& $C\left( \sX/G\right)$	&$\C$\\
	& & \\
	%	&&\\
	Spectrum of $C\left( \sX\right)^G$ 	& $ \sX/G$	& A point\\
	& & \\
	\hline
	&&\\
	$C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G$ 	& $C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G\neq\C$	&$C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G\neq\C$\\
	& & \\
	%&&\\
	Spectrum of $C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G$ 	& $ \sX/G$	& $\sX/G$\\
	& & \\
	
	\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}
Thus the $C\left( \sX\right)^G$ invariant $C^*$-algebra does not always yield $\sX/G$ as a spectrum but the crossed product $C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G$ does. 
Moreover since $C\left( \sX/G\right)$ can be trivial it does not know the map $\sX \to \sX/G$  but $C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G$ knows it, because there  is an inclusion
$C\left(\sX \right) \subset C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G$. If $\sX/G$ is Hausdorff then sometimes a covering of $\sX/G$ can by find by following way:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Find a covering $\widetilde\sX \to\sX$ with an action $G\times \widetilde\sX \to \widetilde\sX$,
\item Then there is the covering $\widetilde\sX / G \to \sX/G$.
\end{enumerate}
However if $\sX/G$ is not Hausdorff this construction does not work. 
However there is an algebraic version of it given by:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Find a covering $\widetilde\sX \to\sX$ with an action $G\times \widetilde\sX \to \widetilde\sX$, and invective *-homomorphism $C\left( \sX\right)\hookto  C\left( \widetilde\sX\right)$,
\item Then there a noncommutative covering  $C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G\hookto C\left( \widetilde\sX\right)\rtimes G $.
\end{enumerate}
The algebraic construction can be applied if $\sX/G$ is not Hausdorff.  The map $\sX \to \sX/G$ is yields a specialization of discussed below Hausdorff blowing up. 



%\paragraph*{}


\begin{definition}\label{blowing_defn}
Any  commutative $C^*$-subalgebra $C\cong C_0\left( \sY\right) \subset M\left(A \right)$ is said to be  a \textit{Hausdorff blowing-up} of $A$  if for any irreducible representation $\rep_x: A \to B\left( \H\right)$ the space $\rep_x\left( C\right) \H$ is dense in $\H$. 
\end{definition}


\begin{empt}\label{blowing_empt}
If $\sX$ is the spectrum of $A$ then	for any $y\in \sY$ there is 
the set
$$
\sX_y \bydef \left\{\left. x\in\sX\right| \rep_x\left(C_0\left( \sY\right)\right)\neq \rep_x\left( I_y\right)   \right\}
$$
where $I_y = \left\{\left. a\in C_0\left( \sY\right) \right| a\left( y\right)= 0  \right\}$.
The map $y \mapsto \sX_y$ yields a partially defined multi-valued map from $\sY\to\sX$.
The map is surjective because for any $x \in \sX$ and for any maximal ideal $J_x \subset \rep_x\left(C_0\left( \sY\right)\right) $ there is a maximal ideal $I_y\subset C_0\left( \sY\right)$ such that $J_x= \rep_x\left(I_y\right)$.
\end{empt}
\begin{definition}\label{blowing_spectal_defn}
A {Hausdorff blowing-up}	$C\cong C_0\left( \sY\right) \subset M\left(A \right)$ is said to be   \textit{spectral} if the described in  \ref{blowing_empt} map is single-valued. It means that one has a subset $s\left( \sY\right)\subset \sY$ with the following equation 
\be\label{blowing_spectal_eqn}
\sY\supset s\left( \sY\right)\xrightarrow{s_\sY} \sX
\ee
where a map $s_\sY$ is surjective.
\end{definition}

\begin{empt}
Let  $C\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left( A\right) $ be a blowing-up of $A$. If for any open subset $\sU \subset \sY$ we put
\be\label{blowig_su_eqn}
A_\sU \bydef C^*\text{-norm completion of } C_0\left(\sU \right) A  C_0\left(\sU \right)
\ee
then one has
\be\label{blowig_sue_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\sU'\cap \sU'' =\emptyset\Rightarrow\left(  C_0\left(\sU' \right) A  C_0\left(\sU' \right)\right)\left(  C_0\left(\sU'' \right)
	A  C_0\left(\sU'' \right)\right) = \{0\} \Rightarrow \\ A_{\sU'}A_{\sU''}= \{0\}.
\end{split}
\ee
\end{empt}

\begin{definition}\label{blowing_good_defn}
A Hausdorff blowing-up	$C\cong C_0\left( \sY\right) \subset M\left(A \right)$ is said to be \textit{good} if for any family of open sets $\left\{\sU_\a\subset \sX\right\}$ such that $\sX = \cup \ \sU_\a$ a union $\cup A_{\sU_\a}$ generates $C^*$-algebra $A$.
\end{definition}
\begin{remark}\label{blowing_good_rem}
Let both $\left\{\sU_\a\subset \sX\right\}$  and $\left\{\sU_\bt\subset \sX\right\}$ be families  of open sets such that  $\sX = \cup~\sU_\bt$ and for any $\bt$ there is $\a$ such that $\sU_\bt \subset \sU_\a$. If a union $\cup A_{\sU_\bt}$ generates $C^*$-algebra $A$ then  $\cup A_{\sU_\a}$ also generates  $A$. 
\end{remark}
\begin{empt}\label{blowing_strict_empt}
Suppose that $\left\{u_\la\right\}_{\la\in\La}$ is an approximate unit of $C_0\left( \sU\right)$ and let $a \in A_\sU$. For all $a \in A_\sU$  there is $a' \in A$ and $f",f'' \in C_0\left( \sU\right) $ such that $\left\|a - f'a'f'' \right\|\le \frac{\eps}{3}$. On the other hand there is $\la_0 \in \La$  such that $\left\|f' - u_\la f' \right\| < \frac{\eps}{3\left\|a'f'' \right\|}$. It follows that
$$
\la\ge\la_0\Rightarrow\left\|a - u_\la a \right\|\le  \left\|a - f'a'f''\right\|+ \left\|u_\la \left( a - f'a'f''\right)  \right\|+\left\|f'a'f'' - u_\la f'a'f''\right\| < \eps.
$$
Similarly there is $\la'_0\in \La$ such that $\la\ge\la'_0\Rightarrow\left\|a - au_\la  \right\| < \eps$.
In result one has the following limit
\be\label{blowing_strict_eqn}
\bt\text{-}\lim u_\la = 1_{M(A)}
\ee
with respect to the strict topology of $M\left( A\right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{strict_topology}).
\end{empt}

\begin{example}\label{blowing_ctr_exm}
If $A$ is a $C^*$-algebra with Hausdorff $\sX$  then from the Theorems \ref{oa_haus_prim_thm} and  \ref{dauns_hofmann_thm} one has the natural inclusion $C_0\left(\sX \right) \hookto M\left( A\right)$. For all $a \in A$ and $\eps> 0$ the subset
$$
\sY \bydef \left\{\left.x \in \sX\right| \left\| \rep_x\left(a\right)\right\|\ge \eps \right\}\subset\sY
$$
is compact (cf. Lemma \ref{ctr_rep_eq_lem}). If $u_\la \in C_c\left(\sY \right)_+$ is a covering sum for $\sY$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_covering_sum_defn}) then for any $\la'\ge\la$ one has
\bean
\left\|au_{\la' }- a \right\|< \eps, \\
\left\|u_{\la' }a- a \right\|< \eps. 
\eean
From the above equations there is the 	limit $
1_{M\left(A \right)  }= \bt~\text{-}\lim_{\la \in \La }u_\la
$
with respect to the strict topology (cf. Definition \ref{strict_topology}) of $M\left( A\right)$. It turns out that $C_0\left(\sX \right) \hookto M\left( A\right)$ satisfies to the condition (a)  Definition \ref{blowing_defn}). If $\rep_x: A \to B\left( \H\right)$ is an irreducible representation then if $f \in C_0\left(\sX \right)$ is such that $f\left(x \right)  = 1$ then $\rep_x\left( f\right) = 1_{B\left(\H \right) }$ and $\rep_x\left(f \right)\H = \H$, i.e.  $C_0\left(\sX \right) \hookto M\left( A\right)$ satisfies to the condition (b)  Definition \ref{blowing_defn}).
So  $C_0\left(\sX \right) \hookto M\left( A\right)$
is a good spectral {Hausdorff blowing-up} of $A$ (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn}, \ref{blowing_good_defn} and \ref{blowing_spectal_defn}).
\end{example}
\begin{definition}\label{blowing_supp_defn}
Let $A$ be $C^*$-algebra, and let $C_0\left( \sY\right) \subset M\left(A \right)$  be a blowing-up (cf. Definition \ref{blowing_defn}). If $a \in A$ then an open set $\sU\subset \sX$ is said to be $a$-\textit{admissible} if
$$
\forall f \in C_0\left( \sY\right)\quad \supp f \subset \sU \quad \Rightarrow\quad f a = 0 \quad \text{ AND }\quad a f = 0.
$$
The \textit{support} of $a$ is given by
\be\label{blowing_supp_eqn}
\supp a \bydef \sY~~\setminus\bigcup_{\sU \text{ is } a\text{-admissible}}~~\sU.
\ee
\end{definition}
\begin{lemma}\label{blowing_supp_lem}
Let $A$ be $C^*$-algebra, and let $C_0\left( \sY\right) \subset M\left(A \right)$  be a good blowing-up (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn}, \ref{blowing_good_defn}). If $a \in A_+$ is positive, $\eps > 0$ and $f_\eps$ is given by the equation \eqref{f_eps_eqn} then the set $\supp f_\eps\left(a \right)\subset \sY$ is compact.  
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
If $b \bydef \sqrt{a}$ then  from the Definition \ref{blowing_good_defn} it turns out that for all $\delta > 0$ there is	
\bean
b' = \sum_{j = 1}^{n} b_{j,1}\cdot ... \cdot b_{j,m_j},\\
\forall j = 1,..., n \quad k = 1,..., m_j\quad \exists \a_{j,k}\in \mathscr A\quad b_{j,k}\in A_{\sU_{\b_{j,k}}},\\
\left\|b - b' \right\| < \delta.\\
\eean
where $\sU_{\a_{j,k}}$ is a subset of a compact set for all $j,k$. From $\supp b'\subset \cup \sU_{j,k}$ it follows that $\supp b'^*b'$ is compact. If $a' \bydef b'^*b'$ and $\delta^2 + 2 \delta \left\| b\right\|< \eps$ then $ \left\| a - a'\right\|< \eps$. 
If $\chi$ is a characteristic map of $\supp a'$ and $A \to B\left(\H\right)$ is a faithful representation then $\chi$ corresponds to a projector $p^\parallel\in  B\left(\H\right)$. If $p^\perp \bydef 1_{B\left(\H\right)}- p^\parallel$ then $p^\perp$ is also a projector. If $p^\perp f_{\eps}\left( a\right)p^\perp \neq 0$ then $\left\| p^\perp ap^\perp\right\|  > \eps$. Otherwise from $p^\perp a
'p^\perp= 0$ it follows that $ \left\| a - a'\right\|> \eps$. From this contradiction one concludes that $p^\perp f_{\eps}\left( a\right)p^\perp = 0$, and $~~\chi f_{\eps}\left( a\right) = 0$ so $\supp f_\eps\left(a \right)\subset \supp a'$. Since the set $\supp a'$ is compact $\supp f_\eps\left(a \right)$ is also compact.
\end{proof}
\begin{exercise}\label{blowing_ped_exer}
Prove that if $a\in A$ lies in the  Pedersen's ideal of $A$ (cf. Definition \ref{peder_id_defn}) then $\supp a$ is compact.
\end{exercise}

\section{Hausdorff blowing-up and noncommutative  coverings}
\paragraph*{}
Let $A$ be a  connected $C^*$-algebra (cf. Definition \ref{conn_c_a_defn}), and let $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(A \right)$  be a Hausdorff  blowing-up of $A$. If $\left(A, \widetilde{A}, G, \pi \right)$ is a noncommutative finite-fold covering then from the Lemma \ref{ind_mult_inv_lem} it follows that there is the natural inclusion $\varphi:M\left({A} \right) \hookto M\left(\widetilde{A} \right)$ of $C^*$-algebras. So there is the natural inclusion $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(\widetilde{A} \right)$. If $\sU\subset \sY$ is an open subset then there is an inclusion $C_0\left(\sU \right)A C_0\left(\sU \right)\subset C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde A C_0\left(\sU \right)$. If  $\widetilde A_\sU$ is the $C^*$-norm completion of $C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde A C_0\left(\sU \right)$ then there is the natural injective *-homomorphism.

\be\label{blowing_jsu_eqn}.
j_{\sU}: A_\sU \hookto \widetilde A_\sU.
\ee

\begin{definition}\label{blowing_semi1_defn}
Let $A$ be a  connected $C^*$- algebra. A Hausdorff  blowing-up $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(A \right)$ of $A$ is said to be \textit{%(reducibly) 
	semilocally 1-connected} if for any $y\in \sY$ and every open neighborhood $\sV$ of $y$   there is an open neighborhood $\sU$ of $y$ such that $\sU\subset \sV$ and  $A_\sU$ (cf. \eqref{blowig_su_eqn}) is %(reducibly) 
reducibly simply connected (cf. Definitions \ref{simply_connected_defn} and \ref{simply_connected_red_defn}).
\end{definition}


\begin{lemma}\label{blowing_simply_conn_lem}

Let $A$ be a  connected $C^*$- algebra, and let $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(A \right)$ be a 
{semilocally} 1-{connected} Hausdorff  blowing-up, with locally connected $\sY$. Then for each reduced noncommutative finite-fold covering $\left(A, \widetilde{A}, G, \pi \right)$ (cf. Definitions \ref{fin_defn} REPLACE !!! \ref{fin_weak_defn}  CONNECTED!!! CONNECTED !!! and \ref{fin_red_defn}), every $y\in\sY$,  each open neighborhood  there is an open connected neighborhood $\sU$ of $y$ such that $\sU\subset \sV$ and the given by \eqref{blowing_jsu_eqn} *-homomomorphism $j_{\sU}: A_\sU \hookto \widetilde A_\sU$ is an almost trivial disconnected noncommutative finite-fold covering (cf. Definition \ref{almost_trivial_defn}).
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
From the Definition \ref{fin_defn} REPLACE !!! \ref{fin_weak_defn}  CONNECTED!!! CONNECTED !!! it turns out that there is an increasing net $\left\{u_\la\right\}_{\la\in\La}\subset M\left( A\right)_+ $  of positive elements such that
\begin{enumerate}
	\item[(a)] There is the limit 
	\be\nonumber
	\bt\text{-}\lim_{\la \in \La} u_\la = 1_{M\left(A \right) }
	\ee
	in the strict topology of $M\left(A \right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{strict_topology}).
	\item[(b)]  If for all   $\la\in\La$ both $A_\la$ and  $\widetilde A_\la$ are $C^*$-norm completions  of $u_\la A u_\la$ and  $u_\la\widetilde{A}u_\la$ respectively then for every $\la\in\La$ a quadruple
	$$
	\left(A_\la, \widetilde{A}_\la, G, \left.\pi\right|_{A_\la} :A_\la\hookto \widetilde{A}_\la\right)	
	$$
	is a noncommutative finite-fold covering with unitization. The action 	$G \times \widetilde{A}_\la\to \widetilde{A}_\la$, is the restriction on $\widetilde{A}_\la\subset \widetilde{   A}$ of the action $G\times  \widetilde{A}\to \widetilde{A}$.
\end{enumerate}
For any $\la\in \La$ there is an  ideal of $C_0\left(\sY \right)$ given by
$$
D_\la\bydef  \left\{\left. f \in C_0\left(\sY \right)\right| fu_\la= u_\la f = 0\right\}.
$$ 
Denote by
$$
C_\la\bydef \left\{\left. f \in C_0\left(\sY \right)\right| \forall f'\in D_\la \quad ff' = 0\right\}
$$
Both $D_\la$ and $C_\la$ are ideals of $C_0\left( \sY\right)$ such that there are open subsets $\sV_\la$ and $\sU_\la$ of $\sY$ which satisfy to conditions $D_\la = C_0\left(\sV_\la\right)$ and $C_\la = C_0\left(\sU_\la\right)$. For all $\la\in \La$ an intersection $\sU_\la\cap \sV_\la$ is empty and a union $\sU_\la\cup \sV_\la$ is dense in $\sY$. From $\bt\text{-}\lim_{\la \in \La} u_\la = 1_{M\left(A \right) }$ it follows that $\bigcap_{\La \in \la}\sV_\la = \emptyset$ and $\bigcup_{\La \in \la}\sU_\la = \sY$. For any $y\in\sY$ denote by  $\la_y\in  \La$ such that $y \in \sU_{\la_y}$. If both $A_y$ and $\widetilde A_y$ are $C^*$-norm completions of both $u_{\la_y}Au_{\la_y}$ and $u_{\la_y}\widetilde Au_{\la_y}$ respectively then 	$\left(A_y, \widetilde{A}_y, G, \left.\pi\right|_{A_y}\right)$ is  a noncommutative finite-fold covering with unitization (cf. Definition \ref{fin_comp_defn}).  It means that following conditions hold:
\begin{enumerate}
	\item[(a)] 
	There are unitizations $A_y \hookto B$, $\widetilde{A}_y \hookto \widetilde{B}$.
	%	\item[(b)]$A = B\bigcap \widetilde{A}$,
	\item[(b)] There is a %(strong) 
	unital  noncommutative finite-fold quasi-covering	$\left(B ,\widetilde{B}, G, \widetilde{\pi} \right)$ such that
	$\pi = \widetilde{\pi}|_A$ (or, equivalently $A \cong \widetilde{A}\cap B$) and
	the action $G \times\widetilde{A} \to \widetilde{A}$ is induced by $G \times\widetilde{B} \to \widetilde{B}$.
\end{enumerate}
From the Definition \ref{fin_uni_defn} it follows that there is a finite set $\left\{\widetilde b_1, ..., \widetilde b_n\right\}\subset \widetilde B$, such that 
$$
\widetilde B = \widetilde b_1B +  ...+\widetilde b_nB
$$
Let $\sU$ be an open neighborhood of $y$ such that $\sU\subset \sU_{\la_y}$ and $A_\sU$ is simply connected. From
\bean
\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)B C_0\left(\sU \right)\right) \left( C_0\left(\sU \right) A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset C_0\left(\sU \right) A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right),\\
\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)A_y C_0\left(\sU \right)\right) \left( C_0\left(\sU \right) B  C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset C_0\left(\sU \right) A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right),\\
\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde B C_0\left(\sU \right)\right) \left( C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right),\\
\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde A_y C_0\left(\sU \right)\right) \left( C_0\left(\sU \right) B  C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset C_0\left(\sU \right) \widetilde A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right)
\eean
and since both $C_0\left(\sU \right) A C_0\left(\sU \right) $ and  $C_0\left(\sU \right) \widetilde A C_0\left(\sU \right) $ are dense in both $A_\sU$ and $\widetilde A_\sU$ respectively
it turns out that $\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)B C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset M\left( A_\sU\right)$ and $\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde B C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset M\left( \widetilde A_\sU\right)$. If $\left\{v_\a \right\}$ is an approximate unit for of $C_0\left(\sU \right)$ then it is an approximate unit of both $M\left( A_\sU\right)$ and $M\left(\widetilde A_\sU\right)$ (cf. equation \eqref{blowing_strict_eqn}).  So all $b\in B$ and  $\widetilde b \in \widetilde B$ the both  nets  $\left\{v_\a bv_\a\right\}$ and   $\left\{v_\a \widetilde bv_\a\right\}$ are convergent with respect to strict topologies of $M\left( A_\sU\right)$ and of $M\left( \widetilde A_\sU\right)$. If both $B_\sU$ and $\widetilde B_\sU$ are $C^*$-algebras of strict limits of nets $\left\{v_\a bv_\a\right\}$ and   $\left\{v_\a \widetilde bv_\a\right\}$ where $b\in B$ and $\widetilde b\in\widetilde B$ then
$$
\widetilde B_\sU = \widetilde b^\sU_1 B_\sU + ... + \widetilde b^\sU_n B_\sU;\quad \widetilde b^\sU_j\bydef \bt\text{-}\lim v_\a \widetilde b_jv_\a; \quad j = 1,...,n.
$$
It follows that the natural inclusions $A_\sU \subset \widetilde B_\sU$ and $A_\sU \subset \widetilde B_\sU$ are unitizations, so
from the Definition \ref{fin_comp_defn} it follows that $\left(A_\sU,\widetilde A_\sU, G, \pi|_{A_\sU}\right)$ is  a reduced noncommutative finite-fold quasi-covering with unitization. From the Lemma \ref{quasi_red_lem} it turns out that $A_\sU \hookto \widetilde A_\sU$ a disconnected noncommutative finite-fold reduced  covering with unitization (cf. Definitions \ref{fin_comp_defn}, \ref{fin_red_defn}). On the other hand $A_\sU$ is reducibly  simply connected, so $A_\sU \hookto \widetilde A_\sU$ is an  almost trivial disconnected noncommutative finite-fold covering of $A_\sU$.
\end{proof}

\begin{empt}\label{blowing_b_empt}
Let $A$ be a $C^*$- algebra and let $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(A \right)$  be a good  blowing-up of $A$ (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn} and \ref{blowing_good_defn}) such that $\sY$ is connected and locally connected. Let $q: \widetilde \sY\to\sY$ be a transitive covering (cf. Definition \ref{top_transitive_defn}).
Let  $\left\{\sU_\a\subset\sU\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$ be a {compliant with} $q$ family, and let $\left\{\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}\right\}_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A}}$  the $q$-{lift} of $\left\{\sU_\a\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$. (cf. Definition 
\ref{top_lconn_defn}).
Let $\mathfrak P$ be a set of $\left\{\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}\right\}$-paths (cf. Definition \ref{top_gen_path_defn}).  Consider a subset  $\mathfrak G \subset \mathfrak P\times A$ such that $\left( \mathfrak p,a \right)\in \mathfrak G$ if $\mathfrak p= \left(\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_1}, ..., \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_n}\right)$ then there are $a_1\in A_{p\left(\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_1 }\right) },...,a_n\in A_{p\left(\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_n }\right) }$ such that $a = a_1\cdot...\cdot a_n$. There is an involution on $\mathfrak G$ given by $\left( \mathfrak p,a \right)^*= \left( \mathfrak p^*,a^* \right)$ (cf. \eqref{top_path_inv_eqn}). The action $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY \right)\times \widetilde \sY\to \widetilde \sY$ induces an action of $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY \right)\times \mathfrak G\to \mathfrak G$.
If $\widetilde\B$ is a generated by $\mathfrak G$ free Abelian group, then both  involution and action of $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY \right)$ on $\mathfrak G$ induce involution and action of $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY \right)$ on $\widetilde\B$. There is multiplication on $\widetilde\B$ such that
\bean
\left( \mathfrak p_1,a_1 \right)\left( \mathfrak p_2,a_2 \right)
\bydef \\
\bydef\begin{cases}
	0 & \left( \mathfrak p_1,\mathfrak p_2 \right)\text{ is not composable (cf. Definition \ref{top_path_comp_defn})}\\
	\left( \mathfrak p_1\circ \mathfrak p_2,a_1a_2 \right) & \left( \mathfrak p_1,\mathfrak p_2 \right)\text{ is  composable}
\end{cases}
\eean
where  $\mathfrak p_1\circ \mathfrak p_2$ is given by \eqref{top_path_comp_eqn}, so  $\widetilde\B$ becomes a *-algebra. If $\A\subset A$ be the algebraically generated by $\cup A_{\sU_\a}$ subalgebra then there is the left and right action of $\A$ on $\widetilde\B$. Let  $a \in A_{\sU_\a}$ and let $\widetilde b \in \widetilde \B$ be represented by the pair $\left(\mathfrak p, b\right)$ such that $\mathfrak p= \left(\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_1}, ..., \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_n}\right)$. If $q\left( \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_1}\right) \cap \sU_{\a} = \emptyset$, then we put $a\widetilde b = 0$. Otherwise there is the unique path $\mathfrak p' = \mathfrak p'' \circ \mathfrak p$ such that $\mathfrak p'' = \left(\widetilde \sU_{\widetilde\a}\right)$ and $q\left( \widetilde \sU_{\widetilde\a}\right) = \sU_\a$ (cf. Lemma \ref{top_path_lift_lem}). We put 
\be\label{blowing_atb_eqn}
a \widetilde b\bydef\left(\mathfrak p', ab\right).
\ee
The union $\cup A_{\sU_\a}$ algebraically generates $\A$ one has an action $\A \times \widetilde \B \to \widetilde \B$. Using *-operation one can obtain the right action of $\A$ on $\widetilde \B$ such that $\widetilde \B$ becomes an $\A$-bimodule.	There is a  *-homomorphism $q_{\widetilde\B}: \widetilde\B \to A$ given by $\left( \mathfrak p,a \right)\mapsto a$ and $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY \right)$-invariant  *-seminorm $\left\|\cdot \right\|_{\widetilde{\B}}$ on $\widetilde \B$ given by
\be\label{blowing_norm_eqn}
\left\|\widetilde b \right\|_{\widetilde{\B}} = \sqrt{\left\|p_{\widetilde{\B}}\left(\widetilde b^*\widetilde b\right)  \right\|}.
\ee 
The set
\be\label{blowing_ideal_eqn}
I_{\widetilde{\B}} = \left\{\left.\widetilde b \in \widetilde\B~\right| \left\| \widetilde b \right\|_{\widetilde{\B}}=0\right\}
\ee
is an involutive two sided ideal. The seminorm on $\left\|\cdot \right\|_{	{\widetilde{\B}}}$ induces a  $C^*$-norm $\left\|\cdot \right\|_{\widetilde B/ I_{\widetilde{\B}}}$ on $\widetilde \A\bydef\widetilde \B/	I_{\widetilde{\B}}$, denote by $\widetilde \H_A$ the $\left\|\cdot \right\|_{\widetilde B/ I_\B}$-norm completion of $\widetilde \A$.  The structure of $\A$-bimodule of $\widetilde{\B}$ induces the structure of the Hilbert $A$-bimodule on $\widetilde \H_A$. On the other hand the multiplication on	$\widetilde \A$ induces  an injective *-homomorhism
\be\label{blowing_end_eqn}
\widetilde \A\hookto \End_A^*\left( \widetilde \H_A\right) 
\ee
where $\End_A^*\left( \widetilde \H_A\right)$ means the $C^*$-algebra of adjointable endomorphisms (cf. Definition \ref{adj_aop_defn}). 
The $C^*$-norm on $\End^*_A\left(\widetilde \H_A\right)$ induces the $C^*$-norm on $\widetilde \A$. If  $\widetilde A$ is the $C^*$-norm completion of $\widetilde \A$ then $\widetilde A$ is a $C^*$-algebra. The algebra $\widetilde\B$ algebraically generated by elements $\left( \mathfrak p, a\right)$ where $\mathfrak p=\left(  \widetilde\sU_\a\right)$ and $a \in A_{p\left( \widetilde\sU_\a\right) }$. If we denote  by $\mathfrak T$ a set of pairs $\left( \sU_\a, a\right)$, such that  $a \in A_{p\left( \widetilde\sU_\a\right) }$ then there is the natural map $\mathfrak T\to \widetilde \B$. This map induces a map
\be\label{blowing_pt_eqn}
q_{\mathfrak T}:\mathfrak T\to \widetilde A
\ee
such that the image of $q_{\mathfrak T}$ generates $C^*$-algebra $\widetilde{A}$.
The action $G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}~\right| \sY\right)\times \widetilde\sY\to \widetilde\sY$ naturally induces the action
\be\label{blowing_gpt_eqn}
G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}~\right| \sY\right)\times \mathfrak T\to \mathfrak T
\ee
\end{empt}


\begin{definition}\label{blowing_lift_a_defn}
In the above situation denote by
\be\label{blowing_a0_x_eqn}
\widetilde A_0\left(\widetilde\sY  \right)\bydef \widetilde A.
\ee
The natural inclusion of $A$ into $ M\left( A_0\left(\widetilde\sY  \right)\right) $ will be denoted by
\be\label{blowing_ab_p_eqn}
A_b\left(q\right): A \hookto M\left( A_0\left(\widetilde\sY  \right)\right).
\ee
The action \eqref{blowing_gpt_eqn} induces an action 
\be\label{blowing_gact_eqn}
G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}~\right| \sY\right)\times A_0\left(\widetilde\sY  \right)\to A_0\left(\widetilde\sY  \right).
\ee
We say that  $A_0\left(\widetilde\sY  \right)$ is the $q$-\textit{lift} of $A$. 

\end{definition}

Prove that   the equation \eqref{top_c0i_ob_eqn} $C^*$-algebra  is a specialization of given by the equation \eqref{blowing_a0_x_eqn} one.

\begin{definition}\label{blowing_lift_desc_defn}
A composition of $A_0\left(q  \right)^{\widetilde{\sU}}$ and the inclusion $A_0\left(\widetilde\sY  \right)_{\widetilde{\sU}}\subset A_0\left(\widetilde\sY  \right)$ is said to be $q$-$\widetilde{\sU}$-\textit{lift} or simply the $\widetilde{\sU}$-\textit{lift}. \ee

\begin{remark}
The above definition complies with the Definition \ref{top_lift_desc_defn}.

\subsection{Finite-fold coverings}

\paragraph{}
Here we prove that a finite-fold coverings of Hausdorff blowing-up yields a noncommutative reduced finite-fold coverings and vice versa.
\begin{lemma}\label{blowing_covi_lem}
Let $A$ be a $C^*$-algebra, and let $C = C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left( A\right) $  be a good  blowing-up of $A$ (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn}, \ref{blowing_good_defn}).
Suppose that $\sY$ is a connected, locally connected space. If $q: \widetilde \sY\to \sY$ is a transitive finite-fold covering and $A_0\left(q \right): A\hookto A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right)$ is given by \eqref{blowing_a0x_eqn}  then there is 	 a reduced noncommutative finite-fold   covering $\left(A, A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) , G\left(\left. \widetilde\sY\right| \sY\right) , A_0\left( q\right)  \right)$ (cf. Definitions \ref{fin_defn} REPLACE !!! \ref{fin_weak_defn}  CONNECTED!!! CONNECTED !!!, \ref{fin_red_defn}) such that if $\varphi : M\left( A\right) \to M\left(A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right)\right)$ is given by the Lemma \ref{ind_mult_inv_lem} then
$\left.\varphi\right|_{A_0\left( \sY\right) }= A_0\left(q \right)$. 

\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Let  $\left\{\sU_\a\subset\sU\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$ be a {compliant with} $q$ family  (cf. Definition 
\ref{top_lconn_defn}), and let $\left\{\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}\right\}_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A}}$  the $q$-{lift} of $\left\{\sU_\a\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$.	If $G$ is given by
$$
G \bydef \left\{ \left.g \in \Aut\left( A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) \right)~\right|~ ga = a;~~\forall a \in A\right\}
$$
then from the action \eqref{blowing_gact_eqn} it turns out that $G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}~\right| \sY\right)= G$, it follows that the triple $\left(A, A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) , G\left(\left. \widetilde\sY\right| \sY\right) , A_0\left( p\right)  \right)$ is  noncommutative finite-fold  pre-covering (cf. Definition \ref{fin_pre_defn}). From the Lemma \ref{comm_direct_lem} it follows that there is an approximate unit   $\left\{u_\la\right\}_{\la\in \La}\subset C_c\left( \sY\right)_+$ for $C_0\left(\sY\right)$ such that $\supp u_\la$ is a connected compact set (cf. Lemma \ref{comm_direct_lem}), for each $\la\in\La$.  Let both $A_\la$ and $A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right)_\la$ be $C^*$-norm completions of $u_\la A u_\la$  and $u_\la A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) u_\la$ respectively, and let us prove that  $\left\{u_\la\right\}$ satisfies to conditions (a), (b) of the Definition \ref{fin_defn} REPLACE !!! \ref{fin_weak_defn}  CONNECTED!!! CONNECTED !!!.
\begin{enumerate}
	\item [(a)] From \eqref{blowing_strict_eqn} one has  the limit 
	\bean
	\bt\text{-}\lim_{\la \in \La} u_\la = 1_{M\left(A \right) }
	\eean
	in the strict topology of $M\left(A \right)$.
	\item[(b)] One needs proof that for every $\la\in\La$ a quadruple
	$$
	\left(A_\la, \widetilde{A}_\la, G, \left.\pi\right|_{A_\la} :A_\la\hookto \widetilde{A}_\la\right)	
	$$
	is a noncommutative finite-fold covering with unitization.
	If for each $\la\in \La$ denote by $\sV_\la\bydef \supp u_\la$ and $\widetilde \sV_\la \bydef p^{-1}\left( \sV_\la\right)$, then there are natural inclusions $C\left( \sV_\la\right) \subset M\left(A_\la\right)$ and $C\left( \widetilde\sV_\la\right) \subset M\left(\widetilde A_\la\right)$. If both $B$ and $\widetilde B$ are  $C^*$-subalgebras of $M\left(A_\la\right)$ and $M\left(\widetilde A_\la\right)$ generated by unions  $A_\la \cup C\left( \sV_\la\right)$ and $\widetilde A_\la \cup C\left(\widetilde \sV_\la\right)$ respectively then the given by the Lemma \ref{ind_mult_inv_lem} inclusion $\phi_\la: M\left(A_\la\right)\hookto M\left(\widetilde A_\la\right)$ is such that $\phi_\la\left(B \right)\subset \widetilde B$, i.e. there is the natural inclusion $\widetilde \pi: B \hookto\widetilde B$. Let us prove that $B$ and $\widetilde B$ satisfy to conditions (a) and (b) of the Definition \ref{fin_comp_defn}.
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item [(a)]  From $B \subset M\left(A_\la\right)$ and $\widetilde B \subset M\left( \widetilde A_\la\right)$ it follows that both $A_\la \hookto B$  and $\widetilde{A}_\la \hookto \widetilde{B}$ are unitizations.
		\item[(b)] Since $q$ is a transitive covering the restriction $q|_{\widetilde \sV_\la}: \widetilde \sV_\la \to \sV_\la$ is also transitive covering, hence from  \ref{ctr_unity_empt} it follows that there is a finite sum
		\be\label{blowing_unity_sum_eqn}
		1_{C\left(\widetilde{\mathcal Y} \right) }= \sum_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A} }\widetilde{a}_{\widetilde{\a}}= \sum_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A} }\widetilde{e}^2_{\widetilde{\a}}\quad \widetilde{a}_{\widetilde{\a}},~\widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\bydef\sqrt{\widetilde{a}_{\widetilde{\a}}}\in C\left(\widetilde \sY\right)
		\ee
		such that 		for any nontrivial $g\in G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right)$	one has
		\be\label{blowing_unity_orth_eqn}
		\begin{split}
			\widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}	\left(g \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}} \right) = 0.
		\end{split}
		\ee
		If $\widetilde a \in \widetilde B$ then from \eqref{blowing_unity_sum_eqn} it follows that
		\be\label{ctr_unity_orthx_eqn}
		\widetilde a = \sum_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A} }\widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\left( \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\widetilde a\right). 
		\ee
		From \eqref{blowing_unity_orth_eqn} it follows that if $g\in G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right)$ is not trivial then 
		\be\label{blowing_unity_orthxx_eqn}
		\widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\left(g\left(  \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\widetilde a\right) \right) = 		\widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}	\left(g \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}} \right) \left(g \widetilde{\a} \right) = 0\cdot \left(g \widetilde{\a} \right) = 0.
		\ee
		From the equations \eqref{ctr_unity_orthx_eqn} and \eqref{blowing_unity_orthxx_eqn} it follows that
		$$
		\widetilde a = \sum_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A} }\widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}} a_\a\quad\text{where}\quad a_\a \bydef \sum_{g\in G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right)}g\left( \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\widetilde a\right)\in B, 
		$$
		i.e. $\widetilde B$ is a finitely generated $B$-module. So $\left(B, \widetilde B,G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right),  \widetilde\pi\right)$ is an unital noncommutative finite fold covering (cf. Definition \ref{fin_uni_defn}). From $ B \cap \widetilde A_\la=A_\la$ and $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right) \times \widetilde A_\la= \widetilde A_\la$ it follows that\\ $\left( A_\la,\widetilde A_\la, G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right) , \widetilde\pi|_{A_\la}  \right)$ is a noncommutative finite-fold covering with unitization.
	\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}
Thus  $\left(A, A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) , G\left(\left. \widetilde\sY\right| \sY\right) , A_0\left( p\right)  \right)$ is a  noncommutative finite-fold   covering, let us prove that it is reduced.\\
Let $\left\{\sU_\a\subset \sY\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$ be a {compliant with} $q$ family and let $\left\{\widetilde\sU_{\a}\right\}_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A}}$ is the $q$-{lift} of $\left\{\sU_\a\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_lconn_defn}). From the equations \eqref{blowig_sue_eqn} and \eqref{blowing_asu_eqn} it turns out then for all $\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A}$ there is an  injective *-homomorphism 
\be\label{blowing_ds_eqn}
\left.A_0\left(q\right)\right|_{A_{q\left( \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}\right) }}:A_{q\left( \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}\right)} \hookto \bigoplus_{g\in G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY\right)}g\left.	 A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY\right)\right._{ \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}}
\ee
If $\widetilde a \in g\left.	 A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY\right)\right._{ \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}}$ is positive then there is the sum $a \bydef  \sum_{g'\in G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY\right)}g'g\left.	 A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY\right)\right._{ \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}}$ is $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY\right)$-invariant, so $a \in A_0\left( p\right)\left( A\right)$ and $\widetilde a < a$.
If $\widetilde A'$ is a hereditary $C^*$-subalgebra of $ A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY\right)$ which contains $A_0\left( p\right)\left( A\right)$ then from  $a \in A_0\left( p\right)\left( A\right)$, $~~\widetilde a < a$ and the Definition \ref{hered_defn} it follows that $\widetilde a \in \widetilde A'$. Since $A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY\right)$ is a generated by the union $\bigcup_{g, \a} g\left.	 A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY\right)\right._{ \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}}$ one has $A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY\right)=\widetilde A'$. Now
from the Definitions \ref{red_alg_defn} and \ref{fin_red_defn} it turns out that the  noncommutative finite-fold   covering $\left(A, A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) , G\left(\left. \widetilde\sY\right| \sY\right) , A_0\left( p\right)  \right)$ is reduced.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}\label{blowing_lift_d_lem}
Let $A$ be a $C^*$- algebra and let $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(A \right)$  be a good  blowing-up of $A$ (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn} and \ref{blowing_good_defn}) such that $\sY$ is connected and locally connected. Let $q_1: \widetilde \sY_1\to\sY$,  $q_2: \widetilde \sY_2\to\sY$ be a finite-fold transitive coverings (cf. Definition \ref{top_transitive_defn}) such that there is a transitive covering $q^2_1:  \widetilde \sY_2\to  \widetilde \sY_1$ with $q_2 = p_1\circ p^2_1$.

\begin{enumerate}
	\item [(i)]		There are  natural actions $G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}_1~\right| \sY\right) \times A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)\to A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)$ and $G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}_2~\right| \sY\right) \times A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_2\right)\to A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_2 \right)$.
	\item[(ii)] One has
	\be\label{blowing_g_inv_eqn}
	\begin{split}
		G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}_2~\right| \sY \right) 
		A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)   =			G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}_1~\right| \sY \right) 
		A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)
	\end{split}
	\ee
	where the natural inclusion $A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)\subset A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_2 \right)$ is implied.
	
\end{enumerate} 

\end{lemma}
\begin{proof} 
(i)	 Follows from the equation \eqref{blowing_gact_eqn}.\\
(ii) From the Corollary \ref{com_norm_cor} one has an exact sequence of group homomorphisms
$$
\left\{e\right\} \to 	G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\widetilde\sY_1 \right) \to 	G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\sY \right) \to 	G\left(\widetilde\sY_1~|~\sY \right) \to \left\{e\right\},
$$
so $G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\widetilde\sY_1 \right)$  is a normal subgroup of $	G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\sY \right)$.
Direct check shows that 	
\be\label{blowing_ga_eqn}
A_0\left(\widetilde\sY \right)\cong \left\{\left.\widetilde a \in A_0\left(\widetilde\sY \right)\right|g\widetilde a= \widetilde{a}\quad \forall g \in G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\widetilde\sY_1 \right) \right\}
\ee
If   $g \in  G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\sY \right)$ and $ g'\in G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\widetilde\sY_1 \right)$ then from \eqref{normal_subgroup_eqn} it turns out that  there is $ g''\in G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\widetilde\sY_1 \right)$ such that $g'g= gg''$. It turns out that
$$
\forall \widetilde a\in A_0\left( \widetilde \sY_1\right) \quad g'\left(g\widetilde a \right) = g\left(g''\widetilde a \right)= g\widetilde a,  
$$
i.e. $g\widetilde a$ satisfies to \eqref{blowing_ga_eqn}, therefore $g\widetilde a\in A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)$.
\end{proof}
