\subsection{Fundamental group and Hurewcs homomorphism}\label{nt_fg_sec}
\paragraph{}
Let $C\left( \T^{2}_\th\right)$ be a noncommutative torus (cf. \eqref{nt_symplectic_eqn}) and let $u, v\in U\left( C\left( \T^{2}_\th\right)\right)$ be its generators (cf. Definition \ref{nt_uni_defn}). Let $n > 1$ and consider two finite-fold noncommutatve coverings
\bean
\phi_1: C\left( \T^{2}_\th\right)\hookto  C\left( \T^{2}_{\th/n}\right),\\
u \mapsto \widetilde u_1,\quad v \mapsto \widetilde v_1^n;\\
\phi_2: C\left( \T^{2}_\th\right)\hookto  C\left( \T^{2}_{\left( \th + 1\right) /n}\right),\\
u \mapsto \widetilde u_2,\quad v \mapsto \widetilde v_2^n
\eean
where $u_1, v_1\in U\left( C\left( \T^{2}_{\left( \th\right) /n}\right)\right)$ and $u_1, v_1\in U\left( C\left( \T^{2}_{\left( \th + 1\right) /n}\right)\right)$. If $U, V \in \mathbb{M}_n\left(\C \right)$ are such that
\bean
U \bydef \begin{pmatrix}
	1& 0 & 0&\ldots &0 \\
	0& e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}} & 0&\ldots &0 \\
	0& 0&e^{\frac{ 2\pi i\cdot 2}{n}}  &\ldots & 0\\
	\vdots& \vdots&\vdots &\ddots&\vdots\\
0& 0& 0&\ldots & e^{\frac{2\pi i\left( n-1\right) }{n}}
\end{pmatrix},\\
V \bydef  \begin{pmatrix}
0& 1 &0&\ldots &0 \\
	0&0& 1 &\ldots &0 \\
	\vdots&\vdots&\vdots &\ddots&\vdots\\
	0& 0&0&\ldots &1\\
	1& 0&0&\ldots &0
\end{pmatrix}
\eean
then $UV = e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}VU$. There is an isomorphism
\bean
C\left( \T^{2}_{\th /n}\right)\otimes \mathbb{M}_n\left(\C \right)\cong  C\left( \T^{2}_{\left(\th+1 \right) /n}\right)\otimes\mathbb{M}_n\left(\C \right),\\
\widetilde u_1\otimes m \mapsto \widetilde u_2\otimes Um, \quad \widetilde v_1\otimes m \mapsto \widetilde v_2\otimes Vm.
\eean 
Although coverings $\phi_1$ and $\phi_2$ are essentially different their  stabilizations
\bean
\phi_1\otimes 1_{M\left(\K\right)} : C\left( \T^{2}_\th\right)\otimes \K\hookto C\left( \T^{2}_{\th /n}\right)\otimes \K,\\
\phi_2\otimes 1_{M\left(\K\right)} : C\left( \T^{2}_\th\right)\otimes \K\hookto C\left( \T^{2}_{\left( \th+1\right) /n}\right)\otimes \K
\eean 
are isomorphic. It follows that the set of equivalent coverings of  $C\left( \T^{2}_\th\right)$ is more wide then the set of of equivalent coverings of  $C\left( \T^{2}_\th\right)\otimes\K$ 
This fact motivates usage of $A\otimes\K$ instead of $A$ in the Definition \ref{fg_bas_defn}.
\begin{exercise}\label{nt_non_iso_exer}
	Prove that there are two projectors $p, p' \in \K$ such that
	\bean
\left( 1_{C\left( \T^{2}_{\th /n}\right)}\otimes 	p \right) \left( C\left( \T^{2}_{\th /n}\right)\otimes \K \right) \left( 1_{C\left( \T^{2}_{\th /n}\right)}\otimes 	p \right) \cong  C\left( \T^{2}_{\th /n}\right),\\
\left( 1_{C\left( \T^{2}_{\th /n}\right)}\otimes 	p' \right) \left( C\left( \T^{2}_{\th /n}\right)\otimes \K \right) \left( 1_{C\left( \T^{2}_{\th /n}\right)}\otimes 	p' \right) \cong  C\left( \T^{2}_{\left( \th+1\right) /n}\right).
	\eean
This exercise is a manifestation of the Remark 	\ref{stab_non_iso_rem}.
\end{exercise}
\paragraph*{}
The torus $\T^2$ can be regarded as a quotient $\T^2 = \R^2/\Z^2$. There is the natural infinite covering $\widetilde p : \R^2\to\T^2$. From the Lemma \ref{top_uni_exist_spa_lem} it follows that $\widetilde p$ is the universal covering such that $G\left(\left.\R^2\right|\T^2\right)\cong \Z^2$. Let us select base points $x_0\in \T^2$ and $\widetilde x_0 \in \R^2$ such that $\widetilde p: \left(\R^2, \widetilde x_0\right)\to \left(\T^2 x_0\right)$ is a pointed map. Consider the family of all pointed finite-fold coverings $\left\{p_\la:\left(\sX_\la, x^\la_0\right)\to \left(\T^2 ,x_0\right)\right\}_{\la\in \La}$ such that for any $\la\in \La$ there is a pointed covering $\widetilde p_\la: \left(\R^2, \widetilde x_0\right)\to \left(\sX_\la, x^\la_0\right)$ which satisfies to the following condition $\widetilde p_\la\circ p_\la=\widetilde p$. The group $\Z^2$ is residually finite  (cf. Definition \ref{residually_finite_defn}), hence from the Lemma \ref{top_res_fin_lem} it fo $\R^2$ is the topological inverse noncommutative limit (cf. Definition \ref{top_topological_inv_lim_defn}) of the category 
$
\mathfrak{S}_{\left(\T^2, x_0\right)}\left\{p_\la: \left( \sX_\la, x^\la_0\right) \to \left( \T^2, x_0\right)\right\}_{\la\in\La}.
$
Let $\widetilde \sF$ be a foliation on $\R^2$ which  corresponds to  a vector field $\tilde{X}$ on $\R^2$ given by
\[
dx = \th dy
\]
where $\th  \in \R\setminus\Q$ is an irrational number. Since $\widetilde \sF$ is invariant with respect to the action $\Z^2 \times\R^2 \to \R^2$ there is the foliation $\sF_\th$ on $\T^2$ such that $\widetilde \sF$ is the $\widetilde p$ -lift of $\sF_\th$ (cf. Definition \ref{fol_cov_defn}). The Lemma \ref{foli_base_point_lem} yields  a pointed algebraical  finite covering category $\mathfrak{S}_{C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF\right)}$ (cf. Definition (ref. \ref{pointed_defn}) 
From the Theorem \ref{foli_main_thm} it follows that the triple 
\be\label{nt_f_c_eqn}
\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right), C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF\right), \Z^2 \right)
\ee
 is  the  { infinite noncommutative covering} of $\mathfrak{S}_{C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th, x_0\right)}$ is a noncommutative infinite covering (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}). The transversal
$$
\widetilde N = \left\{\left.\left(0, y \right)\in \R^2\right| y \in \R \right\}\subset \R^2
$$
is complete and $N \bydef \widetilde p\left(\widetilde N \right)$ is also a complete transversal. There are $C^*$-algebras $C^*_r\left( \G^{N}_{N}\right)$ and  $C^*_r\left( \G^{\widetilde N}_{\widetilde N}\right)$ given by \ref{foli_pseudo_empt}.
From the Lemma \ref{foli_stab_lem} it turns out that
\be\label{foli_stab_eqn}
\begin{split}
	C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right)\cong C^*_r\left( \G^{N}_{N}\right)\otimes\K,\\
	C^*_r\left(\R^2,  \widetilde\sF\right) \cong C^*_r\left( \G^{\widetilde N}_{\widetilde N}\right)\otimes\K.
\end{split}
\ee
It is proven in \cite{connes:ncg94} that
\be\label{nt_f_a_eqn}
C^*_r\left(\G^{N}_{N}\right)\cong C\left( \T^2_\th\right) 
\ee
where $C\left( \T^2_\th\right)$ is a noncommutative torus (cf. Definition \ref{nt_defn}).  From the equations \eqref{foli_stab_eqn} and \eqref{foli_stab_eqn} it follows that
\be\label{nt_f_k_eqn}
	C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right)\cong C\left( \T^2_\th\right)\otimes \K
\ee
Since $p:\R^2\to \T^2$ is the universal covering the  fundamental group $\pi_1\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right)\right)$ comes from the following reduced universal covering
\be
\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right), C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF_\th\right), \Z^2 \cong G\left(\left.\R^2\right|\Z^2\right)\right).
\ee
where $\widetilde \sF_\th$ is the $p$-lift of $\sF_\th$
(cf. Definition \eqref{fg_bas_defn}  the Theorems \ref{blowing_main_thm}, \ref{foli_main_spec_thm}).
From the Theorem \ref{blowing_main_thm} it follows that 
\be
\pi^{\mathrm{stable}}_1\left( C\left( \T^2_\th\right)\right)\cong \pi_1\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right)\right)\cong \pi_1\left( \T^2, t_0\right)\cong \Z^2. 
\ee
(cf. Definition \ref{fg_bas_defn} and the Corollary \ref{foli_n_cat_fg_cor}) where the reduced fundamental group is implied.
\begin{exercise}
	Using the Exercise \ref{cofinal_exer} and the  Corollary  \ref{nt_cofinal_cor} prove that 
	$$
	\pi_1\left( C\left( \T^2_\th\right)\right)\cong \Z^2.
	$$
	 
\end{exercise} 


 The group $\pi_1\left( \T^2, t_0\right)\cong G\left(\left.\R^2\right|\T^2\right)$ corresponds to an inclusion $\Z^2 \subset \R^2$ and any $\left(j_x, j_y \right) \in \Z^2\cong \pi_1\left( \T^2, t_0\right)$ corresponds to a  2 - dimensional  shift $\left(j_x, j_y \right)$ of $\R^2$. The natural action $\Z^2\times \R^2\to \R^2$ yields  actions $\Z^2\times C_0\left( \R^2\right) \to C_0\left( \R^2\right)$, $~\Z^2\times C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF_\th\right)\to C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF_\th\right)$. If $x,y$ are real coordinates  of $\R^2$ and $u, v\in U\left(C\left(\T^2_\th\right)\right)\subset M\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right) \right) $ are generators  (cf. Definition \ref{nt_uni_defn}) then $u$ corresponds multiplication by $e^{2\pi i x}$, and $v$ corresponds to the  $\left(0, 1\right)$ shift. Suppose that $\phi_n$ is given by \eqref{h_n_root}. If $C^*_r\left(\R^2, \sF_\th\right)\to B\left(\H \right)$ is a faithful representation and $\widetilde u = \phi_{n_1}\left( u\right)\quad \widetilde v = \phi_{n_2}\left( v\right)  \in M\left(C^*_r\left(\R^2, \sF_\th\right) \right)\subset B\left( \H\right)$ then
\be\label{h_uv_r_eqn}
\begin{split}
\widetilde u \quad \text{corresponds to the multiplication by } e^{\frac{2\pi i x}{n_1}}\in  M\left(C^*_r\left(\R^2, \sF_\th\right) \right),\\
\widetilde v \quad \text{corresponds to the shift } \left(0, \frac{1}{n_2}\right) \in \Q^2.
\end{split}
\ee

Then there are $\left(u, n_1\right)$ and $\left(v, n\right)$ coverings. It is known that 
\be
\begin{split}
	K_0\left(C\left( \T^2_\th\right) \right) \cong \Z^2,\\
	K_1\left(C\left( \T^2_\th\right) \right) \cong \Z^2= \Z\left[u\right]\oplus \Z\left[v\right]
\end{split}
\ee
(cf. \cite{varilly:noncom}), so
\be
	K_1\left(C\left( \T^2_\th\right) \right)_{\mathrm{free~spec}}= K_1\left(C\left( \T^2_\th\right)\right) = \Z\left[u\right]\oplus \Z\left[v\right]
\ee
(cf. Section \ref{h_free_ass_sec} equation \ref{h_k_sum_eqn}). The described in \ref{h_free_ass_sec} Abelian group (cf. \eqref{h_q_eqn}) is isomorphic to $\Q^2$ and there is the natural inclusion $\Z\left[u\right]\oplus \Z\left[v\right]\subset \Q^2$. If    $\chi: \Q\to U\left( 1\right)$ is a nontrivial character  given by $x \mapsto e^{2\pi i q}$ ($q\in \Q$) then for all $g = \left( j_x, j_y\right) \in G\left(\left.C^*_r\left(\R^2, \sF_\th\right)\right|C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right)\right)\cong \pi_1\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right) \right) \cong \Z^2$ from \eqref{h_uv_r_eqn} it follows that 
\be
\begin{split}
\chi_g\left(\phi_{n_1}\left(u\right) \right)=  \frac{g\phi_{n_1}\left(u\right)}{\phi_{n_1}\left(u\right)}=\frac{g\widetilde u}{\widetilde u} =e^{\frac{2 \pi i j_x}{n_1}},\\
\chi_g\left(\phi_{n_2}\left(v\right) \right)\bydef \frac{g\phi_{n_2}\left(v\right)}{\phi_{n_2}\left(v\right)} =\frac{g\widetilde v}{\widetilde v}=e^{\frac{2 \pi i j_y}{n_2}}.
\end{split}
\ee
Above equations define a character $\chi_g:\pi_1\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right) \right)\to U\left(1\right)$. There is  the unique $x_g \in \Hom\left( \Q^2, \Q\right)$ such that $\chi_g\left(y \right) = \chi\left(x_g\left(y \right)  \right)$. 
From $\Z^2 \in \ker\chi_g$ it turns out that $x_g\in \Hom\left( \Z^2, \Z\right)   \cong \Hom\left(K_1\left( C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right), \Z\right)\right)$. Direct calculation proves that
$$
x_{g} = \left(c_1\left[u\right]+c_2\left[v\right]\mapsto j_xc_1 + j_yc_2\right)\quad c_1, c_2 \in \Z.
$$
The  map $g \mapsto x_g$ yields a free Hurewicz homomorphism
$$
h_{\mathrm{free}}:\pi_1\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right) \right)\to \Hom\left(K_1\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right),\Z\right) \right). 
$$
 Otherwise in \cite{phillips:nt_at} it is proven  that $C\left( \T^2_\th\right)$ satisfies to the Theorem \ref{uct_thm}, so one has
$$
\mathrm{\Ext}^1_\Z(K_*(C\left( \T^2_\th\right)), K_*(\C)) \xrightarrow{\delta} KK^*(C\left( \T^2_\th\right), \C) \xrightarrow{\ga} \mathrm{Hom}(K_*(C\left( \T^2_\th\right)), K_*(\C))
$$
Since $K_1(\C)=\{0\}$ and $K_*(C\left( \T^2_\th\right))$ is torsion free from the above equation it turns out that

\be
\begin{split}
	K^1 \left(C\left( \T^2_\th\right) \right) \bydef KK^1(C\left( \T^2_\th\right), \C) \cong \mathrm{Hom}(K_*(C\left( \T^2_\th\right)), K_*(\C))\cong\\ \cong \Hom\left(\Z\left[u\right]\oplus \Z\left[v\right], \Z \right). 
\end{split}
\ee
Using above equations one concludes that the Hurewics homomorphism corresponds to the natural isomorphism
$$
h_{\mathrm{free}}:\pi_1\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right) \right)\to K^1 \left(C\left( \T^2_\th\right) \right).
$$




	
	
\subsection{Coverings of $O^*$-algebras}
\paragraph*{}
If $a\in \Coo\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)$ and $b\in \SS\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ then  there is the product $a\times b\in L^2\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)$ (cf. equation \eqref{nt_l2r_eqn}.
\begin{lemma}\label{nt_cont_lem}
Consider the above situation. If $\sF\left(a\times b \right)$ is the Fourier transformation of  $a\times b\in L^2\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)$ then $\sF\left(a\times b \right)$ corresponds to a complex-valued continuous map on $\R^{2N}$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
From \eqref{nt_prod_duality_eqn} if turns out that
$$
\mathcal{F}\left(a \times b \right) = \mathcal{F} a \diamond  \sF b.
$$
If $a = \sum_{k\in \Z^{2N}} c_k U_k$ (cf. equation \eqref{nt_series_eqn}) then the Fourier transformation of $a$ is given by
$$
\sF\left(a \right) = \sum_{k\in \Z^2N}c_k\delta_k
$$
where $\delta_k$ is  concentrated at $k\in \R^{2N}$ the Dirac delta function.
From the equation \eqref{nt_diamond_eqn} it follows that
\be\label{nt_mp_d_eqn}
\mathcal{F} a \diamond  \sF b= \sum_{k\in \Z^2N}c_k\delta_k\diamond b = \sum_{k\in \Z^2N}c_k e^{-ik \cdot t} \mathcal{F} b\left(t \right).
\ee
From $b \in \SS\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ it turns out  that $\sF b \in \SS\left( \R^{2N}\right)$, in particular $\sF b\in C_b\left( \R^{2N}\right)$,
If $C \bydef \left\|\sF b  \right\|_{C_b\left( \R^{2N}\right)}$ where $\left\|\cdot  \right\|_{C_b\left( \R^{2N}\right)}$ is the uniform norm on $C_b\left( \R^{2N}\right)$ then
$$
\left\|t \mapsto  e^{-ik \cdot t} \mathcal{F} b\left(t \right)  \right\|_{C_b\left( \R^{2N}\right)}=C\quad \forall k \in \Z^{2N}.
$$
On the other hand  from \eqref{schwartz_z_eqn} and the Lemma \ref{nt_xm_lem} it follows that the series $\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^{2N}}\left| c_k \right|$ is convergent, so the right part of the equation \eqref{nt_mp_d_eqn} is  convergent with respect to $\left\|\cdot  \right\|_{C_b\left( \R^{2N}\right)}$ norm. Thus one has
$$
\mathcal{F} a \diamond  \sF b\in C_b\left(\R^{2N} \right).
$$.
\end{proof}
\begin{lemma}\label{nt_smooth_lem}
In the situation of the Lemma \ref{nt_cont_lem}. The Fourier transformation of any partial derivation of  $a\times b$ of any order  to a complex-valued continuous map on $\R^{2N}$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Form \eqref{mp_parial_mult_eqn} it follows that
$$
	\partial_j \left( a \times b \right)=	\partial_j a \times b + a \times \partial_j b
$$
From $\partial_j b\in \SS\left( \R^{2N}\right)$ and the above proof it follows that $\sF\left(a\times\partial_j b \right)$ lies in   $C_b\left(\R^{2N} \right)$. On the other hand similarly to the above construction one has
$$
\sF\left( \partial_j a \times b\right) = c_k k_j e^{-ik \cdot t} \mathcal{F} b\left(t \right)
$$ From \eqref{schwartz_z_eqn} and the Lemma \ref{nt_xm_lem} it follows that the series $\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^{2N}}\left| c_kk_j \right|$ is    convergent with respect to $\left\|\cdot  \right\|_{C_b\left( \R^{2N}\right)}$ norm, so on has
$$
\sF\left( \partial_j a \times b\right)\in C_b\left( \R^{2N}\right)\Rightarrow 	\partial_j \left( a \times b \right)\in C_b\left( \R^{2N}\right)
$$
Similarly one can proof that the Fourier transformation of  partial derivations of any orders are continuous functions. 

\end{proof}
\begin{lemma}\label{nt_ss_lem}
In the situation of the Lemma \ref{nt_cont_lem}. The Fourier transformation of any partial derivation of  $a\times b\in \SS\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	From the Proposition \ref{mp_factor_prop} it follows that $b = b' \times b''$ where $b', b'' \in \SS\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)$. From $\SS\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)\subset L^2\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)$ and $C\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)\times L^2\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)= L^2\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)$ it follows that
	$$
	a \times b = \left( a \times b'\right) \times b'' \subset  L^2\left( \R^{2N}\right)\times L^2\left( \R^{2N}\right),
	$$
	and taking into account the Remark \ref{mp_l2_rem} one has
	$$
	a \times b\in C_0\left( \R^{2N}\right).
	$$
Similarly from
\bean
\partial_j \left( a \times b \right)=	\partial_j a \times b + a \times \partial_jb,\\
\partial_j a \in C\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right),\\
\partial_jb \in \SS\left( \R^{2N}\right)
\eean
one can deduce that $\partial_j \left( a \times b \right)\in C_0\left( \R^{2N}\right)$. Similar operation can be performed for all differential operator of any order, so $a \times b$ is a smooth function. Taking into account  the Lemma \ref{nt_smooth_lem} one has $a\times b\in \SS\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right) $.
\end{proof}
\begin{lemma}
For all $a \in  C\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)\setminus  \Coo\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)$ one has $a \times \SS\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)\not\subset \SS\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)$
\end{lemma}\label{nt_ss_c_lem}
\begin{proof} Let $\phi$ is a map $\R^{2N}\to \R$ such that
	\be
	\begin{split}
	\sF \phi \in \SS\left(\R^{2N}\right),\\
	\sF \phi \left(\R^{2N}\right) = \left[0,1\right],\\
	\supp \sF \phi  \subset \left\{x \in \R^{2N}\left|\left\|x\right\|< \frac{1}{2}\right.\right\}.	
	\end{split}
\ee
If $a = \sum_{k\in \Z^{2N}} c_k U_k\in  C\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)\setminus  \Coo\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)$ then from the equation \eqref{mp_znorm_eqn} it follows that there is $M\in N$ such that the map
\bean
f_\N: \Z^{2N}\to \R,\\
k \mapsto \left| c_k\right|  \left\|k \right\|^M 
\eean
If $f_\R \bydef \left| \sF\left( a \times \phi\right)\left(x \right) \right\| \left\|x \right\|^M $ then from  
From \eqref{nt_mp_d_eqn} it follows that
$$
f_\R\left(k \right) = f_\N\left( k\right) 
$$
so the map $f_\R$ is not bounded. It turns out that $\sF a \diamond\sF\phi \not\in \SS\left(\R^{2N} \right)$ or, equivalently $  a \times\phi \not\in \SS\left(\R^{2N} \right)$.
\end{proof}
\begin{lemma}
If we consider the inclusion  $\Coo\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)\subset B\left( L^2\left(\R^{N} \right) \right)$ then one has  $\Coo\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)=  C\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)\cap \L^\dagger\left(\SS\left(\R^{2N} \right)  \right)$. 
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
From the Lemma \ref{nt_ss_lem} it follows that $\Coo\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)\subset \L^\dagger\left(\SS\left(\R^{2N} \right)\right) $. Conversely from the Lemma  \ref{nt_ss_c_lem} it follows that
$$
a\in C\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)\setminus  \Coo\left( \T^{2N}_\th\right)\quad \Rightarrow \quad a\notin \L^\dagger\left(\SS\left(\R^{2N} \right)\right).
$$
\end{proof}
 From the Theorem \ref{nt_d_fin_thm} and the Exercise \ref{nt_d_fin_exer} it turns out that there is  a {pointed algebraic finite covering categories of $O^*$-algebras}  given by
\bea
\label{nt_comp_pt_o*_eqn}
	\mathfrak{S}^{\N}_{D\left(\T^{2N}_\th \right) } = \left(\left\{\pi_j: D\left(\T^{2N}_\th\right)  \hookto D\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right) \right\}, \left\{\pi^l_k\right\}\right),\quad\quad\\
		\label{nt_comp_pt_of*_eqn}
	\mathfrak{S}^{\N}_{\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_\th \right) } = \left(\left\{\left.\pi_j\right|_{\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_\th\right) }: \Coo\left(\T^{2N}_\th\right)  \hookto \Coo\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right) \right\}, \left\{\left.\pi^l_k\right|_{\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m^2_k}\right)}\right\}\right)\quad~~
	\eea
	(cf. Definition \ref{comp_o*_defn}).
The is a natural inclusion  $\SS\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)\subset \L\left( \R^{2N}\right)$ such that $\SS\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)$ is a dense subspace.  If $\widehat \H \bydef \bigoplus_{g \in J}L^2\left(\R^{2N}\right)$ is the described in the Section \ref{nt_inf_ind_repr_constr_sec} Hilbert space then an algebraic direct sum $\widehat \D \bydef \bigoplus_{g \in J}\sS\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right)$ is a dense subspace of $\widehat \D$.
 If given by \eqref{nt_comp_pt_o*_eqn} and \eqref{nt_comp_pt_of*_eqn} injective *-homomorphisms are regarded as inclusions  then there are the following inclusions
\bea\label{nt_dinc_eqn}
\pi:\bigcup_{j \in \N} D\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right) \hookto \L^\dagger\left(\widehat \D \right) ,\\
\label{nt_dincf_eqn}
\left.\pi\right|_{\bigcup_{j \in \N} \Coo\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right)}:\bigcup_{j \in \N} \Coo\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right) \hookto \L^\dagger\left(\widehat \D \right). 
\eea
 If $\widehat G \bydef \varprojlim  \Z^{2N}/\Z^{2N}_{m_j}$ there is the natural action $\widehat G\times \widehat \H\to \widehat \H$ which satisfies to \eqref{o*_dinv_eqn}. The bounded part of both  $D\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right)$ and $\Coo\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right)$ equal to $\Coo\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right)$. The $C^*$-norm completion of  $\Coo\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right)$ equals to $C\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right)$. Similarly to  \eqref{bl_cat_eqn}
one has  a pointed algebraical  finite covering category
\be\label{nt_bl_cat_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}_{C\left(\T^{n}_{{\Th}} \right)}^\N
	=\left( \left\{ \left( C\left(\T^{2N}_{{\th}} \right), C\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right), \Z^n_{m_j}, \rho_j\right)  \right\}_{\substack{j \in \N\\ ~\\~}}\right., \\ \left. \left\{  \rho^j_k: C\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\hookto C\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_k^2} \right) \right\}_{\substack{j,k \in \N\\ j < k}}\right) \subset \mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{C\left(\mathbb{T}^n_{\Theta}\right)}.
\end{split} 
\ee
(cf. \eqref{nt_cofinal_eqn}) where both $\rho_j$ and $\rho^j_k$ come from $\left.\pi_j\right|_{\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m^2_k}\right)}$ and $\left.\pi^j_k\right|_{\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m^2_k}\right)}$ respectively. It turns out that both \eqref{nt_comp_pt_o*_eqn} and \eqref{nt_comp_pt_of*_eqn} are pointed algebraic finite covering categories of $O^*$-algebras (cf. Definition \ref{comp_o*_defn}).
If $\widehat B\bydef C^*$-$\varinjlim C\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)$ then there is the given by \eqref{nt_equiv_eqn} equivariant representation $\widehat{\pi}^\oplus: \widehat{B}\hookto B\left( \widehat{\H}\right)$. From the Theorem \ref{nt_inf_cov_thm} it turns out that triple $\left(C\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_\th \right), C_0\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right), \Z^{2N} \right)$ is  the  $\widehat\pi^\oplus$-infinite noncommutative covering of $\mathfrak{S}_{C\left(\T^{n}_{{\Th}} \right)}^\N$ (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}). If $\widetilde \H$ is the norm completion of $C_0\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right)\widehat\H$ then one has
\be
\begin{split}
	\widetilde \H \cong L^2\left(\R^{2N}\right) ,\\
	\widetilde \D\bydef \widehat\D \cap \widetilde \H \cong \SS\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right) 
\end{split}
\ee
Above construction is a version of the described in \ref{comp_pt_o*_empt} general construction.
Denote by $C_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right) \bydef K\left( C_0\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\right)$ the Pedersen's ideal of $C_0\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ and let $\Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\bydef C_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\cap \L^\dagger\left(\widetilde \D \right)$. Denote by 
\be\label{nt_cood_eqn}
\begin{split}
\Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\bydef\\\bydef \left\{a\in \L^\dagger\left(\widetilde \D \right)\left|a\Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\subset \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)~ \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)a\subset \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right) \right.\right\}.
\end{split}
\ee
If $D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ a *-subalgebra of  $\L^\dagger\left(\widetilde \D \right)$ generated by $\Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ and a set of differential operators $\left\{\partial/\partial x_1, ..., \partial/\partial x_n \right\}$ then any $P \in  D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ can be represented as
\bean
P = \sum_{j=1}^m a_j P_j,\quad a_1,..., a_m\in \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right);\\
P = \sum_{j=1}^m P_j b_j,\quad b_1,..., b_m\in \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right).
\eean
where $P_j$ is a monomial of $\left\{\partial/\partial x_1, ..., \partial/\partial x_n \right\}$ for all $j=1,...,n$.
Indeed $D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ is a *-subalgebra of  $\L^\dagger\left(\widetilde \D \right)$   which  satisfies to the following equivalent conditions: 
\bea\label{nt_diff1_eqn} 
D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)=\left\{\widetilde d \in\L^\dagger\left(\widetilde\D\right)  \left|~\widetilde d\Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\subset  D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\right.\right\},\\
\label{nt_diff2_eqn}
D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)=\left\{\widetilde d \in\L^\dagger\left(\widetilde\D\right)  \left|~\widetilde d\Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right) \subset  D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\right.\right\}.
\eea

\begin{theorem}
	In the described above situation following conditions hold:
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item[(i)] The triple $\left(\Coo\left( \T^{2N}_\th \right) , \Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right) , \Z^{2N}\right) $ is the 
		$\left.\pi\right|_{\bigcup_{j \in \N} \Coo\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right)}$- inverse noncommutative limit of the given by \eqref{nt_comp_pt_of*_eqn} {pointed algebraic finite covering category $\mathfrak{S}^{\N}_{\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_\th \right) }$  of $O^*$-algebras} (cf. Definition \ref{inv_o*_lim_defn} MAXI !!!).
		\item [(ii)] The triple $\left(D\left( \T^{2N}_\th \right) , D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right) , \Z^{2N}\right) $ is the 
		$\left.\pi\right.$- inverse noncommutative limit of the given by \eqref{nt_comp_pt_o*_eqn} {pointed algebraic finite covering category $\mathfrak{S}^{\N}_{D\left(\T^{2N}_\th \right) }$  of $O^*$-algebras} (cf. Definition \ref{inv_o*_lim_defn} MAXI !!!).
	\end{enumerate}

\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}(i)
From $\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\subset C\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\subset M\left(C_0\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\right)$ it follows that
\be
\begin{split}
\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)C_c\left(\R^{2N}_{\th} \right)\subset C_c\left(\R^{2N}_{\th} \right),\\
C_c\left(\R^{2N}_{\th} \right)\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\subset C_c\left(\R^{2N}_{\th} \right)
\end{split}
\ee

 Taking into account that  $\forall j\in \N\quad \Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\subset  \L^\dagger\left(\widetilde \D \right)$ and \eqref{nt_cood_eqn} one has
 \bea
 \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty \Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\subset \Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right),\\
  \Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right)\left(  \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty \Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\right)	\subset		\Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)  \Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right),\\
    \left(  \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty \Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\right)\Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)	\subset		\Coo\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)  \Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right).
 \eea
 If $\widetilde A'$ is a $\left.\pi\right|_{\bigcup_{j \in \N} \Coo\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right)}$-admissible algebra (cf.  \ref{comp_pt_o*_empt}) then from the equations \eqref{inv_o*_llim_eqn}, \eqref{inv_o*_rlim_eqn} it follows that
\bean
\mathrm{span}\left\{ \Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right) \widetilde A'\right\}=\\=\mathrm{span}\left\{ \Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right) \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty \Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\right\} \subset  \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right),\\
\mathrm{span}\left\{  \widetilde A'\Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right)\right\}=\\=\mathrm{span}\left\{  \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty \Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right)\right\} \subset  \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)
\eean
and taking into account \eqref{nt_cood_eqn} one has
$$
\widetilde A'\subset \Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)
$$
Now for completion the proof of (i) one should show that the algebra $ \Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ is admissible, i.e. it satisfies to the  conditions \eqref{inv_o*_lim_eqn} CHANGE TO \eqref{inf_cov_o*_sub1_eqn}-\eqref{inv_o*_rlim_eqn}.
\begin{itemize}
	\item The condition \eqref{inv_o*_lim_eqn} CHANGE TO \eqref{inf_cov_o*_sub1_eqn} follows from the natural action $\Z^{2N}\times \Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\to \Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$.
	\item The condition \eqref{inv_o*_blim_eqn} follows from $\Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\cap C_b\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\subset C_b\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$.
	\item The conditions \eqref{inv_o*_llim_eqn} and \eqref{inv_o*_rlim_eqn} follow from \eqref{nt_cood_eqn}.
\end{itemize}
(ii) 
Taking into account \eqref{nt_diff2_eqn} one has
\be\label{nt_uni_inc_eqn}
\bigcup_{j=1}^\infty D\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\subset D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right).
\ee
	Let us prove that $D\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right)$ is $\pi$ admissible, i.e. it satisfies to the equations \eqref{inv_o*_lim_eqn} CHANGE TO \eqref{inf_cov_o*_sub1_eqn}-\eqref{inv_o*_rlim_eqn}; that is
	\bea\label{nt_inv_o*_lim_eqn}
	\Z^N D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)  = D\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right),\\
	\label{nt_inv_o*_blim_eqn}
	C_b\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right) \cap \L^\dagger\left(\widetilde \D \right)\subset 	C_b\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right), \\
	\label{nt_inv_o*_llim_eqn}	
	\Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)  D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)= \Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right) \left(  \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty D\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\right)  ,\\	
	\label{nt_inv_o*_rlim_eqn}
D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)  =\left(  \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty D\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)	\right)\Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right). 
\eea

	\begin{itemize}
		\item The equation \eqref{nt_inv_o*_lim_eqn} follows from $	\Z^N \Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)=\Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ and \\	$\Z^N\left\{\partial/\partial x_1, ..., \partial/\partial x_n \right\}= \left\{\partial/\partial x_1, ..., \partial/\partial x_n \right\}$.
		\item The equation \eqref{nt_inv_o*_blim_eqn} is a tautology.
		\item From \eqref{nt_uni_inc_eqn} ir follows that
		$$
 \Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right)\left(  \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty D\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\right)	\subset		\Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)  D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right).
 			$$
 		Conversely if $a \in \Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)$ and $P= \sum_{j=1}^m a_j P_j,\quad a_1,..., a_n\in \Coo\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)\in  D\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ (cf. \eqref{nt_diff1_eqn}) then 
 	\bean
 		aP = aa_1P_1 + ... + aa_mP_m = b_mP_1 + b_mP_1 =\\= b_1 1_{{\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)} }P_1 + ... + b_m 1_{{\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)} }P_m \in \Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right) \left(  \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty D\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\right)
 	\eean
 	where $b_j \bydef aa_j \in  \Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right)$ for any $j =1,...,m$.
		\item The proof of the equation  \eqref{nt_inv_o*_rlim_eqn} is similar to the proof of \eqref{nt_inv_o*_rlim_eqn} 
	\end{itemize}
	Now one should prove that $D\left( \widetilde \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ is the maximal *-algebra which satisfies to  the equations \eqref{inv_o*_lim_eqn} CHANGE TO \eqref{inf_cov_o*_sub1_eqn}-\eqref{inv_o*_rlim_eqn}. 
	If it is not maximal then there is $\widetilde d \in \L^\dagger\left( \widetilde \D\right)\setminus D\left(\widetilde \R^{2N}_\th \right)$ such that
\be
		\Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right) \widetilde d\subset  \Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right) \left(  \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty D\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\right)
\ee
	(cf. equations \eqref{inv_o*_llim_eqn} and \eqref{nt_inv_o*_llim_eqn}). However from $\Coo_c\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right) \left(  \bigcup_{j=1}^\infty D\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right)\right)\subset D\left(\R^{2N}_\th \right)$ and \eqref{nt_diff2_eqn} it follows that $\widetilde d \in  D\left(\widetilde \R^{2N}_\th \right)$. From this contradiction one concludes that $D\left( \widetilde \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ is a maximal *-algebra which satisfies to  the equations \eqref{inv_o*_lim_eqn} CHANGE TO \eqref{inf_cov_o*_sub1_eqn}-\eqref{inv_o*_rlim_eqn}. 

\end{proof}

\subsection{Coverings of quasi $*$-algebras}
\paragraph*{}

Let  $\SS'\left( \R^{n}\right) $ the vector space dual to $\SS\left( \R^{n}\right) $ (cf. Definition \ref{mp_mult_defn}), and let $G_j\bydef ker\left( \Z^{2N} \to \Z^{2N}_{m_j}\right)$

The action $G_j \times \R^n\to \R^n$ yields the action  $G_j \times \SS'\left( \R^{n}\right)\to \SS'\left( \R^{n}\right)$ denote by
\be
\left( \SS\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)'\right)^{G_j}  \bydef \left\{\left.T\in \SS'\left( \R^{2N}\right)\right| gT = T \quad \forall a \in G_j \in \right\}
\ee
\begin{lemma}
	Let 
	$\varphi_j:	S\left(\R^{2N}\right)\to \Coo\left(\T^{2N}_{\th/m^2_j} \right)$  be a given by \eqref{nt_ss_nt_map_eqn} surjective map.
	
	In the described above situation there is the natural isomorphism.
	$$
	\left( \SS\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)'\right)^{G_j}\cong \Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta/m_j^2}\right)'
	$$
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	Let $\phi\in \left( \SS\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)'\right)^{G_j}$. Define $\psi_j\in \Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta/m_j^2}\right)'$ by the following way
	$$
	\psi\left(a_j \right)\bydef \phi\left(\widetilde a \right) \quad  \text{where} \quad a_j = \varphi_j\left( \widetilde a\right). 
	$$
	Above definition is correct because $\varphi_j$ is surective and $\phi$ is $G_j$-invariant. Conversely let $\psi_j\in \Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta/m_j^2}\right)'$. Define $\phi\in \left( \SS\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)'\right)^{G_j}$  by the following way
	$$
	\phi\left(\widetilde a \right) \bydef \psi\left(a_j \right) \quad  \text{where} \quad a_j = \varphi_j\left( \widetilde a\right). 
	$$
	Constructed $\C$-linear maps are mutually inverse.
\end{proof}

An application of both the Exercise \ref{nt_quasi_fin_exer} and the given by \eqref{nt_comp_pt_of*_eqn} category 	$\mathfrak{S}^{\N}_{\Coo\left(\T^{2N}_\th \right) }$ yields a \textit{pointed algebraic finite covering category of quasi-$*$-algebras}
(cf. Definition \ref{comp_qo*_defn})  given by
\be\label{nt_distr_inf_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\left(\Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)', \Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)  \right) } =\\  =\left(\left\{\pi_j: \left( \mathfrak A, \mathfrak A_0 \right) \hookto \left( \mathfrak A^j, \mathfrak A_0^j \right) \right\}_{j \in \N}, \left\{\pi^k_l: \right\}_{\substack{k,l \in \N\\ l > k}}\right),\\
	\text{where } \left( \mathfrak A, \mathfrak A_0 \right)\bydef\left(\Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)', \Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)  \right),\\ \left( \mathfrak A^j, \mathfrak A_0^j \right)\bydef\left(\Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta/m_j^2}\right)', \Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta/m_j^2}\right)  \right).
	\end{split}
\ee


\begin{lemma}
In  the described above situation the triple
$$
\left(\left(\Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)', \Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)  \right), \left(\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)', \Coo\left(\R^{2N}_{\theta}\right)  \right) , \Z^{2N}\right) 
$$
is  the inverse noncommutative limit of the given by \eqref{nt_distr_inf_eqn} pointed algebraic finite covering category	$\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\left(\Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)', \Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)  \right) }$ of quasi *-algebras (cf Definition \ref{inv_qo*_lim_defn} MAXI !!! MAXI !!!). 
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Let $\left\{p_\a\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}\subset \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ be the subset all finite-rank projectors. If we define partial order on $\La$ such that
$$
\forall\bt , \ga\in \mathscr A \quad \bt  \le\ga  \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \im p_\bt \subseteqq \im p_\ga
$$  
then $\mathscr A$ becomes a directed set. For all $\widetilde a a \in \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ there is $\a_{\widetilde a} \in \mathscr A$ such that
\be\label{nt_comp_st_eqn}
\forall\a\in\mathscr A \quad \a \ge \a_{\widetilde a} \quad \Rightarrow \quad \widetilde a = \widetilde a p_{\a}
\ee
If $\left(\widetilde A', \Coo\left(\R^{2N}_{\theta}\right)\right)$ is an admissible quasi *-algebra (cf. Definition \ref{comp_pt_qo*_defn}) and $\widetilde a \in \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'$  such  then from the condition \eqref{inv_qo*_rlim_eqn} !!! REPLACE it follows that
$$
\widetilde a p_\a \in \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)'
$$
If $\left\langle\cdot , \cdot \right\rangle : \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)'\times \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ is a natural covering then for all $\widetilde b \in \Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)$ from \eqref{nt_comp_st_eqn}  it turns out that
$
\left\langle \widetilde a p_\a , \widetilde b\right\rangle = \left\langle \widetilde a p_{\a_{\widetilde a}} , \widetilde b\right\rangle\quad\forall \a \ge \a_{\widetilde a}
$
i.e. the net\\ $\left\{ \left\langle \widetilde a p_\a , \widetilde b\right\rangle\right\}_{\la\in\La}\in\C$ is convergent. So the net $\left\{  \widetilde a p_\a , \right\}_{\a\in\mathscr A}$ is convergent with respect to  the weak topology of $\Coo_c\left( \R^{2N}_\th\right)'$. Now we define a $\C$-linear map
\bean
\Psi: \widetilde A'\to \Coo\left(\R^{2N}_{\theta}\right),\\
 \widetilde a \mapsto \lim_{\a\in\mathscr A}\widetilde a  p_\la
\eean 
From the equation \eqref{inv_qo*_lzero_eqn} it follows that the map $\Psi$ is injective, i.e. any admissible quasi *-algebra is a subalgebra of $\left(\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)', \Coo\left(\R^{2N}_{\theta}\right)  \right)$. To finish the proof one should show that $\left(\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)', \Coo\left(\R^{2N}_{\theta}\right)  \right)$ is admissible, i.e. it satisfies to the conditions (a)-(c) of the Definition \ref{comp_pt_qo*_defn}.

\begin{enumerate}
	\item[(a)]  The natural   action $\Z^{2N}\times \R^{2N} \to \R^{2N}$ induces the action \\ $\Z^{2N}\times \left(\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)', \Coo\left(\R^{2N}_{\theta}\right)  \right) \to \left(\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)', \Coo\left(\R^{2N}_{\theta}\right)  \right)$ which complies with the natural action $ \Z^{2N}\times \Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)\to \Coo\left(\R^{2N}_{\theta}\right)$.
	\item[(b)] The inclusion $\bigcap_{j\in\N} \Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta/m_j^2}\right)'\subset\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)'$ follows from an inclusions  $\Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta/m_j^2}\right)'\subset\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)'$ for all $j\in \N$.
	
	\item[(c)] The specific versions of the equations
	 \eqref{inv_qo*_rzero_eqn}-\eqref{inv_qo*_rlim_eqn} !!! REPLACE  are presented below:
	\bea
	\label{nt_inv_qo*_rzero_eqn}
	\forall\widetilde a\in \Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)'\quad \Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right) \widetilde{a}= \{0\}\quad \Rightarrow\quad \widetilde{a}= 0,\quad\quad \\
	\label{nt_inv_qo*_lzero_eqn}
	\forall\widetilde a\in \Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)'\quad \widetilde{a}\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right) = \{0\}\quad \Rightarrow\quad \widetilde{a}= 0,\quad\quad \\
	\label{nt_inv_qo*_llim_eqn}	\mathrm{span}\left\{ \Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right) \Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)'\right\} =\mathrm{span}\left\{  \Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right) \left( \bigcap_{j\in\N} \Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta/m_j^2}\right)\right) \right\} ,\quad\quad\\	
	\label{nt_inv_qo*_rlim_eqn}\mathrm{span}\left\{  \Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)'\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)\right\} =\mathrm{span}\left\{   \left( \bigcap_{j\in\N} \Coo\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta/m_j^2}\right)\right)\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right) \right\} .\quad\quad
	\eea
	\begin{itemize}
		\item From $\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right) \widetilde{a}= \{0\}$ it follows that $p_\a \widetilde a = 0$ for all $\a\in \mathscr A$. It turns out that $\widetilde a = 0$, so \eqref{nt_inv_qo*_rzero_eqn} is proven.
		\item The equation  \eqref{nt_inv_qo*_lzero_eqn} can be proven similarly to \eqref{nt_inv_qo*_rzero_eqn}.
		\item Left and right parts of both \eqref{nt_inv_qo*_llim_eqn} and \eqref{nt_inv_qo*_rlim_eqn} equal to $\Coo_c\left(\mathbb{R}^{2N}_{\theta}\right)'$.
	\end{itemize}
	
\end{enumerate}

\end{proof}



\subsection{Covering of spectral triples}



\paragraph*{} 


Let us consider following objects
\begin{itemize}
	\item A spectral triple of a noncommutative torus\\ $\left(C^{\infty}(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta}),\mathcal{H}=L^2\left(C\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\theta}\right), \tau\right)\otimes\mathbb{C}^{2^N},D\right)$ (cf. equation \ref{nt_sp_tr_eqn}).
	\item  A good algebraical  finite covering sequence given by
	\begin{equation*}
	\mathfrak{S}_\th= \left\{	C\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_\th\right) \to	C\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\th/m_1^{2}}\right) \to C\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\th/m_2^{2}}\right) \to... \to C\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_{\th/m_j^{2}}\right)\to ...\right\}
	\end{equation*}
	given by \eqref{nt_cofinal_eqn}.
\end{itemize}
From the Theorem \ref{nt_inf_cov_thm} it follows that $\left(C\left(\mathbb{T}^{2N}_\th \right), C_0\left(\R^{2N}_\th\right), \Z^{2N} \right)$ is a  $\widehat{\pi}^\oplus$-infinite noncommutative covering of $\mathfrak{S}_\th$ (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}).
Otherwise from the Exercise \ref{nt_st_fin_exer} it follows that
\begin{equation}\label{nt_triple_seq_eqn}
\begin{split}
\mathfrak{S}_{\left(C^{\infty}\left( \T_\th\right) , L^2\left(C\left(\T^{2N}_\th \right), \tau\right) \otimes \C^{2^N} , D\right) } = \{ \left(C^{\infty}\left( \T_\th\right) , L^2\left(C\left(\T^{2N}_\th \right), \tau\right) \otimes \C^{2^N} , D\right), \dots,\\
\left(C^{\infty}\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2}\right) , L^2\left(C\left( \T^{2N}_{\th/m_j^2} \right), \tau_j\right) \otimes \C^{2^N} , D_j \right), \dots
\}.
\end{split}
\end{equation}
is coherent set of spectral triples (cf. Definition \ref{cov_sec_triple_defn}).
